The reporters were selected in advance by their employers and pledged to keep their movement secret to protect the security of the military operation. But journalists complained that the Pentagon pool did not work in Panama, where reporters were kept away from the action. The arrangement was set up after the U.S. invasion of Grenada, when journalists were kept away from the Caribbean nation entirely. Journalists from The Associated Press, Reuters, United Press International, Scripps-Howard News Service, Cable News Network, National Public Radio, the Milwaukee Journal, the Los Angeles Times and Time Magazine are in the pool.

DOC.HEAD: Big Motorcycle Rally Ends After Weekend Bar Shooting
DOC.TEXT: The 50th Black Hills Motor Classic, which lured 300,000 bikers to this town of 7,000, had everything people here had come to expect from a motorcycle rally: choppers, tattoos, leather _ and violence. Eleven people died, one man was shot and two others were stabbed in a bar brawl between motorcycle gangs, and hundreds were arrested during the weeklong event. ``As I've said before, the potential is there,'' said Sheriff Floyd Cleland. ``These people all drink booze, take drugs and carry knives and guns.'' Law officers shot to death a knife-wielding Australian who charged them, and another person died of carbon monoxide poisoning in a tent. The nine other deaths came in crashes. Marcy Myhre, executive director of the Sturgis Area Chamber of Commerce's Black Hills Motor Classic Board, had predicted last fall that this year's event could draw more than 250,000 people. Last year's rally drew only 60,000, but officials estimated that at least 300,000 showed up during the past week. ``I think that's kind of conservative,'' Myhre said of the official estimate. Long lines of motorcycles roared out of town Sunday. Bill Kienast of Oshkosh, Wis., said he was attending his first rally here and would probably return despite the bloody bar brawl. ``With this amount of people, you know there's going to be things happen. There's going to be accidents. There's going to be fights,'' Kienast said. Myhre acknowledged that some Sturgis residents were bothered by the huge crowds and violence. ``A lot of them feel it was a little too much, but a lot of them realize this is a once-in-a-lifetime crowd, too,'' she said. Law officers had made 202 drunken driving arrests and 73 drug arrests by Sunday. There were 133 reported traffic collisions, 78 involving injuries. Officers issued 1,060 traffic tickets and 2,143 warnings. The bar brawl at Gunner's Lounge and Casino Saturday night erupted between rival from the Outlaws and Sons of Silence motorcycle gangs, he said. Aggravated assault charges will be filed against two Sons of Silence gang members who were hospitalized in serious condition with stab wounds, authorities said. An Outlaws gang member who was shot in the neck was allowed to travel home to Atlanta on Sunday and was not immediately charged. Sturgis residents Ken and Barb Grosch were on Main Street on Saturday night with their video camera to record the procession of bikes and bikers. ``It's nice to see a small, boring town come alive,'' said Mrs. Grosch. ``I think it's great, but after a week or so I'm ready to see them go home.''

DOC.HEAD: Markets Close Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 26,176.43, down 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Babies Already Learning About Language Before Born, Studies Suggest
DOC.TEXT: Yuppie mothers-to-be who try to put their children on the fast track by talking to them in the womb may be on the right track. Studies have found that starting in the womb, babies recognize speech as a special sound and distinguish between spoken passages, Anthony DeCasper, a psychology professor at the University North Carolina at Greensboro, said Sunday. DeCasper described research involving a group of women who were in their 32nd week of pregnancy. Researchers asked the women to recite a particular paragraph of a children's story three times in a row each day until the birth. Three different passages were used, but each mother recited only one. About 52 hours after birth, the babies were given a special nipple and earphones. By altering their rate of sucking, they could choose to hear a woman reciting either the story their mothers had recited, or one of the other stories. They chose the familiar story, DeCasper said. ``We're talking about recognition of linguistically relevant speech sounds,'' he said. ``The implication is that fetuses heard, perceived, listened and learned about something about the acoustic structure of American English.'' In another study, 24 newborns were exposed to the sound of a heartbeat or a woman speaking, DeCasper said. They were able to choose which ear would hear the sound by varying the frequency at which they sucked a pacifier. Babies chose to hear speech in the right ear and the heartbeat in the left ear, said DeCasper. So they were already processing speech differently from other sound, he said. ``What it shows is, at birth, there is some `knowledge' of the language of the culture,'' said DeCasper, who spoke in a presentation and an interview at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association. Mriganka Sur, of the department of brain and cognitive science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the idea that the result shows specialized processing of speech sounds ``makes a lot of sense to me.'' It reflects specialization in the brain's two halves, called hemispheres, he said. That probably is driven by genes, although the experience of hearing speech before birth may also play a role, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Accident Claims Life of California Serviceman in Saudi Arabia
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto LA10 of Aug. 12
DOC.TEXT: A career military man from California who the Pentagon said was accidentally hit by a truck in Saudi Arabia has become the first American soldier to die in the U.S. buildup in the Middle East. John Campisi, a 30-year-old Air Force staff sergeant and father of four from Covina, Calif., died Sunday during troop preparations. Campisi, who had been in the military since he was 18, was assigned to Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska. ``It will be very hard on those children,'' Campisi's father, Salvatore Campisi, said. ``Anything he could do with his children he did with them.'' ``The main thing is that he was a wonderful father,'' his mother, Marge Campisi, said in a telephone interview. ``He was involved in everything with those kids _ scout leader, religious classes. He always made time for his family.'' The elder Campisi described his son as having ``the patience of Job.'' The elder Campisi said his oldest child was ``a good kid ... committed to the Air Force.'' Salvatore Campisi had carved his own career with the Navy. A Pentagon preliminary investigation indicated Campisi was hit by a truck on a dark runway. Pentagon sources speaking on condition of anonymity said he may have been wearing ear coverings that hindered his ability to hear. Pentagon spokesman Major Doug Hart said the accident is under investigation. Besides a wife of 11 years and two sons and two daughters, Campisi leaves three brothers and a sister. Two brothers are in the Navy. ``One of them just got back last week or he would have gone too,'' Campisi's mother said. Campisi grew up in West Covina, about 20 miles from downtown Los Angeles, and attended Edgewood High School, where his favorite sports were baseball and wrestling. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments involving Iraq and Kuwait:
The United States has said it will intercept Iraqi oil shipments and has indicated it will block some food shipments and other supplies from entering Iraq.

Iraqi President Saddam Hussein demanded the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Saudi Arabia and an end to the U.N. economic sanctions against his country. The Iraqi leader also warned: ``If the spark of war is started, many will be burned.''

President Bush rejected Saddam's offer to pull his troops from Kuwait if Israel withdraws from the occupied territories. ``I didn't see ... anything pleasing in there at all,'' Bush said of Saddam's statement. Israel dismissed Saddam's proposal as ``cheap propaganda.''

About 3,500 Americans are still detained in Kuwait and Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III expressed hope they'll be allowed to come out soon. ``The truth of the matter is that (Iraq) has restricted the right of all foreign nationals to leave ... that runs against all international behavior norms,'' he said.

Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. Central Command, said U.S. soldiers are aware of possible terrorist attacks against them in the Middle East. He also said of the Iraqis: ``If they do make an attack they are going to pay a price for it.''

The first U.S. journalists being allowed to travel to Saudi Arabia since American troops arrived are on their way. The Washington-based reporters were scheduled to arrive today aboard an Air Force cargo plane. Journalists had protested to the Pentagon that they were not being allowed in.

A U.S. airman in Saudi Arabia became the first American killed in the desert operation, according to the Pentagon. He is identified as Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi, a 30-year-old aircraft maintenance technician from Covina, Calif. Pentagon sources said, on condition of anonymity, that a preliminary investigation indicated Campisi was hit by a truck on a darkened runway.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Moves: A New Setback For Elusive Arab Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's conquest of Kuwait and threats against Saudi Arabia have sharpened the inter-Arab rivalries that have long thwarted hopes of forging a regional unity against Israel. The failure of the Arabs to move against Saddam for gobbling up a fellow Arab state has underlined their inherent inability to take decisive, collective action. But the debate over the Iraqi president's action still rings with appeals to pan-Arab concerns, including declarations by the Saddam himself. The various Arab factions all condemned Israel's seizure of Arab lands in 1967, and Saddam declared Sunday he was ready to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis if Israel gave up those conquests. It was Saddam's own attempt to use one of the few issues that all Arabs agree on to stir up pan-Arab support for his cause. Most Arab nations may have objected to Saddam's predatory invasion Aug. 2, but they split cleanly over what to do about it. Only a few have sent small military forces to help defend Saudi Arabia, the Arab world's bankroller. King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had no choice but to call in the Americans to defend his throne against a brother Arab because no one else was prepared to do it. The Arab League, now with 21 members, was founded in 1945 to unite the Arab world as the colonial era ended after World War II. But in a region riven by centuries-old tribal feuds, overlaid with the political and territorial confrontations spawned in the postwar era, that unity has proved to be as elusive as a desert mirage. Gen. Saad el-Shazly, a hero in the Arab world for masterminding the 1973 Egyptian assault across the Suez Canal that sent the Israelis reeling, noted in his book ``The Arab Military Option,'' that ``the Arab world is a mosaic. ``Seen from afar it looks whole, but examined closely it reveals itself no more than a pattern of glinting, multicolored fragments. The bleak but inexorable verdict has to be that it is impossible to see how Arab unity can be achieved in the foreseeable future.'' He stresses that ``three diseases ravage the Arab world, debilitating its potential strength'' _ rival ideologies, uneven economic wealth and the conflicting ambitions of its leaders. The Arab world stretches from the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic, from the Mediterranean to the Congo. Its 210 million people share a common religion, Islam. All speak Arabic, but traditions and custom vary so much that an Algerian Arab is virtually incomprehensible to a Levantine Arab from Lebanon. The creation of Israel in 1948 in what was once Palestine should, in theory, have been the catalyst for bringing the fledgling Arabs states together. But it did not _ and to this day still has not. One reason why the combined Arab armies of Syria, Jordan, Iraq, Lebanon and Egypt failed to crush the heavily outnumbered Israelis in the first Middle East war of 1948-49 was that national jealousies prevented the creation of a unified Arab command. That remains true now, three unsuccessful wars with the Jewish state later. All attempts at political union by some countries, such as Egypt and Syria, have failed because of conflicting objectives. No two Arab regimes are the same. The rivalries stemmed in large part from the arbitrary and often artificial borders drawn for many of these states by the British and French after World War I when they carved up the old Ottoman Empire. With Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, which was ruled by an emir, there are now seven monarchies, most of them absolute, like Saudi Arabia. Seven states have thinly veiled military or military-backed dictatorships, such as Iraq, Syria and Libya. The others are either one-party republics or emerging democracies. Iraq and Syria, ruled by rival wings of the Baath Arab Socialist Party, have been feuding for more than 10 years and have backed different sides in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Algeria and Morocco are at odds over the mineral-rich Western Sahara. Syrian President Hafez Assad has been scrapping with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat since 1983. Syria ended an 11-year rift with Egypt in December. Syria broke off relations with Cairo in 1978 after Egyptian President Anwar Sadat signed a peace treaty with Israel. Amid these frustrations, many Arab states have settled for forming sub-regional economic and security alliances, a move that some analysts see as evidence of a new pragmatism in the Arab world. The Gulf Cooperation Council was founded in 1981, while the Iran-Iraq war raged, and includes Saudi Arabia, Oman, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and what was then the independent emirate of Kuwait. In February 1989, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan and North Yemen _ now united with South Yemen _ formed the Arab Cooperation Council, while Libya, Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco and Mauretania joined together in the Arab Maghreb Union. Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 and his massing of tens of thousands of troops on Saudi Arabia's northern border was a body blow to the Gulf Cooperation Council, which despite its joint-security agreement failed to rally behind Kuwait. Saddam's action was also a slap in the face for Egypt, its Arab Cooperation Council partner and a leading Arab moderate which had tried to head off the Iraqi invasion. At an emergency Arab summit in Cairo on Friday, Egypt was one of only 12 Arab states that voted for a resolution on sending troops to Saudi Arabia. Economically, there are also great imbalances in the Arab world which have exacerbated the lack of unity. The oil-rich gulf states long reveled in their petro-dollar wealth while millions of fellow Arabs have languished in poverty, their countries burdened by mountainous debts. Sadat's successor, Hosni Mubarak, has skillfully guided Egypt back into the Arab fold after a decade of ostracism by the Arabs and clearly hoped to become the beacon for moderate forces in this turbulent region. His strategy appeared to be making headway until Saddam, his regional ambitions fueled by his self-proclaimed ``victory'' in the 1980-88 war against Iran, went on the warpath and shifted the center of Arab gravity from Cairo to Baghdad.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Ed Blanche, the Associated Press' Middle East News Editor based in Nicosia, has covered the region since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: How to Save a City: Give Buildings to Their Occupants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The historic heart of the old czarist capital is crumbling and can be saved only by giving it to the people who live there, says a young archaeologist who has become an influential politician. For Alexei Kovalyov, one of the gems of European culture is the prize to be won or lost by an experiment in market economics and individual responsibility. Piles of dirt and debris lie in Peace Square, once a beauty spot of the city. The broad Corinthian columns of the Kazan Cathedral are disintegrating. Majestic structures associated with Peter the Great, Dostoyevsky, Pushkin and Tchaikovsky sag in dirt and decay. About 5,000 historic buildings dating from the time when Leningrad was St. Petersburg are under official protection, but that has little practical meaning because there has been no attempt at maintenance. ``The condition of the city is catastrophic, and this applies not only to its architectural monuments, but to all of its buildings,'' said Kovalyov, 26, an intense man who began his campaign to save Leningrad in 1986, when he was an archaeology student. He now is chairman both of the city council committee on historic preservation and one of the council factions. Like most other public issues in the era of glasnost, his effort has become intensely political. ``We usually say we don't have the money, we don't have the materials, we don't have the working hands we need,'' Kovalyov said of the reconstruction effort. ``That's all an illusion. If we had normal economic relations, we would all of a sudden have the money, the material, the working hands.'' Since all buildings are public property under the Soviet system, the occupants do not care about them, he said in the Marinsky Palace, city council headquarters. Most people who live in a historic but run-down building in the center of Leningrad jump at the chance to move to a new, prefabricated apartment on the outskirts. ``The preservation of our city is possible only in one instance: if we now start to transfer homes to individual owners,'' Kovalyov said. ``These owners can be private, cooperatives ... every form of ownership permitted in other countries of the world.'' Similar plans are under way in Moscow. Both cities elected reform mayors this year and the two officials, Leningrad lawyer Anatoly Sobchak and Moscow economist Gavriil Popov, quit the Communist Party in July. Although the means are the same, Moscow's purpose is different: to start a housing market that might spur construction and end the chronic shortage of living quarters. Alexander Osovtsov, chairman of the Moscow council's commission on social policy, told the weekly Moscow News in July the city would start giving apartments to their residents beginning in early 1991. Residents with more than the officially allotted space per person, about 130 square feet, will have to buy the excess from the Moscow city government. Those with less will get certificates entitling them to new and larger housing. Moscow residents say advertisements from potential buyers already are appearing on the streets. In Leningrad, as in Moscow, the issue is part of a broader effort to eliminate the legacy of Soviet rule. Leningrad seeks a special status that could permit it to offer tax holidays, give free rein to entrepreneurs, boost tourism and possibly issue its own currency. Kovalyov and his supporters say their city of 5 million has more to preserve than Moscow or most other European capitals because there never has been enough money to modernize it. Many downtown buildings date from the time when the city sparkled as an imperial capital. Palaces and parks dot the central district. There is little traffic on Nevsky Prospekt, the main street that leads from the Alexander Nevsky Monastery, where luminaries of science, literature and music are buried, to the majesty of the Hermitage and the gold spire of the Admiralty. ``Of all the European capitals, Petersburg is the most preserved city of all,'' Kovalyov said. ``If we take London or Paris, there reconstruction was much more serious.'' Saving the city must go beyond protecting the most famous sites that attract thousands of tourists yearly, he said. ``For us, it's most important to preserve the city environment, all the way to saving every house, each structure, every gate and bracket,'' Kovalyov declared. He said Leningrad's current state is tied to its namesake, Vladimir I. Lenin, and the communist system he built. The city was known as St. Petersburg for more than 200 years after Peter the Great founded it as his capital. Then, to remove the name's Germanic flavor, it was rechristened Petrograd during World War I. It was named Leningrad in 1924, after Lenin's death. Whether to resume the old name is being discussed on the streets and in the city council. Many other cities are demanding, and getting, their old names back, but changing Leningrad to St. Petersburg is of special significance in a country whose founder has been venerated for decades. Skirmishes already have occurred in the council chamber on the sensitive topic of renaming landmarks associated with Lenin. Last spring, the council took up a proposal to rename the square in front of the Smolny Institute, Lenin's revolutionary headquarters, but referred it to a committee. It now is called Dictatorship of the Proletariat Square and the proposal is to name it for Andrei Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and human rights activist who died in December. Kovalyov said Leningrad is an appropriate name if the city continues to deteriorate, but ``if the conditions of the city's existence change, then the overwhelming majority of residents will understand the need to rename it.''

DOC.HEAD: Shattered East Europe Economies Likely to Suffer From Gulf Crisis
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Westerners' nightmares of long lines at the gas station and higher fuel prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis are already a reality in Eastern Europe. The visions last fall of new freedoms and better standards of living as first one former Soviet bloc nation and then another ousted its Communist rulers are increasingly blurred by economic difficulties. And the dramatic increase in oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait is not likely to help East European countries implement planned market reforms. In contrast, however, the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, stands to gain from the Middle East crisis. ``We can gain several billion dollars,'' Alexei M. Vasiliev, deputy director of the African Institute in Moscow, told Soviet television on Thursday. ``This is a breath of fresh air for our ruined economy.'' The Iraqi attack on its oil-rich neighbor darkened hopes that the difficult transition to a market economy would quickly mean a better standard of living. ``I would rather have gas prices go up than the cost of bread,'' said Julia Buda, a 40-year-old Budapest translator. ``But I fear both, along with everything else, will be going up.'' The Soviet Union dealt the first blow when earlier this summer it cut oil exports to East European countries by up to 30 percent. According to a CIA report, Soviet oil production has fallen in recent months because of aging oil fields, and labor and ethnic unrest. The newly democratic governments in Eastern Europe raised gasoline prices by up to 50 percent to try to cut consumption. Citizens resorted to panic buying, waiting up to 10 hours to fill their tanks. In Czechoslovakia, some people have started storing gasoline in bath tubs. But Eastern Europe is likely to feel the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis hardest in 1991. Beginning next Jan. 1, the countries grouped in the Soviet-led trading bloc Comecon will trade in hard currency at world prices. Eastern Europe faces the additional burden of the large export credits the region granted to Iraq for investment projects. It also faces unpaid bills for weapons and other products sold to Iraq. Adherence to the worldwide embargo against Baghdad ``will even more complicate the current situation,'' said Peter Havlik of the Vienna Institute for Comparative Economic Studies. Iraq owes Poland, for example, more than $500 million for weapons and other military supplies. Part of the debt was to be paid with oil. Hungary has already begun purchasing oil from Libya and Algeria to offset the Soviet reductions of some 30 percent. But the country, strapped with a foreign debt of nearly $20 billion, has to pay dollars for those imports. Havlik said Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Bulgaria were likely to be hardest hit, because they rely almost exclusively on Soviet energy imports. East Germany may have an easier time once it unites with West Germany and can rely on that mighty economy. Unification of the German states is expected to come later this year. Bulgaria recently declared a moratorium on its $10.3 billion foreign debt and has no spare hard currency to buy oil on the world market. Romania produces about half the oil it consumes, but its economy is also in ruins.

DOC.HEAD: Briton Dead In Exodus From Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners have fled Iraq and Kuwait despite the Baghdad government's attempt to close the borders, but one attempt at escape ended in death for a British businessman. The British government said Sunday Iraqi troops shot and killed the man as he tried to flee to Saudi Arabia from Kuwait. It was the first official report of a Westerner killed by Iraqi troops in Kuwait since Iraq invaded Aug. 2. ``This is a barbaric crime,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The report came as scores of foreigners were returning to their homelands Sunday with stories of rapes and other abuses by Iraqi soldiers in the emirate that Iraq overran 11 days ago. But others said the Iraqi forces appeared well disciplined and said no widespread destruction was apparent in the small Persian Gulf nation, though food supplies were dwindling. Among recent departures, 90 Filpinos arrived in Manila on Sunday, bringing to 263 the number of people who have returned to the Philipines, officials said. Seven Koreans arrived in Amman, Jordan from Baghdad on Sunday. In Iraq, a government spokesman quoted by Baghdad radio said the authorities have been instructed to ``facilitate the travel of the Arabs and foreign residents in Kuwait and other cities of southern Iraq.'' It was not clear whether the spokesman meant foreigners in Kuwait could leave the country. Some foreigners were taken from Kuwait to Baghdad in the aftermath of the Iraqi invasion. In London, the Foreign Office identified the slain businessman as Douglas Thomas Croskery of northeastern England. A source close to the family told Sky news television that Croskery, who managed a printing company, was shot Saturday. Britain said Croskery's death ``must be construed as murder'' and called on Iraq to punish the culprits, whose actions had flouted international law, the spokesman said. Kuwait's ambassador to Britain, Ghazi al-Rayes, said he was told, by sources he did not identify, that Croskery was in a two-or three-car convoy detained by Iraqi troops. ``The second (car), they stopped and immediately they shot this man. They asked the others to leave the car and go walking to the border, which was about three miles'' away, the ambassador told Sky Television news. Many foreigners told of dramatic escapes to freedom. John Norman, an accountant from Raleigh, N.C., working in Kuwait, said he rode a taxi for five hours across the Iraqi desert, chain-smoking cigarettes and nibbling on hard-boiled eggs as the cab bounced toward Jordan. At the border checkpoint, Norman said, Iraqi soldiers began firing their automatic weapons after a broadcast speech by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``It was an escape,'' Norman told The Charlotte Observer Saturday. ``It wasn't a walk through. I didn't know whether I was going to leave Iraq alive.'' He returned to North Carolina on Friday, ending an odyssey that in three days took him by cab, private car and jumbo jet from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan, to London and then to Raleigh. Norman was scheduled to leave Kuwait on a monthlong vacation Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded Kuwait. Adrian King, who was among those returning to Britain on Sunday, said he had heard a burst of machine-gun fire as the Britons made their escape. King's wife, Anne, said her German neighbor was raped by an Iraqi soldier. ``The soldier had tied the husband up, raped his wife and then made them sit down and have a cup of tea,'' Mrs. King said. But Daryl Holt, who fled to Saudi Arabia with his daughters Michelle, 10, Amanda, 6, and Caroline, 4, said he encountered no serious problems in Kuwait city ``apart for the soldiers being there.'' ``We were not threatened by them. In fact they were very courteous,'' said Holt, a banker who has lived in Kuwait for 15 years. He spoke on arrival at Heathrow airport. The newspaper Gulf Daily News reported Sunday that one group of 32 escapees included Britons, Americans, Irish, one Singaporean and one Filipino. There were 11 women and seven children among them.

DOC.HEAD: War Bride Returns Home After Hasty Marriage
DOC.TEXT: The honeymoon was short, but at least there was a wedding for Angie Nelson and her sweetheart, a soldier bound for the Middle East. ``I'm a married woman,'' Angie Ohmer, 19, announced Sunday afternoon as she stepped off a private jet returning her from her hastily arranged wedding at Fort Bragg, N.C., to Pfc. Mark Ohmer of Walled Lake. The couple planned to marry Saturday afternoon in Walled Lake, but Iraq's invasion of Kuwait forced Mark Ohmer, 20, to return to his unit, the 82nd Airborne. The wedding went on anyway _ six hours later than scheduled and about 1,000 miles from Walled Lake. The couple got help from Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., who arranged for a Michigan businessman to donate use of his jet to take the bride and her family to North Carolina. After a one-night honeymoon, Mrs. Ohmer's new husband was back with his unit, awaiting orders to ship out. ``It seems like all we ever do is say goodbye,'' Mrs. Ohmer said. ``But it's good to be married.'' The couple had planned to live in North Carolina, where Mrs. Ohmer hoped to take college classes. Now, with her husband's unit leaving, she said she will register for classes in Michigan. ``I'm going to try and find a job and keep really, really busy,'' she said. ``I didn't think about any of the bad stuff, but I'll probably start thinking about it when I get home.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 173 in Tamil Attack
DOC.TEXT: White flags of mourning today fluttered above Moslem homes in five fishing villages where Tamil gumnen massacred 173 residents with machine gunfire and machetes. Military officials raised the death toll as families brought in more bodies from the stricken villages after the Saturday night massacre. It was one of the worst eruptions of violence in this island nation's escalating ethnic conflict, which pits Tamil separatists against the Sinhalese-dominated government. Although Moslems claim neutrality in the 7-year-old civil war, the government says Tamils suspect them of siding with the army. Elsewhere in Sri Lanka, military officials said rebels suspected of being Tamils ambushed a truck in the northeastern Trincomalee district at dawn today and killed 15 Sinhalese. On Sunday, at least 15 Tamil Tiger rebels, four Moslems and six government soldiers were killed in separate incidents. A Tamil politician said Saturday's attack on Moslem villages was in retaliation for the killing of 33 Tamil villagers by Moslems earlier the same day. The People's Front of Liberation Tigers, the main Tamil rebel group, denied involvement in the massacre. At least 538 people have been killed on Sri Lanka's east coast in the past 10 days. The victims include 363 Moslems, 100 Tamils and 75 Sinhalese, military officials and politicians say. In Eravur, tension lingered as the military lifted an overnight curfew and stepped up patrols. Victims were given a mass burial. Brigadier Upali Seneviratne, the top army officer in the eastern province, said at least 40 Tamil gunmen attacked the villages. ``They broke into three groups and shot at everybody in sight,'' he said. He said the dead included 29 women and 31 children, one of whom was a 9-day-old girl. After a 90-minute raid on Eravur, the gunmen moved to adjacent villages, the officials said. The villages are clustered on the east coast, 125 miles east of Colombo. On Aug. 3, gunmen raided another eastern village and massacred 140 Moslems in two mosques. The incident set off a chain of vengeance killings. On Sunday, Sri Lankan police shot and killed 15 Tamil rebels after the guerrillas killed four Moslem farmers in Sammanturai, officials said. Six soldiers died in a rebel attack in northeastern Talaimannar on Sunday. The government blames attacks on Moslem and Sinhalese civilians on the Tamil Tigers, the militia fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in the north and east. The Tigers said Saturday's killings were carried out by pro-government Tamil agents to discredit their organization. ``Why should we attack Moslems?,'' said Lawrence Thilakar, a Tamil Tiger leader, from the group's press office in London. ``We need the fullest cooperation of the Moslem people,'' he said. ``This dangerous game being played by the government will not last long, very soon the truth will come out.'' Tamil separatists, seeking an independent nation, resumed fighting the Sinhalese-dominated government on June 11, breaking a 13-month cease-fire. At least 3,200 combatants have been killed since June. Hundreds of civilians have also been killed. Tamils say they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese comprise 75 percent and Moslems are 7 percent. In all, 14,000 people have died in the civil war, which began in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Denounces Estonia's Rejection of Soviet Constitution
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has strongly denounced Estonia's rejection of the Soviet Constitution and said the move was intended to legalize the republic's withdrawal from the Soviet Union. ``Such anti-constitutional actions, ultimatums and demands have no grounds and no future,'' Gorbachev said in a statement released late Sunday by the official news agency Tass and published today in Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper. Last Tuesday, Estonia's Parliament declared that the constitution of the Estonia Soviet Socialist Republic was no longer effective. The declaration was part of a package defining the basis for Estonia's independence negotiations with Kremlin representatives. On March 30, 1990, Estonia declared a transition period toward independence. Gorbachev rejected that move, as well as a similar step by Latvia and an outright declaration of independence by Lithuania. However, over the following months, Gorbachev has moved toward negotiations with all three Baltic states. Sunday's strong language broke the pattern. Gorbachev condemned the Estonian Parliament's move as violating United Nations principles, international standards and the Soviet Constitution on questions of territorial integrity and violation of borders. He said the Parliament's main goal appeared to be to ``legalize Estonia's withdrawal from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, bypassing the people of the republic and the existing laws.'' The statement ended by inviting Estonians to join Kremlin representatives in working out a new union treaty. Gorbachev said a democratic basis ``for solving the question of sovereignty'' will be found in this framework. All three Baltic republics have said they will seek full independence from the Soviet Union and do not plan to participate in drafting the new union treaty. Gorbachev's statement may have been aimed at supporting Estonia's large Russian population, which largely opposes the republic's independence. Russian representatives in the Estonian Parliament walked out of last week's vote on rejecting the Soviet Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: French Abortion Pill Faces Difficult Time Abroad
DOC.TEXT: The French abortion pill has proved to be a safe, efficient way of terminating early pregnancy, but it faces an uncertain future abroad. The drug, known as RU-486, has been denounced by the powerful anti-abortion lobby in the United States and has not yet been endorsed by the World Health Organization. It has been used with 96 percent success by more than 55,000 women, most of them in France and a few from 14 other countries, said Catherine Euvrard, a pharmacist and spokeswoman for Roussel-Uclaf, the manufacturer. Medical experts say RU-486, which must be used in the first seven weeks of pregnancy, has great potential for reducing illegal abortions and complications associated with surgery. The drug is known as mifepristone and is marketed as Mifegyne. France approved RU-486 in 1988 and is the only country in which it is available. Marketing is unlikely to extend beyond Britain and perhaps a few other northern European countries for at least another year. The drug prevents fertilized eggs from implanting in the uterus, causing miscarriage. It is taken with injections of the hormone prostaglandin, which causes uterine contractions and reduces the risk of hemorrhaging. Abortions in France using RU-486 cost about $145, but 80 percent is reimbursed under France's social insurance system, so the actual cost to the patient is about $30. ``RU-486 has a direct toxic, poisonous effect on a developing baby,'' American anti-abortion leader John Willke said in an interview. ``If it works, it kills the baby. If the mother changes her mind and decides not to abort, then we've given a powerful, poisonous steroid at the time of organogenesis.'' Willke is president of both the U.S. National Right to Life Committee and the International Right to Life Federation, based in Switzerland. Approval by the World Health Organization, a U.N. agency, is vital to the drug's acceptance in underdeveloped countries because of the need for followup care and fear of a black market for the job. The health organization, based in Geneva, notes cautiously that RU-486 appears to be an effective, safe approach to termination of early pregnancy and also shows potential for treating endometriosis and breast cancer. WHO spokesman Thomas Netter said, however, that the agency does not ``believe abortion is acceptable as a family planning method.'' Dr. Etienne-Emile Beaulieu, a consultant to Roussel-Uclaf who developed RU-486, has claimed WHO had not approved the drug because it feared a cutoff of U.S. funds, which make up about one-fourth of the agency's budget. Washington has withheld $100 million from the U.N. Fund for Population Activities in the past five years to protest alleged forced abortions in China. In response, Netter said: ``We are studying the administration of the drug, doses, timing, cost, logistics of delivering it to local health services, the question of follow-up and how to avoid misuse. We want to look at every aspect of the implementation of RU-486 before we can advise on general use of the drug.'' He acknowledged RU-486 was among the most sensitive matters before the agency. ``If we approve it, or if we don't approve it, we'll be accused of murder,'' he said. ``We're caught between a rock and a hard place.'' A major obstacle to selling RU-486 in the United States is a threatened boycott by anti-abortion groups of products made by Hoechst AG, Roussel-Uclaf's parent company in West Germany. If RU-486 ever reaches the American market, ``we will unleash a boycott in the U.S. of any company that sells it, any subsidiary of Roussel-Uclaf and any subsidiary of Hoechst,'' Willke said. ``It would be a blockbuster boycott involving tens of millions of people. The company would feel the effects immediately.'' On the other hand, Ms. Euvrard said, ``the pro-choice side has told us, nicely, that they will boycott us if we don't sell RU-486. Either way, we will have a boycott.'' In France this month, the Association of Catholic Families condemned the ``vulgar publicity orchestrated anew'' about the pill, which it called ``fatal for babies and, in the absence of a precise understanding, a risk for the mother.'' Roussel-Uclaf predicts global acceptance in 15 years. ``Control of overpopulation is a very big problem in the future,'' Ms. Euvrard said. ``The problem of birth control will be a top priority, even if we have to proceed with abortions. It's a question of life and death for the entire planet.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Runner Killed By Train Near Finish Line
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age runner was killed by a train after he weaved through lowered railroad crossing gates and past flashing warning lights during a race. Andrew Edin, 17, of Hinckley was about 300 yards from the finish line in the 3.5-kilometer race Saturday when he was hit by the freight train traveling at about 35 mph, police said. Edin's mother and his track coach said he probably tuned out the train's whistle because he was concentrating so hard on the race. But sheriff's Deputy Jerry Olson said he thinks the boy saw the train and ``made a judgment error.'' Other runners had raced through the gates before him. His 15-year-old brother, Michael, had to be treated for shock after he, too, reached the crossing and saw what had happened. The race was part of Quarry Days, an annual celebration in Sandstone, about 70 miles north of Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: More Arrests In Corruption Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested about a dozen people in what authorities called a probe of alleged corruption in the government of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, according to news reports today. Those arrested were stalwarts of Ms. Bhutto's left-of-center Pakistan People's Party. Pakistan's President Ghulam Ishaq Khan fired Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government a week ago on charges of political ineptitude and corruption. Only five people have been identified, although police said at least a dozen people were detained over the past two days. Charges ranged from corruption to gun-running. Supporters of Ms. Bhutto said on condition of anonymity that arrest orders were being drawn up for dozens more people, most of whom live in Ms. Bhutto's power base in the interior of her home province of Sind. A spokesman for Pakistan's interim prime minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi said none of the arrests was politically motivated. Jatoi and his Information Minister Abida Hussein said tribunals to probe corruption charges will be established and conducted by Supreme Court justices. Ms. Bhutto said she will not appear before a tribunal established by her successors. Many of those arrested were reportedly close associates of Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, the target of a litany of charges of corruption. The former prime minister repeatedly has denied corruption charges against her husband, a polo-playing landowner from southern Sind province. Hussein said tribunals will be set up sometime before the planned election date of Oct. 24, although it is unlikely they will have completed their investigations before the polls. Ms. Bhutto said army troops had surrounded the village of her former tourism minister Agha Tariq. It was not clear whether he had been arrested. Hussein said Supreme Court justices appointed to the tribunals will decide whether to try only elected officials or whether to expand their mandate to include immediate family members of politicians. Meanwhile, Ms. Bhutto's mother, Nusrat Bhutto, left Pakistan for London on Sunday for medical treatment. The elder Bhutto was a senior minister without portfolio in her daughter's Cabinet, which put her in charge of the government when Ms. Bhutto was out of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest, Fog Over East and South
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Midwest early today and scattered fog was reported over the East and South. Skies were cloudy in the West. A band of showers was forming coast to coast, winding its way like a 3,000-mile snake from Southern California through Oklahoma and Missouri and upwards to the tip of Maine. The storm system also extended to Wyoming, Utah and Colorado. Other areas expecting rain today were the Pacific Northwest and the Florida peninsula. Because of a large high-pressure system, sunny skies were expected in southern New England, much of the East Coast and the Deep South. Sunshine was also forecast for the northern central part of the country and most of the West. Continued hot weather was expected in the West, with highs in the 100s for much of inland California and southern Arizona. The forecast called for temperatures in the 90s in the South, the 80s in the East and Midwest and the 70s in the Pacific Northwest. The high for the nation Sunday was 119 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Jolts Site of June Quake
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake jolted today the Iranian city of Roudbar, site of the June 21 quake that killed 40,000 people in Gilan Province, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The temblor hit at 9:48 a.m. and measured 4.9 on the Richter scale, said the agency, monitored in Nicosia. Its epicenter was 120 miles northwest of Tehran, according to the Geophysics Center of Tehran University, it said. There were no immediate reports of damages or injuries. The quake was also felt slightly in Rasht, the provincial capital, and lasted longer than previous aftershocks, the news agency said. A temblor of magnitude 5 on the Richter scale, a measure of the ground motion recorded on a seismograph, can cause considerable damage in populated areas. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: 84-Year-Old Hostage Fixes Breakfast For Captor
DOC.TEXT: A bungling burglar got motherly treatment from an 84-year-old woman he held hostage for 5{ hours, with a home-cooked breakfast and a scolding about his criminal line of work, police said. Ruth Wolko was held inside her Bronx apartment Sunday during a standoff between police and Jose Cruz, 29, before he set her loose and surrendered, Detective Dominick Misino said. ``They developed a very unusual rapport,'' Misino said. Cruz broke into Mrs. Wolko's Riverdale apartment after neighbors called police when he allegedly was discovered ransacking another apartment. Armed with a realistic-looking toy gun, he threatened to shoot his hostage if police stormed the building, the detective said. Mrs. Wolko calmed her captor with offerings from her refrigerator and sincere concern about his predicament, police said. ``She got him juice and told him to eat,'' said neighbor Elsie Hyman. ``She has always been a loving and a courageous person, the classic Jewish mother.'' During the standoff, Mrs. Wolko cooked Cruz a kosher breakfast and asked, ``Do you have any other profession besides this one?'' she told friends. After the meal, she urged him to find a legitimate job. Cruz ultimately agreed to let her go if police would give him two cigarettes. He surrendered about two hours later. Outside, the alleged burglar told Mrs. Wolko ``I'm sorry, Ruth.'' Cruz was a complete gentleman throughout the ordeal, police said. ``When it was over, he kept asking us if she was all right. He was really concerned,'' Assistant Police Chief Aaron Rosenthal said. Cruz, a former paratrooper and prison parolee, previously has been convicted of burglary, grand larceny and criminal possession of stolen property. He will be charged with unlawful imprisonment and burglary, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Child Abuse, Drugs, Easy-to-Get Guns Could Boost Number of Killer Kids
DOC.TEXT: Child abuse leads a list of social ills contributing to rising numbers of teen-agers who kill, many who are poor and use easy-to-get guns while high on drugs, a forensics psychologist said. ``We're about to see an epidemic of juvenile violence, such as Americans have never before witnessed,'' said Charles Patrick Ewing, who has written a book titled ``Kids Who Kill.'' ``In the past five years, juvenile homicide has increased five times faster than homicides committed by adults,'' Ewing said Sunday. ``And it's not just murder. Murder is just the awful tip of the iceberg,'' he said at a press conference sponsored by the University of Buffalo at the American Psychological Association's annual meeting here. The number of juveniles arrested for murder and non-negligent homicide began a steady rise in 1985, according to figures supplied to Ewing by the FBI. In 1989, 2,208 juveniles nationwide were arrested on charges of murder or non-negligent manslaughter, more than 25 percent more than the previous year. In his study of 225 juvenile killers over the past 10 years, Ewing found that more than half came from poor backgrounds, the majority used guns and 25 percent had drugs in their systems at the time of the killings. He pointed to rising poverty figures and drug abuse statistics, as well as the increasing availability of guns, but Ewing believes escalating child abuse is the most direct influence on the growing homcide rate among teens. ``Kids learn to be violent and they learn from their role models, especially their parents,'' he said. ``And kids who are especially brutalized by their parents learn to be the most brutal, the mostly likely to kill others.'' As social problems like child abuse and drug abuse worsen, Census Bureau projections indicate a 7 percent rise in the national juvenile population after a 3.4 percent decline during the previous decade, he said. Ewing said stricter gun laws are needed, and recommended federal controls. Richard Majors, a psychologist who chairs the newly formed National Council of African-American Men, agreed with Ewing's description of what causes teens to kill. Other factors include the diminishing value placed on family, church and school, while children's peers have gained importance, Majors said. He called on large corporations to sponsor mentor programs to build urban children's self-esteem and create hope for an escape from poverty.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sharply Lower; Gold Gains
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was sharply lower against key currencies in European trading today, as concern about U.S. economic weaknesses overcame anxieties about the Middle East. Gold, a traditional refuge in times of turmoil, approached $400 an ounce. As the crisis in the Middle East has dragged on with no actual combat, traders have turned their attention back to the fundamental weakness in the dollar, dealers said. Arab leaders ``are exchanging statements, which is better than exchanging bullets,'' said Eckhart Hager, vice president and analyst at Chase Bank AG in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.65 yen, up 0.90 yen from Friday's closing rate. Later, in London, it was quoted at 150.15 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.5749 West German marks, down from 1.5895 _1.3209 Swiss francs, down from 1.3400 _5.2850 French francs, down from 5.3360 _1.7760 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7925 _1,155.60 Italian lire, down from 1,166.50 _1.1465 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1476 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8862, compared with $1.8730 late Friday. Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank in Tokyo predicted that ``the dollar would remain firm and share prices might lose ground for the time being unless the situation improves in the Middle East.'' Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $399.90 a troy ounce this morning, up from $391.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $399.00, up from $390.50 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.92 an ounce today to close at $397.67. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $4.95.

DOC.HEAD: President Turgut Ozal Takes Center Stage in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to ADD details of parliamentary vote; Pickup 5th, `There is...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal has basked in the limelight since his country, which lies on Iraq's northern border, became a key player in the Persian Gulf crisis. Yet while Ozal's popularity in the West has never seemed greater, not all Turks are happy with his paramount role in the crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug 2. As NATO's front-line state in the region, Turkey has assumed a strategic part in the international campaign to force Iraq out of its tiny oil-rich neighbor and deter President Saddam Hussein from further aggression. On Sunday, Parliament voted 216-151 to authorize the government to declare war, send troops into combat and allow foreign forces on Turkish soil, but only if the country is attacked. The vote was seen as a setback for Ozal, who wanted much broader powers to mobilize troops. There is evidence of some troop movements along both sides of Turkey's 180-mile-long border with Iraq, although Ozal and most Turkish officials say they do not expect an Iraqi invasion. The 64-year-old Ozal has led Turkey's effort to rein in Iraq. He hopes Turkey's strong stand against Saddam will translate into more Western support for this country, particularly in its bid to join the European Community. Ozal was elected president in 1989 after six years as prime minister. Although the presidency is normally a ceremonial post with little executive power, he has remained Turkey's most powerful politician. Since Iraq overran Kuwait, Ozal has clearly run the show. He has chaired Cabinet meetings, plotted strategy with military chiefs and conducted telephone diplomacy with world leaders. He has received most of the credit for the tough economic sanctions imposed against Baghdad, including the closure of twin oil pipelines across Turkey that carried more than half of Iraq's oil exports. In his speech announcing the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, Bush lauded Ozal as a ``staunch friend.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III traveled to Ankara last week to thank Ozal for the ``forthright'' action against Iraq and assure him of NATO's support in case of an Iraqi attack. But Ozal does not give the impression of a man gearing up for war. He was in Istanbul recently dancing with his wife Semra at a policeman's ball. When a reporter entered Ozal's office at the Cankaya presidential palace for an interview, he found the president watching Cable News Network and chuckling over highlights of a brawl between the New York Mets and Philadelphia Phillies. On Sunday, as Parliament debated the war powers request, Ozal attended a horse race in Istanbul. With tensions rising, Ozal went on national television last week in a skillful performance to explain Turkey's position and calm the nation. ``He went a long way to conveying to the Turkish public that the world was acting and Turkey needed to be part of the world,'' said a Western diplomat. Turkey's decision to join the economic embargo of Iraq was not an easy one, not only because the country stands to suffer more than $2 billion in losses as a result of the U.N. economic sanctions against Baghdad. Just as importantly, Ankara has sought friendly relations with Iraq and other Moslem and Arab nations of the region, while at the same time seeking to be part of the West. Ozal, a devout Moslem, stresses Turkey has not upset its delicate balance between Europe and Asia. ``We wear two hats, as a modern nation allied with the West and as a member of the Islamic bloc,'' he said Saturday. ``We want to continue this.'' Until recently, Turkey felt it was losing importance in the eyes of the West following the end of the Cold War. But Ozal hopes the current spotlight on Turkey will give the country renewed status within the West. ``This crisis has highlighted Turkey's importance in the Middle East as a stable and modern country,'' he said. Ozal's election by Parliament was boycotted by opposition parties, which accused him of nepotism, corruption and high-spending during his term as premier. Now the opposition accuses him of exceeding the powers of the presidency and violating the constitution. During a heated parliamentary debate Sunday, chief opposition leader Erdal Inonu compared Ozal to a dictator. Others say strong leadership is just what is needed. Columnist Ilnur Cevik wrote in Sunday's English language Turkish Daily News: ``As we sail though the current crisis, we are better off having an able captain than being run aground by someone else.''

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Postpones Trip To Deal With Gulf Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf background at bottom.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu postponed a trip to the Middle East because he is needed in Tokyo to decide Japan's policy on supporting the international force arrayed against Iraq, officials said today. Makoto Watanabe, director of the Foreign Ministry's Middle East affairs bureau, appeared to leave open the possibility that Japan would consider military or military-related aid even while observing the no-war clause in the Japanese constitution. The constitution, imposed by U.S.-led occupation authorities after World War II, is interpreted as limiting Japan's military forces strictly to self-defense and forbidding use of Japanese troops abroad. A decision to send troops openly to the Persian Gulf would raise a tremendous controversy in Japan, though indirect assistance in support of the multinational military force might be acceptable to the public. Kaifu had been scheduled to depart Wednesday on a 13-day trip to Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Oman and Jordan _ all of which are embroiled in the Iraqi crisis. He would have been the first outside head of government to venture into the region since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Scheduled long in advance, the trip had been planned as a general effort to improve relations with countries in the region that supplies 70 percent of Japan's oil. The decision to postpone was announced this morning after meetings during the weekend among Kaifu and top Cabinet officials. ``The situation has changed. The purpose of the trip was forced to change, and since it has become a hair-trigger crisis, we made that decision,'' Kaifu said in brief comments to reporters. Government spokesman Misoji Sakamoto, the chief Cabinet secretary, said it was ``necessary for the prime minister to stay in Tokyo and grasp all the reins of government in order to decide a concrete policy as soon as possible.'' Kaifu hopes to reschedule the trip by early October. Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama will visit the same countries to get further information on how Japan may help, Watanabe told foreign journalists. Asked repeatedly if Japan ruled out sending military aid, Watanabe said several times, ``We will examine all possible measures while observing the provisions of the constitution.'' He said Japan was determined to decide on ``concrete measures'' to assist the international force, which already includes U.S., Egyptian, British and French forces. Japan has banned all trade with Iraq and Kuwait, which were supplying 11.2 percent of Japan's oil in the first half of 1990. The decision has not caused fuel prices to rise in Japan, but economic worries have knocked Tokyo stocks off a cliff. The closely watched Nikkei index of 225 shares has declined 15.12 percent since Aug. 2, closing today at 26,176.43. Today's big drop of 4.22 percent came on extremely thin trading, as this week is Japan's traditional mid-summer holiday. Government offices will start energy-conservation measures such as reducing the use of air conditioning and lighting, and encourage the private sector to do the same, Kyodo News Service quoted officials at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry as saying. The Iraq-Kuwait crisis marks the second time in three years that the Middle East has thrown Japan's non-military postureinto an uncomfortable light. It makes Japan vulnerable to accusations of taking a ``free ride'' when others have to risk manpower, money and prestige to ensure the flow of oil from the Middle East. In 1987 the attacks on oil tankers by both sides in the Iran-Iraq war caused some to urge Japan to send at least minesweepers to the Gulf. But the government of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone decided the constitution would bar sending military forces. Later, Japan took a number of supportive steps: It paid to install advanced navigational equipment in the Gulf, extended loans and a credit line to Jordan and increased its payments to support U.S. troops based in Japan. Japanese news reports said Washington had encouraged Kaifu to go on the planned Mideast trip. Neither the Foreign Ministry nor the U.S. Embassy would deny the reports. The reports said U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who met Kaifu in Tokyo on Sunday, had said the United States supported the trip.

DOC.HEAD: Custody Battle Over Fetus Could Break New Legal Ground
DOC.TEXT: A surrogate mother carrying a couple's test-tube baby says she wants to keep it because the biological parents haven't lived up to their end of the deal and are therefore unfit. ``This is the first case that I'm aware of where the surrogate is biologically a stranger and is seeking custodial rights,'' said Christian Van Deusen, the couple's lawyer. Anna Johnson, 29, intends to sue the couple, identified only as Mark and Chris, for custody, child support and damages for emotional distress. She said she would file the suit today in Superior Court. Ms. Johnson signed a $10,000 contract to have the couple's embryo implanted and bear the child to term. She was hired because the biological mother had undergone a hysterectomy. The mother's egg and her husband's sperm were brought together in a laboratory to produce three embryos, which were implanted Jan. 19. One survived. The highly publicized Baby M dispute four years ago in New Jersey centered on a child conceived with a surrogate mother's egg and the sperm of a man hiring the surrogate. The man's wife had no biological ties to the child. Like Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother in the Baby M case, Ms. Johnson said she saw the surrogate contract as a financial opportunity. ``I thought I could save up some money, get a car, and put myself through (graduate) nursing school,'' she said. Her lawsuit will contend the couple lost interest in her pregnancy, gave her no emotional support, were late with her monthly payments and failed to buy her a life insurance policy the contract required. ``They never held up their end of the deal,'' she said. ``They were showing their irresponsibility and the fact that they would not be attentive parents. To me, this is fetal neglect.'' Van Deusen denied the allegations. ``Every payment that she was due was paid on time and, in fact, two major payments were made early,'' Van Deusen said. An insurance policy was arranged through an agent but Ms. Johnson never filled out the application despite repeated requests, he said. The couple contend Ms. Johnson broke the contract's confidentiality requirement, the Orange County Register reported Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year Search for Son's Killers Ends in Guilty Verdict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Immediately after...', to correct spelling of fliers. SUBS 11th graf, `In 1987, ... to delete extraneous time element.
DOC.TEXT: For more than a decade, Rose Hoffman nosed around biker bars, braved threats and talked to virtually everyone she met in an effort to find her son. Her quest ended this month when three men were convicted of sodomizing and murdering 20-year-old Gus Hoffman Jr. and stealing his motorcycle. His mother's ordeal began in 1978, when the young man didn't return to his San Jose home the night of July 4. ``We're a very close family, and when your son doesn't come home all night, you right then know something is definitely wrong,'' Mrs. Hoffman said. ``I would brag he was home every night, and I would say at least I know where he is.'' Hoffman was last seen on his rebuilt Harley-Davidson motorcycle at a San Jose intersection. Witnesses said he was being chased by two other motorcycles and a car filled with people. Neither his body nor the motorcycle was ever found. ``My son was a very gullible young kid. He helped a lot of people in his life. He had a heart of gold,'' Mrs. Hoffman said. ``The bike was the reason he was killed. He spent almost all his money ... on that bike. He only had it running for three weeks, and then he was missing.'' Immediately after their son's disappearance, the Hoffmans hired private investigators, sent out fliers and offered rewards. Mrs. Hoffman, now 55, began checking out biker bars and other places zfor information. ``I didn't care if I went into a grocery store or liquor store, I talked to people,'' she said. ``I just would not give up. I'm very, very persistent. He was my son. ... What would you do for your son?'' She said she was threatened and told to stop asking questions. ``But it didn't bother me,'' she said, adding that ``there are a lot of good bikers out there.'' The case had been assigned as well to police, who didn't find much. But Mrs. Hoffman kept dogging them to pursue the case. On her own, she learned that a man named Michael Lee Stevenson might have had something to do with her son's disappearance. In 1987, the San Jose Police Department's homicide chief, in an attempt to close the books on old cases by assigning them to night detectives, gave the case to Sgts. Jack Baxter and Jeff Ouimet. They took it from there. ``We knew we had leads and witnesses to talk to, which led us to other witnesses,'' Ouimet said. ``There was a ray of hope there which felt pretty good.'' A key prosecution witness turned up: the ex-wife of suspect Richard Morris Dollar, who said she witnessed the attack. Deputy District Attorney Don Shearer said the woman, whose name was withheld, had kept silent for years for fear of retribution from Stevenson and the legal system. But Stevenson, in whose garage the assault is believed to have occurred, was shot to death in 1986 by an elderly man after trying to shake down the man's son, Shearer said. In 1988, Dollar and two other alleged motorcycle gang members were arrested in Gus Hoffman's slaying. Dollar, 34, Michael Allen Hodges, 38, and John Michael Stelle, 49, face a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole at sentencing Oct. 17. Hodges' attorney, Francis Cavagnaro, said he will seek a new trial. ``It did not bring our son back,'' Mrs. Hoffman said of the conviction. ``But we did what we could to get justice, and our prayers were answered.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Blasts Iraqi Proposal, Palestinians Show Support For Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with Palestinian demonstrations in support of Iraq, Palestinians calling on Saddam to use chemical weapons on Israel. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of West Bank Palestinians rallied today in support of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, chanting ``We are with you until victory!'' and urging him to attack Israel with chemical weapons. The Israeli government, meanwhile, blasted Saddam's attempt to link an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories as ``cheap propaganda.'' But analysts warned that Saddam's proposal could lead to more violence in the 32-month Palestinian uprising against Israel. On Sunday, Saddam said he would pull out of Kuwait if Israel withdrew from the West Bank and Gaza Strip and a Syria withdrew from Lebanon, where it maintains 40,000 troops. President Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Maine, rejected Saddam's proposal. ``I didn't see ... anything pleasing in there at all,'' Bush said. The proposal was Saddam's third attempt in five days to involve Israel in the Persian Gulf crisis in a bid for grass-roots support from Arab countries. Saddam invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and subsequently annexed the emirate. Saddam's proposal drew praise from Palestinians, long frustrated by failed peace attempts. In Nablus, the West Bank's largest city, at least 2,000 people marched through the winding alleys of the old marketplace waving Iraqi flags and carried poster-sized pictures of Saddam and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat, who has allied himself with Iraq. ``Saddam, we are with you till victory!'' they chanted. ``Get rid of the collaborators working with the crusaders!'' shouted others. Many Arabs perceive support for Iraq as part of a holy war against Western influence in the Middle East. They compare the U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf to the crusaders of the Middle Ages. In Nablus, Israeli troops fired tear gas at the marchers, but there were no reports of injuries. In the West Bank town of Jenin, about 1,000 Palestinians participated in a pro-Saddam march, shouting ``Saddam, you hero, attack Israel with chemical weapons.'' Another march was reported in the Balata refugee camp near Nablus, where about 300 masked activists carried posters of Saddam and Iraqi flags. The marches were the most dramatic signs yet of Palestinian support for Saddam. Palestinian observers said such support for an Arab leader has not been seen in the occupied territories since mass demonstrations in 1970 to hail Egypt's hard-line President Gamal Abdel Nasser. They noted that since Arafat had linked his fate so closely to that of Saddam, a defeat of Iraq in the current crisis would mean a serious setback for the Palestinian cause. In several cities, masked activists used loudspeakers to shout slogans in support of Iraq, calling for a ``war against reactionary forces ... and all the leaders who support the American colonialist position.'' In Gaza, the Moslem fundamentalist Hamas group issued a sharply worded leaflet calling on Saddam ``to attack the heart of Tel Aviv if Iraq is attacked by Western crusaders.'' The leaflet also called on Palestinians to prepare themselves for a ``long and tough holy war'' against Israel and its Western allies and urged the Arab countries to attack American and other Western interests in the Arab world. Sunday, the military refused to comment on foreign reports that Israel placed its air force on alert and moved anti-aircraft missiles to the Jordanian border following threats from Iraq to use chemical weapons against it. Israeli stores have reported a huge increase in purchases of gas masks.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Tanker Not Allowed to Enter Terminal to Load
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to add Saudi refusal to comment, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's last major oil export outlet, a pipeline across the Arabian peninsula, is effectively closed and an Iraqi tanker was turned away when it tried to load at the pipeline's terminal, diplomatic sources said today. The sources at the terminal at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia said the tanker al-Qaddisiyah arrived Sunday evening and ``just tried to get alongside the jetty.'' They spoke on condition of anonymity. Tugs that are necessary to help the ships dock did not aid the tanker, and the vessel sailed away today without taking on oil, the sources said. Pumping through the pipeline also ceased, they said. Saudi officials refused to comment. The kingdom has not said publicly it would block the oil flow from the pipeline. But the diplomatic sources said there was no doubt Saudi authorities both turned away the tanker and declared the pipeline shut. About 1.5 million gallons of Iraqi crude had been passing through the pipeline daily until a boycott by most countries of Iraqi oil forced Baghdad to reduce the flow last week. The other main outlets for Iraqi crude had been two pipelines through Turkey to the Mediterranean. Those lines are no longer in operation. Iraq depends on oil revenue as its main source of income. Its daily OPEC production quota is 3.14 million barrels a day, but punitive actions taken since its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 have virtually eliminated the market for Iraqi oil. The giant Saudi Aramco company operates both the Saudi pipeline and the terminal. The Iraqis had continued to pump oil through the pipeline at a reduced rate because the tanks at the terminal were half full. Oil executives, speaking anonymously, said the tanks are now full, at about 10 million barrels. During the Iran-Iraq war, Iraq also trucked oil through Jordan to the Red Sea port of Aqaba. Jordan has avoided saying anything about allowing Iraqi oil transports, other than to say it would abide in principle with a U.N. Security Council resolution ordering an embargo on Iraqi goods. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said the United States would intercept Iraqi oil shipments to ensure full implementation of U.N. Security Council embargo. There are at least nine U.S. warships and two aircraft carriers in the Persian Gulf region. There are also warships from Britain, France and the Soviet Union in the area to help enforce the U.N. sanctions. The United States has not been using the word blockade but Baker said there was ``legal basis'' to enforce the sanctions. The pipeline through Saudi Arabia is capable of pumping 1.5 million barrels of oil daily and had been pumping at about 900,000 daily. After the U.N. sanctions were approved Aug. 6, the Iraqis slowed pumping to 400,000 barrels per day, according to some sources. Others said it had been as low as 200,000 barrels per day. Customers of Iraqi oil stopped picking up their imports immediately after the U.N. resolution was passed. Two tankers were scheduled to turn up at the Yanbu terminal after the resolution but did not show up. One was Norwegian, the other Indian.

DOC.HEAD: Two Protesters Charge They Were Run Down by Navy
DOC.TEXT: Two animal rights activists say they were struck repeatedly by Navy boats as they tried to block explosives tests that they say are harmful to dolphins. The Navy conceded the men could have been hit during the protest Friday near the Dry Tortugas islands, but said they were not hit repeatedly and not on purpose. Russ Rector, who joined Richard O'Barry _ former trainer of the television dolphin Flipper _ in the protest, charged the incident was no accident. ``They used boats as weapons,'' Rector said. ``They ran right over me. I dove down and, by the grace of God, I'm not chewed up by propellers.'' O'Barry, 50, suffered a concussion and bruises, according to a medical report from Florida Keys Memorial Hospital, and Rector suffered a back injury and bruises. ``Apparently they were pursued, and one of the boats could have hit them,'' said Dan Probert, who is overseeing the Navy trials of the explosives. Probert said he spoke with the FBI on Saturday about the incident. Dolphin activists have demanded cancellation of the Navy tests because of dolphin sightings in the area. Fishermen want the tests suspended because the region is home to several seafood varieties, and environmentalists are concerned about possible damage to nearby coral reefs. O'Barry and Rector, 42, were dropped from a sea plane into the test zone 85 miles northwest of Key West in the Gulf of Mexico. The pair were swimming when they saw boats approach, said Lincoln O'Barry, Richard's son and vice president of an activist group called the Dolphin Project. According to Rector, the two men were run over by a boat about 60 feet long and then repeatedly hit by other smaller boats. O'Barry said he was hit in the head and jabbed in the face with an aluminum pole. Probert described the scene differently. ``We have no indication of boats running over them repeatedly. So far as we know, (O'Barry and Rector) were swimming around boats trying to get to the target buoy,'' he said. ``As the boat was backing away, it appears (O'Barry) was not looking at the boat. They just literally ran into each other.'' The two activists didn't know at the time that the Navy's explosives test had been completed 45 minutes before the incident, Lincoln O'Barry said. The two men were pulled from the water by the Coast Guard and taken to the hospital in Key West on stretchers.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Pay Tribute to Berlin Wall Victims
LEADS thruout to UPDATE with ceremonies at wall. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: At a cross ringed with barbed wire, Germans from East and West paid solemn tribute today to the victims of the Berlin Wall on the 29th anniversary of its construction. Eighty East Germans died trying to escape across the now-crumbling barrier that began separating the city on Aug. 13, 1961. The best-known of them is Peter Fechter, an 18-year-old East Berlin worker cut down by Communist border guards' bullets in 1962. Fechter lay bleeding to death for nearly an hour before he was hauled away. ``Here where Peter Fechter died, we can feel how much suffering the wall caused,'' said East Berlin Mayor Tino Schwierzina during the ceremony this morning. Schwierzina stood beside the cross erected as a memorial to Fechter in West Berlin. It is located near where Fechter lay dying and calling out ``help me.'' A weathered photograph of the young man lying in agony on Aug. 17, 1962, is tacked to the dark wood. About 300 people, most of them Germans, gathered for the brief service under a brilliant sun. More than a dozen large flower arrangements were placed before the cross. Although the wall has disappeared there, windows in buildings on the Eastern side still have the bars that kept people from jumping to freedom. In years past, the Communist East Germans marked the wall's anniversary with bombastic military parades that drew criticism from the Western Allies. With the wall vanishing and Germans rushing to unification, today's service was the first joint memorial officially linking both sides. West Berlin officials promised that part of the Berlin Wall will be kept intact as a reminder to future generations. ``The wall cannot disappear completely,'' said city councilor Erich Paetzold. He said a remainder will be preserved ``so that we don't forget what happened here, so that no one forgets what happened here.'' ``The open wound is closing, but a scar will stay forever,'' Paetzold added. Paetzold and the other officials later talked quietly with Fechter's sister Ruth, who had taken part in the ceremony. Despite the solemn commemoration of the wall's victims, this year's anniversary will have an air of celebration. Tonight, the Rolling Stones are planning a concert in an outdoor sports stadium in East Berlin, and the Japanese symphony orchestra Saito Kinen, conducted by Seiji Ozawa, is to play what was billed as ``The Berlin Wall Memorial Concert.'' Twenty-nine years ago, East German military and paramilitary units stunned the world by hastily erecting the foundations for the ugly concrete barrier. The wall was built to halt the exodus of East Germans to the West. More than 2.5 million East Germans fled to the West from 1949 until the wall went up. The barrier was watched over by armed guards with ``shoot-to-kill'' orders. On Nov. 9, 1989, East Germany's Communist government opened the wall in a frantic bid to retain power and halt a renewed exodus of 200,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Lobbyist Advises Souter to be Prepared
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 12th graf, bgng, This time... to include date of confirmation hearing; picks up 12th graf pvs, Korologos said...
DOC.TEXT: Tom Korologos has some advice for Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter. It's the same advice he's given countless nominees he has shepherded through Senate confirmation. ``Get ready. Expect the unexpected.'' Korologos, a veteran Washington lobbyist and former White House aide, is active only on the fringes of the Souter nomination, lending his counsel when called upon. But he has been in the thick of the battle for confirmation of several current justices as well as in the bruising and unsuccessful 1987 fight to win Senate approval for Robert H. Bork.
