In the past two decades, he estimates he has helped steer between 200 and 300 ambassadors, judges and other government officials through confirmation, ranging from two vice presidents to ``people nobody ever heard of.'' ``You tell them the hearing process is not fair,'' he said in an interview in the ornate reception room just off the Senate floor. ``It is not judicial. It is not done on a level playing field. The senators even sit higher than you do.'' ``You say the Constitution stops at the hearing room door,'' he said. ``Hearsay evidence is admissible; rumors are admissible. There is no subject on earth to which a senator might not wish to address himself, whether it's about Roe vs. Wade or the designated hitter. ``So get ready. Expect the unexpected.'' Korologos, 57, a former Salt Lake City political reporter, came to Washington as an aide to Sen. Wallace Bennett, R-Utah, and became an assistant to Presidents Nixon and Ford. He now is president of the Washington lobbying firm of Timmons and Co. and offers his help for nominees as a free service. The first step, he said, is to sit down with the nominee and ask some questions, such as, ``Do they know what they are getting into?'' ``Most do not,'' said Korologos. ``Chances are he has never gone through a Senate confirmation.'' Souter has been through the mill once before, when he was confirmed as a member of the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, but such hearings usually are perfunctory. This time around is sure to take longer. The Senate Judiciary Committee says it will open hearings on Sept. 13 on Souter's nomination to succeed retired Justice William J. Brennan Jr. Korologos said one of his next steps is to study the voluminous financial disclosure and other papers that a nominee must fill out, ``to see if there's anything that telegraphs what's going to be coming at you.'' He asks the nominee if there is anything in his background that would be embarrassing to him or the president. ``I am not asking you to tell me,'' he says. ``I am asking you to get an answer in your head, because those guys on the Hill are going to find it out.'' Next come courtesy calls on members of the Senate Judiciary Committee and other senators with key roles in the confirmation process. An aide tags along, taking notes on what questions the senators ask. The next step is known as the murder board. ``You ge a bunch of people to sit around a table and fire the rottenest, worst questions you can possibly think of at these guys,'' Korologos said. He usually starts out by asking, ``Mr. Jones, when did you first find out the young lady in question was only 15 years old?'' ``Everybody laughs and I make the point that it could be that bad,'' said Korologos. ``You help him with answers,'' he said. ``You don't try to insert anything into his principles. But if he bobs and weaves and ducks, you say to him, `That's unacceptable; you've got to get a better answer than that.''' ``Soon, though, he's ready, and the questions from the senators aren't half as bad as the ones you asked him.'' At least not usually, Korologos said. Occasionally, they are worse.

DOC.HEAD: Sara Seegar, `Dennis the Menace' Actress, Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Actress Sara Seegar, who played Mrs. Wilson on the television series ``Dennis the Menace,'' has died. She was 76 and lived in Newtown. She died Sunday at St. Mary Hospital. Cause of death was not given. Ms. Seegar, who in private life was known as Sara Seegar Stone, appeared as a character actress on Broadway and in London, on radio and television and as one of the town ladies in the movie version of ``The Music Man.'' She also appeared 14 seasons at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope and co-produced with her husband, actor Ezra Stone, a 1983 tricentennial salute to Newtown, ``Sweet Land.'' Since 1967, she had been active in training young actors through the American College Theater Festival, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the music and theater department of the Army. ``Dennis the Menace'' was broadcast from 1959 to 1963. Ms. Seegar played the second Mrs. Wilson from 1962 to 1963 after the actor playing the first Mr. Wilson, the naughty protagonist's curmudgeonly neighbor, died and was replaced by Gale Gordon. In addition to her husband, she is survived by a son, Josef; a daughter, Francine Lida Stone; two sisters; and four grandchildren. Services will be private.

DOC.HEAD: Students, Dissidents Demand Free Travel to North Korea
LaserPhoto SEL7
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of radical students and dissidents shouting ``Unification!'' rallied today at a university to demand free travel to Communist North Korea. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters, and several dozen students hurled stones. There were no injuries or arrests at the protest outside Seoul's Yonsei University, where the 3,000 protesters had gathered in support of unification. But in a separate incident, seven students were arrested trying to cross Freedom Bridge, a major access to the border. Another five radicals were arrested in downtown Seoul shouting anti-government slogans. Also near the border, fifteen rightists were arrested after cutting a barbed wire fence and trying to march toward the Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. ``North, open the border,'' they shouted, accusing Pyongyang authorities of blocking reunions with their families, who live in North Korea. South Korea proposed opening its heavily guarded border last Saturday for unrestricted travel to North Korea, but the proposal collapsed after both sides failed to agree on procedures. The Korean peninsula was divided in 1945. South Korea and North Korea have been bitter rivals since the division. They fought a three-year war in the early 1950's. The border is sealed and there is no mail or other forms of communication between the two sides. The protesters at Yonsei University, a hotbed of anti-government protests, shouted support for a unification rally to be held with North Koreans at the border truce village of Panmunjom on Wednesday. The Seoul government has said that South Koreans can not attend the meeting unless North Korea guarantees their safety in writing. More than 61,000 South Koreans have applied to visit the North during the five-day trial border opening. At the rally, a group of folk dancers beat drums and gongs under a huge painting of a South Korean student jailed for making an illegal trip to North Korea last year without government approval. The woman student, Im Su-kyong, is hailed by North Korea and South Korean dissidents as ``the flower of unification.''

DOC.HEAD: As Lifeguards Change Their Image, Fewer Sign Up for Duty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Anyone can...', to CORRECT `don't don't' to `don't know'. SUBS 10th graf, `Now kids...', to restore dropped word `of.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Time was, being a lifeguard was a dream job: sitting atop a white tower, a bronzed Adonis for the bikini-clad teen-age girls to admire. These days, it's hard to find people interested in the job. Because of chronically low wages and costly and more rigorous certification lessons, potential candidates, especially in the Northeast, are drawn to easier, better paying jobs _ like flipping burgers in fast-food restaurants. Some beaches and pools in New England and the mid-Atlantic states have closed for lack of lifeguards, according to the U.S. Lifesaving Association. ``Not too long ago we had waiting lists of applicants,'' said Tim Hall, lifeguard coordinator for the Maine Bureau of Parks and Recreation. ``Now we have to go out and recruit them. The booming economy of the late '80s made summer jobs more available to college students. Work as chambermaids, waitresses and construction workers paid more.'' Those who do sign up, from California to Florida, are frequently much younger than in years past and not always as conscientious, longtime lifeguards said. ``Anyone can put on an orange suit but these young guys don't know what to look for,'' said Rian Wilkinson, a veteran lifeguard from Newport, R.I. ``They just sit on the stands and there aren't any older guys around to keep them from goofing off.'' Part of the shortage stems from tougher and more expensive training. In 1982, the Red Cross introduced a national lifeguard certification program to replace the simpler lifesaving courses designed for the general public. ``Now kids have to pay $75 or $80 for certification when it used to be free, and so they'd rather work somewhere else,'' said Joe Pecoraro, president of the U.S. Lifeguard Association and general supervisor of beaches and pools for Chicago. ``It used to a be a glamour position,'' said Donald Cotter, recreation director in Foxboro, who began recruiting lifeguards in January and did not sign up his last one until a week before the season opened. ``Young kids just don't want to do the training.'' Many in the profession say the tougher requirements are part of a plan to ensure that lifeguards are better trained and more professional. ``What we call the `beach mystique' is still there,'' said Hall. ``But the lifeguard's image has basically changed and that's good. We're not looking for people who want to smear suntan lotion on their bodies and look for women. We're looking for people who are interested in someday being policemen, firemen, paramedics _ who'll see lifeguarding as an emergency service provider.'' John Crisp, 42, assistant chief for lifeguards in the Daytona Beach, Fla., area, said Volusia County takes lifeguards at 16 in the hope they ``stick with us through high school and college and turn into a real professional.'' ``When I first came on here in 1972, it was party time, something to do to kill a few years,'' said Crisp. ``But now we're trying for a more professional image.''

DOC.HEAD: Clash Erupts Between Residents, Police; Talks Agreement Signed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE number of wounded to 75, arrested and size of crowd. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Quebec Native...
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of protesters, angered by a monthlong Mohawk blockade of a major commuter bridge, hurled bottles and rocks at police, who responded with tear gas. At least 75 people, including 16 police officers, were injured but none of the injuries were serious, police said. Eighteen people were briefly arrested following the four-hour melee late Sunday at Mercier Bridge, which connects Montreal with its suburbs. About 10,000 people participated in the demonstration at its peak. Earlier in the day, an agreement was signed between the Indians and the federal and provincial governments to start negotiations to bring down the Mohawk barricades. The Indians are blocking the bridge to protest plans to expand a golf course on what they claim is sacred tribal land. Today, broken bottles, bricks, rocks the size of grapefruit and tear gas canisters littered the area. Three large plate glass windows in the front of a nearby furniture store were smashed. Quebec Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia said the talks were expected to start within two days, after a team of 24 international observers chosen by the International Federation of Human Rights arrives. The observers will remain on the scene until the Mohawks remove their barricades and all police forces are withdrawn. Sunday's ceremony, also attended by federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon, was held in the pine forest behind Mohawk barricades in Oka. The Mohawks signed the agreement after provincial and federal government officials agreed to allow international observers. They will verify the free flow of food and supplies through the Mohawk barricades and to permit unimpeded access for Mohawk advisers. Mohawk negotiator Ellen Gabriel said the Indians would not remove their barricades in Oka and at the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal, where a main commuter bridge has been blocked, unless there is a final agreement. A dispute over town plans to expand a golf course on ancestral land claimed by the Mohawks led to a July 11 gunbattle between Indians and Quebec police at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, and the two sides have faced each other across barricades since then. An officer was shot to death in the clash that began when police tried to storm a barricade put up by the Mohawks. Responsibility in the death has not been established. Residents of Chateauguay and other southern suburbs across the St. Lawrence River from Montreal have been demonstrating and blocking roads in frustration at the Mohawks' blockade of the Mercier Bridge, which has forced them to take long detours to reach the city. On Sunday, about 100 local residents blocked a drawbridge with vehicles, stopping boat traffic for several hours on the St. Lawrency Seaway. The demonstrators were allowed to occupy the bridge until after the late afternoon announcement about the agreement in Oka. About 100 riot police then moved in to clear them out, and one officer received a cut to the head in a scuffle with demonstrators. Two protesters were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: More Fire-Sparking Lightning Storms Feared in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE acreage at Yosemite, Tehama County; add damage and cost of fighting fire; comments from park's chief naturalist. Picks up 11th graf pvs: ``The 200,000-acre ...' ADDS new last graf on fires abating in Utah.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Giant 2,000-year-old sequoias were treated with fire retardant to protect them against flames advancing today through the majestic forest that photographer Ansel Adams captured on film. In Oregon, 1,200 Army soldiers were being sent to take up firefighting positions. Fires also burned in Alaska, Washington, Idaho and Utah. Drought and the threat of more lightning in California worried fire officials after more than 200,000 acres burned statewide in the past week. ``More lightning means more fires,'' said Forestry Department spokesman Chris Parker. ``What we're seeing is the culmination of four years' drought.'' Yosemite was declared off limits to tourists Friday. By Sunday, more than 2,200 firefighters were battling two fires in the park that have burned 17,000 acres. The flames were about 10 miles from landmarks like El Capitan, Half Dome and Yosemite Falls, and within two miles of a stand of giant sequoias. Workers tried to protect the trees by clearing debris and undergrowth from around their trunks and applying a chemical fire retardant. Seventy-five people fled a park settlement Sunday to escape the one of the fires. Fires have burned 127 structures since last week in California ranging from outbuildings to homes. Sixty-six were in Foresta, near Yosemite. The park, which usually gets 25,000 weekend visitors, was empty of tourists. ``There's a degree of peacefulness, if you are not caught up in the frantic business of firefighting,'' said Jeff Nicholas, curator of Yosemite's Ansel Adams photo gallery. More than $10 million in property has been destroyed by the fires, Yosemite fire officials said Sunday. The cost of fighting the fire had passed $1.5 million Sunday evening. The park's chief naturalist, Len McKenzie, called the fires catastrophic and blamed past park management for the size and intensity of the blazes. By suppressing all wildfires in the forest, he said, a huge buildup of dead wood, dry grass and other fuel built up. ``We overprotected the forest,'' he said. Thunderstorms like those that brought 24,000 recorded lightning strikes last week to California were expected to return by Tuesday. The state has had below-average precipitation since the mid-1980s. In Tehama County, about 200 miles north of Yosemite, two blazes have charred a combined 130,000 acres of forest. In Sequoia National Forest, about 100 miles south of Yosemite, a fire had burned more than 24,000 acres. ``The 200,000-acre figure for the state is probably pretty conservative,'' said Forestry Department spokeswoman Karen Terrill. ``What I hear the experts saying is that this could get to be much, much worse.'' More than 12,000 firefighters were on duty around the state, most of them battling 14 major fires. More than 6,000 people worked Sunday to corral five lightning fires that have burned more than 120,000 acres of eastern Oregon, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Jim Guest. About 100 soldiers from Fort Lewis, Wash., were sent to Oregon on Sunday. A total of 1,100 more were to follow today after some quick training. A mule deer and its fawn returned to a charred area after surviving the largest of the Oregon fires. ``It's nice to see the animals come back,'' said Risa Lange-Navarro, a Forest Service field observer. Oregon's two largest fires, measuring 73,700 acres and 18,925 acres, were expected to be encircled by fire lines today. A third was surrounded late Sunday and firefighters reported making headway in trying to control the two others. Several smaller lightning-sparked fires kept Washington firefighters busy. A rash of forest and range fires that broke out in Idaho last week were brought under control Sunday. The Boise Interagency Fire Center in Idaho, which coordinates the fighting of forest fires around the country, said nearly 20,000 firefighters were at work Sunday on fires covering 856,000 acres, more than half of that in Alaska. The weather cooperated with firefighters battling blazes throughout Utah as rain and higher humidity helped crews contain the state's two biggest blazes and slow the spread of several others.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Offers Pullout But Prepares Iraq For Long Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with comments from commander of U.S. task force, Iraqi minister denies Iraq plans to attack Turkey, Britain cant recover body, details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,PX1,XCLA1
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi oil tanker steamed away empty from a loading terminal today after Saudi Arabia refused to let it dock, diplomatic sources said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein urged his countrymen to be frugal in anticipation of a drawn-out conflict. Saddam, in an apparent attempt to change the focus of debate on the Persian Gulf crisis, offered Sunday to pull out his troops from Kuwait if Israel withdraws from the occupied territories. The United States and Israel rejected the idea, but thousands of Palestinians rallied to support Saddam. The Iraqi leader tested the strength of worldwide sanctions by sending a tanker to a Red Sea terminal Sunday to take on oil from an Iraqi pipeline. Sources at the terminal at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, said the tanker al-Qaddisiyah was unable to gain entry because tugs necessary to help ships dock did not appear. The same sources said that pumping through the pipeline had ceased. The Saudi pipeline was Iraq's last major operating oil export outlet following the closure of two pipelines through Turkey last week in retaliation for the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Saddam's army took over the wealthy sheikdom Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money, then began massing along the border of Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest oil reserves. Western nations quickly boycotted Iraqi goods, including the vital oil, and some Arab nations last week joined the sanctions. American and Arab soldiers were deployed to defend Saudi Arabia, while European, Canadian, and Australian warships headed to the Persian Gulf to join a U.S. flotilla. Also, Iraqi troops were accused of fatally shooting a British businessman trying to flee Kuwait _ the first report of a foreigner dying in the invasion. Iraqi troops refused to allow a British diplomat to recover the body, the the Foreign Office said today. Saddam, in a statement read on Iraqi television, called Sunday for ``all cases of occupation, and those cases that have been portrayed as occupation'' to be resolved simultaneously, under the ``same principles and guidelines.'' He said Israel must leave the West Bank and Gaza Strip and Syria must withdraw from Lebanon if Iraq is to leave Kuwait. Israel took the territories from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Saddam also demanded the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Saudi Arabia and the end to economic sanctions against his country. The Iraqi leader warned: ``If the spark of war is started, many will be burned.'' Israel dismissed Saddam's proposal as ``cheap propaganda,'' and President Bush also rejected it. ``I didn't see ... anything pleasing in there at all,'' said Bush, on vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine. Saddam's proposal appeared aimed at broadening the debate over his invasion of Kuwait into a discussion of a host of Middle East problems, some of which remain unresolved after decades of talks and war. Palestinian leaders in the Israeli-occupied territories welcomed Saddam's proposal. An estimated 10,000 Palestinians staged a noisy demonstration of support for Iraq at a refugee camp in southern Lebanon. Chanting ``Death to America!'' the demonstrators hanged effigies of Bush and Saudi King Fahd. But Hussein Musawi, leader of a branch of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah movement, criticized Palestinians for supporting Saddam. ``Saddam is a Satan, not a Moslem leader,'' Musawi said. ``The one who waged war against the Islamic republic (Iran) and Syria and who unleashed chemical weapons against the Kurds is not a hero but a Satan.'' There were signs the Iraqis are preparing for a long siege. One day after warning that black marketeers in Iraq would be executed, Saddam urged Iraqi women to cut meat and bread consumption in half and be frugal with clothing. ``What is demanded is that no one stockpile food supplies,'' Saddam said. ``Stockpiles will bring about shortages.'' The Middle East Economic Survey, a respected weekly newsletter, reported today that despite Baghdad's claims to the contrary, the Iraqi economy is weak and ill-prepared to withstand an economic blockade. A U.N. embargo on trade has blocked outgoing oil _ Iraq's main export _ and incoming shipments of food, military parts and essential goods. However, the embargo may allow humanitarian shipments of food. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States would honor a request by the ousted Kuwaiti government to intercept Iraqi oil shipments. ``Let's not use the word blockade,'' Baker told ABC-TV. ``Let's just say we have the legal basis for interdicting these things.'' U.S. and allied warships are poised to meet Iraqi tankers coming from the Persian Gulf, Red Sea or Mediterranean Sea. Iraq is heavily dependent on oil exports to buy food and supplies for its 17 million people. A French warship sailed through the Suez Canal today en route to join three French naval units in the gulf. The Dutch government announced it was dispatching two warships. Iraq is virtually encircled on the ground with the possible exception of Jordan, where King Hussein said he is working for ``an Arab solution.'' In Iraq's northern neighbor, Turkey, the Parliament on Sunday gave the government permission to declare war and send troops into combat if Turkey is attacked. Iraqi Information Minister Nusayyif Jasim today denied allegations that Iraq was planning an attack on Turkey and said such assertions were ``part of the international conspiracy against Iraq.'' The United States has committed 50,000 troops to the crisis, and about 3,000 elite Egyptian forces had arrived by Sunday, the vanguard of 10,000-strong Arab League force. Morocco and Syria are also sending troops. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. Central Command, told pool reporters that U.S. soldiers are aware of possible terrorist attacks against them in the Middle East. Aboard the USS La Salle, flagship of the Joint Task Force Middle East, commander Rear Adm. William M. Fogarty said U.S. troops are prepared to defend themselves in case of an Iraqi chemical weapons attack. ``The fact that they do have chemical weapons is disturbing to everybody throughout the world,'' Fogarty said. But, he added ``We are a trained force.... I feel confident we are prepared to defend ourselves.'' A U.S. airman died Sunday in Saudi Arabia after an accident, becoming the first American killed in the desert operation, the Pentagon said. The dead man was identified as Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi, a 30-year-old aircraft maintenance technician from Covina, Calif. Pentagon sources said on condition of anonymity a preliminary investigation indicated Campisi was hit by a truck on a darkened runway. Meanwhile, Iraqi soldiers shot and killed British businessman Douglas Thomas Croskery in Kuwait as he tried to flee to Saudi Arabia, the British government said. A source close to the family said Croskery was slain on Saturday. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman called Croskery's slaying ``a barbaric crime'' and demanded Iraq punish those responsible. Before Saddam invaded Kuwait, he accused that country's leaders of robbing Iraq of billions of dollars by stealing oil-rich land and exceeding its OPEC oil cartel production quota, driving down world oil prices. Saddam also had demanded that Kuwait forgive $10 billion to $20 billion in loans. Iraq has a $70 billion foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 20,000 Gallons of Oil Spills into Ship Channel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with oil transfer completed; cleanup continuing. Picks up 7th graf pvs., `Cleanup crews ...'
DOC.TEXT: Salvage crews today transferred oil off a barge that buckled and leaked about 21,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil, the Coast Guard said. It was the Houston Ship Channel's third large spill of the summer. ``Now they're just trying to clean up the remaining oil,'' said Coast Guard Seaman Karl Christensen. ``They're using booms and vacuum trucks, small boats and absorbent pads. There were some skimmers and pumps supposed to be arriving later today to help with that effort.'' The accident occurred while the barge was being loaded at an Arco Petrochemical dock Sunday morning. ``It was just sitting there at the dock and apparently, it just started buckling in half,'' said Coast Guard Senior Chief Dale Eichmann. The cause of the accident was not immediately known. Crews put temporary patches over fractures in the barge Sunday evening and began transferring the oil into another vessel, Eichmann said. The transfer was completed this morning. He said the barge had been loaded with 630,000 gallons of oil. Cleanup crews strung three containment booms around the spill, and the ship channel remained open. ``It looks like we have the situation under control,'' Coast Guard Petty Officer Richard Fleming said this morning. The Coast Guard on Friday finished cleaning up a 700,000-gallon oil spill that occurred July 28 when a Greek tanker collided with two barges. The spill bottled up ships in the busy channel and prompted a brief ban on fishing in the rich Galveston Bay. Earlier this year, the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg spilled 3.9 million gallons of crude into the Gulf of Mexico off Galveston after an explosion ripped through the vessel, killing four crew members and injuring 17.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Says It Repulsed Indian Attack, India Denies Attacking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``Defense officials...' to CLARIFY that Indian troops used heavy weapons in attempt to capture Pakistani post. Pickup pvs 4th graf, ``The outpost...'
DOC.TEXT: The government said today its armed forces repulsed an attack by Indian troops along the cease-fire line that divides the disputed territory of Kashmir, officials said. India denied the claim. The Defense Ministry said the attack on a remote observation post in the Himalayas occurred Sunday, the day after talks ended between the two countries to ease border tensions. Defense officials said Indian troops used heavy artillery, anti-tank guns and mortars in an attempt to capture an outpost on the KEL sector in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir. The outpost is located about 60 miles northeast of Muzzaffarabad, the capital of Azad (Free) Kashmir. ``Our forces repulsed the attack and inflicted casualties on the intruders,'' the official said, but he gave no figures. In New Delhi, a spokesman for the Indian government denied any fighting had occurred. ``It's not true,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``We have not attacked. We have not used any artillery. We have not suffered any casualties.'' Skirmishes and small arms fire are frequent along the cease-fire line, but Sunday's assault marked the first time that heavy artillery has been used, the defense official said. The Defense Ministry said India's attack had been reported to U.N. military observers in India and Pakistan and that defense measures had been intensified. The official said the use of heavy artillery and mortars was an attempt to escalate the situation along the line of control to try to divert world attention from a Moslem secessionist movement in Indian-held Kashmir, the agency said. The uprising, which has claimed more than 950 lives since late January, has heightened already uneasy tensions between predominantly Hindu India and Moslem Pakistan, which were created along religious lines in the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The two countries on Saturday completed the second round of talks aimed at a series of ``confidence-building'' measures to relieve tensions. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the talks ``did not go well'' and that while both agreed that another round should be held, no date was set. Tensions escalated last spring between the two countries in the 43-year-old dispute over Kashmir, a former princely state claimed by both. India and Pakistan amassed their armies along the cease-fire line drawn by wars in 1948 and 1965. Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh asked his countrymen to psychologically prepare for war. The crisis was averted largely due to diplomatic pressure by the United States and the Soviet Union. India accuses Pakistan of arming, training and harboring Moslem militayts in India Kashmir, a charge that Islamabad denies. Pakistan contends India has unleased brutal force to crush an indegenious independence movement.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Esther Rolle Injured in Fatal Car Accident
LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with identity of 70-year-old victim; add background on Rolle. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Actress Esther Rolle, who played the mother in the 1970s hit television series ``Good Times,'' was seriously injured in a single-car accident that killed a Texas woman, authorities said. Miss Rolle, 69, was in serious but stable condition today following the Sunday afternoon accident, said Kathleen Brown, a nursing supervisor at University Medical Center. She declined to provide specifics about the actress' injuries. The character for which Miss Rolle is best known, Florida Evans, started on the situation comedy ``Maude'' and later became the focus of the spinoff ``Good Times.'' In ``Maude,'' Florida Evans was a sassy maid; in ``Good Times,'' the role focused more on how she was the strong-willed matriarch of her family. Just last year, she became the first woman to receive the NAACP Chairman's Civil Rights Leadership Award, which honored her work in helping raise the image of blacks through her stage, television and movie work. More recently, she appeared as the housekeeper Idella in the Academy Award-winning film ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' She was a passenger in a northbound car that rolled over on Interstate 15 near the California border, Nevada Highway Patrol troopers said. The driver was identified by the Clark County coroner's office as Paulene Hopkins, 70, of Marshall, Texas. She was pronounced dead at the scene. The car drifted off the left side of the roadway about six miles north of the California border, overcorrected and overturned into the median, according to Nevada Highway Patrol spokeswoman Mary Coyne. Two other car passengers, Martha Jordan, 63, of Las Vegas, and Mary Collins, 63, of Los Angeles, both received minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Dallas Boardinghouse Blaze; Woman Charged with Arson
DOC.TEXT: A fire early today killed four residents of a home that houses mental health outpatients, and another resident was charged with arson, authorities said. Margaret Ann Wright, 46, was taken in for questioning and charged shortly after the blaze at the boardinghouse in a south Dallas neighborhood, said Fire Department spokeswoman Carolyn Garcia. The blaze at the two-story home was doused 45 minutes after it was reported shortly before 4 a.m. Nine people lived at the home, Ms. Garcia said. At least some of the home residents were clients of the Dallas County Mental Health-Mental Retardation Center, authorities said. But Barry Waller, the agency's director of mental retardation services, could not confirm whether Ms. Wright or any of the victims were among the agency's clients. The victims, whose identities were not immediately released, ranged in age from 18 to 63, Ms. Garcia said. Three women died at the hospital, and one at the scene. All four lived on the second floor at the home, she said. The other residents, who lived on the ground floor, escaped without harm, Ms. Garcia said. Ms. Garcia said the county mental health agency uses private boardinghouses throughout the city to house outpatients.

DOC.HEAD: Potato Unlikely to Be Flavor of Month
DOC.TEXT: Potato ice cream may be a good concept, but it isn't likely to make any flavor-of-the-month lists. David Lee recently won high praise for his development of potato ice cream as part of his studies for a bachelor's degree in applied science. But Lee says the commendation he received was more for the way he replaced sugar in ice cream with potatoes rather than for the flavor itself. He said potatoes gave ice cream a flour-like taste, which he tried to counter by adding fruit pulp. That move was successful in small doses, but Lee said a 5.3-gallon batch he produced ``went down like the proverbial lead balloon.''

DOC.HEAD: Korean Tourists Going to Asian Games to Be Decided by Computer
DOC.TEXT: There are so many people who want to visit China for the Asian Games next month that a computer will decide who gets to go, officials said Monday. Those who are chosen will be required to observe at least one game and root for South Korean athletes, said authorities at the Transportation Ministry. Nearly 50,000 people, about 12 times the number authorized, have applied to visit China as tourists during the Sept. 22-Oct. 7 games in Beijing. A computer will be used to choose names at random. The number of visitors is being restricted because of limited transportation services and accommodations in Beijing. In addition to the tourists, South Korea will have about 1,500 athletes, officials and reporters in Beijing during the games.

DOC.HEAD: Conscientious Objector Ordered Freed
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year-old man who refused to serve in the army for political reasons was ordered freed from jail Monday after a court reduced his six-year jail sentence. Charles Bester had been imprisoned 20 months, since Dec. 5, 1988. The Rand Supreme Court, in upholding Bester's appeal of the six-year term, substituted it for a sentence of 20 months and ordered him released. Bester was 19 when he was sentenced for refusing to serve two years in the army for political reasons. He refused the option to become a religious objector and thereby do community service instead of going to the army. Earlier this year, the compulsory military training for white male South Africans was reduced to one year.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Employees Extend Walkout
DOC.TEXT: Greek employees at two U.S. military bases slated for closure extended a strike Monday for a week to protest the imminent loss of their jobs. The 1,000 employees at the Hellenikon air base and Nea Makri naval communications station, both near Athens, have been on strike since Wednesday. Their union said Monday the strike would continue until Aug. 20. The Greek employees at the U.S bases demand to be relocated to other spheres in the civil service when the bases are closed. They also want the United States to pay them $10 million in back pay and $26 million in social security contributions they claim have not been paid. The Nea Makri base is due to close this month, and the Hellenikon base will close early next year. A spokeswoman for the Hellenikon base, Capt. Lisa Jeffery, said Friday that the strike had had ``minimal impact on base services.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Theologist to Head World Alliance of Reformed Churches
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. theologist today was elected president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, succeeding the Rev. Allan Boesak of South Africa. Professor Jane Dempsey Douglass was elected by secret ballot at a closed session of the alliance's executive committee. Last week, the committee accepted Boesak's resignation after it was disclosed that he had an affair with a married woman. Boesak did not come to Geneva to participate in the session.. Ms. Douglass, 57, is a professor of historical theology at Princeton Theological Seminary, in New Jersey, and an elder in the Presbyterian Church (USA). She has become known as an outspoken advocate of women's rights. Her publications include ``Women, Freedom and Calvin.'' She joined the 28-member executive committee at the alliance's General Council meeting in Seoul in August, 1989. The World Alliance represents 175 churches in 84 countries with an estimated 70 million members. Ms. Douglass will serve until the next General Council. The venue and date of that assembly has not yet been fixed, but it normally takes place every five to seven years. Boesak was first elected President in 1982 in Ottawa. Boesak, an anti-apartheid activist, resigned from the church in July and said he intended to pursue a political career. He is a member of the United Democratic Front, an anti-apartheid group.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Carriers' Warplanes Conducting Fighter Missions Over Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 26-27, `The 31-year...' with 1 graf to restore dropped words. Picks up graf 28 pvs, `The F-14...'
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following story is based on a pool report from aboard the U.S.S. Independence.
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD THE USS INDEPENDENCE IN THE GULF OF OMAN (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Warplanes from the Carrier USS Independence have been conducting fighter missions over the Persian Gulf nightly since a few days after Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. The Independence, accompanied by six ships, reached the area Aug. 5, three days after the invasion, after breaking off drills at Diego Garcia, 2,500 miles south. Before visiting the Independence, a U.S. Department of Defense regional media pool was aboard the USS La Salle, flagship of the Joint Task Force Middle East, in the Gulf. Rear Adm. William M. Fogarty, commander of U.S. forces in the Gulf, said in a briefing that U.S. forces rushed to the region since the invasion are equipped with protective suits, masks and antidotes in case of an Iraqi chemical weapons attack. Asked if he was worried about chemical weapons, Fogarty said: ``The fact that they do have chemical weapons is disturbing to everybody throughout the world, but we are a trained force, if they happen to employ them.'' On the Independence, Rear Adm. Jerry L. Unruh, commander of Battle Group Delta, said the battle group's ships also were equipped to deal with a chemical attack, but that chances of such an attack were ``very, very slim.'' Fogarty described the Persian Gulf as ``a tough environment'' because of the high heat and humidity, especially in the summer. But but said: ``Our forces have met this challenge.'' He said he would not characterize the Iraqi Air Force as weak, but added, ``I'll tell you, we're better, that I know.'' Capt. Robert Ellis, commander of the Independence, said his crew averaged 18-20 years old and most were on their first deployment. There are 5,000 people on board the Independence. ``For a lot of young people this is their first time away from home and they are facing these unknowns for the first time,'' he said. Capt. Jay B. Yakeley III, commander of Navy Air Wing 14 aboard the Independence, said his pilots had had ``no close encounters'' and had not sighted any Iraqi aircraft. ``Many of them are combat-tested against Iran, we know that. We know the type of training they have. They probably have some real good pilots and some that are not so good.'' In interviews, several pilots said they were aware that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's air force had many pilots with recent combat experience in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, and said they were somewhat familiar with the French-built F-1 Mirages flown by Iraq. But they said they were more concerned about the threat of surface-to-air missles than engaging in aerial combat with the Iraqis. The pilots expressed confidence that despite their own lack of combat experience, their training and superiority of U.S. aircraft gave them confidence. ``We all feel as if we're ready for it'' said one 23-year-old ensign who flies the F-18. ``Any fighter pilot here feels that he can carry out his mission better than any Third World nation pilot,'' said another ensign. Asked whether American pilots were eager to get into a fight, he said: ``We're not warmongers out here but we're ready for action and we want to put our training to good use.'' Fogarty, who is in overall command of the U.S. forces in the Gulf and the north Arabian and Red Seas, answers to Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf III, commander in chief of central command. He said the military's mission was ``to defend against an Iraqi attack against Saudi Arabia and to be prepared to conduct other operations as directed.'' He said no decision had been made on command structure of the multinational force, but that the structure ``is being put into force right now. It is being worked on, it is a matter or coordination and communications.'' He refused to say whether U.S. forces would be subordinate to any non-American commanders. Fogarty said he had no intelligence at the time of the briefing to back up a report by diplomatic sources in Riyadh that Saudi gunners had fired on two Iraqi reconnaissance planes near Khafji on Sunday. The media pool then flew to the Independence, where another briefing was held by Unruh. He was asked whether the Navy had interdicted any oil shipping leaving Iraq or occupied Kuwait. ``We have been given no directive to stop any shipping. We are not on a blockade mission,'' he said. But he said he thought the Iraqi oil flow ``had pretty much dried up.'' Turkey last week shut off its oil pipeline, one of three primary outlets used by the Iraqis. The 31-year-old, 80,000-ton ``Indy'' carries 60 to 70 aircraft made up of seevn types: two F-14 squadrons, two squadrons of the F-18 Hornet and one of the A-6E intruder, EA-6E Prowler Electronics Countermeasures Plants, E-2C Hawkeye AWACS, S-3A Vicking anti-submarine patrol planes and SH-3 Sea King helicopters. The F-14 Fighter Gap Missions over the Gulf are to protect the U.S. Naval Force in the waterway, now totaling nine ships, and to respond to other missions as ordered, officers said. A surface warfare officer in the carrier's combat information center said the Iranians were putting out P-3 Orion surveillance plances in the area, ``But they don't get too close. They are very friendly. We talk to them and they talk to us.'' The F-14s, equipped with three kinds of air-to-air missiles, including the highly classified Phoenix, which can hit an opponent at ``long distance,'' can perform four-hour missions and stay aloft ``indefinitely'' with the support of Air Forces KC-135 and KC-10 tanker planes in Saudi Arabia, Yakeley said. The mood of the men aboard the Independence was one of anticipation that they were about to be part of an important event. ``They are glad that their country has made this commitment and that they're the ones who were picked to be out here on the front line,'' said one officer.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Crisis Puts Tough Questions to Japan
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Ask what Japan will do next to help in the Iraq crisis, and the answer is it will observe the Japanese Constitution, which forbids military activity. Ask what Washington wants Japan to do, and the answer is even more vague. No one is saying, not even whether Washington has put specific requests to Tokyo. These issues go to the heart of Japan's standing in the world today, its curious mixture of confident wealth and uncertainty of how to play the role of a big power. What specifically can Japan do in a heated crisis to back its global partners, the United States and other big Western democracies? What can it be asked to do? The administration of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu left an impression Monday of tough choices still ahead, so great that Kaifu postponed a trip to Saudi Arabia and four other Middle East countries snared in the Iraqi crisis. The nub of the issue for Tokyo is that an international military effort is growing in the Middle East, which is the source of 70 percent of Japan's oil. And Japan steers clear of foreign military actions, from painful experience a half-century ago. Instead of going to the Middle East and showing support for the countries that oppose Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Kaufu will stay at home to direct the government through the minefield of deciding how to back the international force in the Persian Gulf without violating the constitution. Japan is determined to decide on ``concrete measures'' to support the gulf force, Makoto Watanabe, director of the Foreign Ministry's Middle Eastern affairs bureau, told reporters. Asked repeatedly whether Japan might send military units such as naval vessels, he stolidly replied, ``We will examine all possible measures while observing the provisions of the constitution.'' Kaifu's government already has barred trade with Iraq and Kuwait and fully supports international economic sanctions to dislodge the Iraqis from Kuwait. The sanctions were a genuine sacrifice for Japan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said last week. Japan drew 11.2 percent of its oil from Iraq and Kuwait in the first half of this year. While Japan has 142 days worth of oil in reserve, the government is expected to authorize modest energy-conservation measures Tuesday in case the gulf standoff drags on. The crisis has knocked 15.12 percent off the closely watched Nikkei index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The big decline seems to belie predictions that Japan's economy, growing strongly at more than 4 percent annually, has a comfortable cushion in times of crisis. Whatever economic sacrifices emerge, the tough decision for the Japanese government is how far it can go to support a foreign military effort by its allies. Japan's no-war constitution is better suited to a peaceful world that does not exist. It was imposed by U.S.-led occupation authorities after World War II. The constitution declares that the Japanese people ``forever renounce war as a sovereign right'' and that armed forces ``as well as other war potential will never be maintained.'' After the outbreak of the Korean War in 1950, the constitution was interpreted to mean that Japan could maintain armed forces for self-defense. From there, Japan's defense budget has grown to a limit of 1 percent of gross national product, but there is fierce debate whenever anyone suggests projecting military force abroad. The navy, for instance, could have been chosen to protect plutonium-carrying ships from terrorists. The lower-profile coast guard was picked instead. In 1987, both sides in the Iran-Iraq war attacked oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. The United States led a multinational task force to clear the path for oil vital to Japan, but Tokyo decided it could not send even such a defensive military unit as a minesweeper to the gulf because of the constitution. Instead, Japan financed a navigation system to keep track of ships in the gulf, extended new loans and a credit line to Jordan and assumed a bigger share of the cost of basing U.S. troops in Japan. It's most likely that Japan will use money again to back the gulf crisis force. Other countries will risk manpower and prestige, and Japan will face accusations of getting a free ride again.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Larry Thorson is the AP's Asia news editor and based in Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Prices, Mortgage Rates Hurt Homebuyers
DOC.TEXT: Rising prices and mortgage rates continued to undermine the purchasing power of first-time homebuyers in the second quarter despite increased incomes, a real estate trade group said Monday. And, the National Association of Realtors added, a prolonged conflict in the Middle East will drive up mortgage rates even further, adversely affecting not only the entry-level sector, but the entire housing market as well. The Realtors said its first-time homebuyer affordability index was 72.9 in the April-June period, meaning a typical renter family with wage earners between 25 and 44 years old had 72.9 percent of the income needed to qualify for financing to buy a typical starter home. The index measured 73 during the previous quarter. The Realtors' composite index measuring the affordability of all buyers of existing homes was 104 during the second quarter, down from 104.3 from January through March. The median income of a first-time homebuyer rose $245 to $23,368 in the second quarter. The median income means half of the buyers earn more, half less. However, the typical first-time buyer would need an income of $32,061 _ $8,693 higher than the median income _ to qualify for conventional financing covering 90 percent of a home priced at $81,800, the median starter-home price. The Realtors said a first-time buyer would qualify to buy a home costing just $59,600. The starter-home price rose $300 during the second quarter. The closing interest rate used in the index rose from 10.04 to 10.15 percent including additional fees, or points, paid at settlement. Private mortgage insurance raised the interest rate to 10.40 percent. The changes in price, income and interest rate resulted in a monthly payment of $668, up $9 from the first-quarter. Realtors President Norman D. Flynn said the association expects mortgage rates to ease if the Middle East crisis ends quickly. ``If the crisis is of longer duration, we expect there to be a significant negative impact on housing markets and affordability, especially for first-time buyers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: US Moving Ahead With Naval Barricade of Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 10 grafs new with Fitzwater, pool report; pick up 4th graf pvs bgng ``I consider...; cuts bottom 5 grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today its naval barricade of Iraqi ships is taking hold as the United States and its allies squeeze Saddam Hussein economically so the Iraqis cannot ``maintain their war machine.'' The Bush administration said bluntly today that even food would be withheld from Iraq. ``You don't give them the essentials that enable them to carry on the war,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. In Saudi Arabia, where American troops are building a massive defense against any further Iraqi aggression, the acting chief of staff for U.S. troop operations told reporters, ``I think our position grows stronger with each day that goes by.'' As Maj. Gen. Don L. Kaufman spoke, the steady drone of planes brought more soldiers and hardware to the Saudi desert. Kaufman said planes were landing virtually every 10 minutes or so with their military cargo. On the economic front, Fitzwater said the sanctions endorsed by the United Nations are hurting Baghdad. ``The purpose of the embargo is to put the pinch of them,'' Fitzwater said in Kennebunkport, where President Bush is vacationing. ``We assess the impact of the embargo as excellent.'' He said the White House had ``obvious humanitarian concerns'' about prohibiting food imports into Iraq. But he added: ``The purpose of the sanctions and the embargo is to put the pinch on them. It seems fairly obvious to me you don't let foodstuffs and other things go in that are subject to the sanctions. The purpose is not to let supplies go in that allow them to maintain the war machine, allow them to maintain their aggressive takeover of Kuwait.'' Asked about reports that Jordan was allowing Iraqi shipments through, Fitzwater said, ``We are hopeful that Jordan will comply. They have said they will abide by the sanctions.'' Fitzwater also said the White House reported ``two or three ships in recent hours that have turned away or been turned away or at least have otherwise not landed with their cargo.'' An Iraqi tanker tried to dock at a Saudi terminal to take on oil, but was turned away by Saudi officials, diplomatic sources in the region reported. Bush and his top aides are avoiding the word ``blockade'' to describe a U.S. decision to use whatever means necessary to choke off Iraq's oil trade and imports of other goods, including food. But their intention was clear. ``I consider interdiction of shipping to be in accord'' with United Nations economic sanctions, Bush told reporters Sunday. ``No point getting into all these semantics. The main thing is to stop the oil from coming out of there and that is what we're going to do.'' Diplomatic sources at the oil terminal near Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, said the Iraqi tanker al-Qadissiyah, which could carry up to 900,000 barrels of oil, failed in its attempt to moor Sunday night because three tug boats that normally would help have been taken out of the water. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the tanker sailed away today, after its apparent attempt to defy a U.S. declaration that its warships would enforce a U.N. embargo aimed at forcing Iraq's Saddam Hussein to give up his forced annexation of Kuwait. Prince Bandar Bin Sultan, the Saudi ambassador to Washington, said on ``Good Morning America'' that Saddam should not try to make the Israeli territories a part of the Kuwait crisis. ``He is mixing the issues,'' the ambassador said. ``That is not an excuse for an Arab country to go an invade another Arab country.'' The United States intensified its military fortification of Saudi Arabia and the surrounding seas over the weekend, sending in Marine and Army air assault troops and shipping Patriot surface-to-air missiles and other sophisticated air-deployed weapons to the region. Sources who disclosed the movements said Pentagon planners assumed that, in the event of an Iraqi attack, an initial air battle could be decisive. The commander of the U.S. military action, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, briefed reporters at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida on the logistical difficulties of transporting troops and backup equipment 7,000 miles by air and 12,000 miles by sea. Schwarzkopf said the Iraqis are ``dug in right now for a strong defense.'' ``We have built up a great deal of force over there now ... and if they do make an attack they are going to pay a price for it,'' he said. Schwarzkopf said troops would be on guard against terrorists as well as Iraqi guns and gas. An estimated 50,000 troops are committed to Saudi Arabia in the initial deployment, with contingency plans for a force up to 250,000. ``I would never tell you that the American forces that are there are 100 percent out of harm's way,'' the general said. Indeed, the Pentagon reported the first casualty of the military action on Sunday. Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi, a 30-year-old aircraft mechanic from Covina, Calif., was klled when he was hit by a truck on a darkened runway. While soldiers took up their stations in the Saudi deserts, the White House pressed forward with its economic isolation of Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States would begin ``almost instantly'' to ``take measures that are necessary and proportionate in order to enforce the (United Nations) sanctions.'' Asked if the United States was mounting a naval blockade, Baker _ appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' _ said: ``Let's simply say that we now have the ability, the legal basis for interdicting those kinds of shipments.'' He declined to use the word blockade. Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Maine, said the U.N.-approved embargo ``gave us broad authority, working in conjunction with others, to do whatever is necessary to see no oil goes out.'' Asked if the United States would block shipments of food as well as oil, the president said, ``Just watch. Everything.'' The Washington Post today quoted a senior administration official as saying, ``We will fire on a ship if it won't stop. We'll do the usual things _ warn them off, fire a shot across the bow. But if it comes to that, there is no question what we will do.'' The U.S. pledge to stop the flow of goods in and out of Iraq came after Kuwait's exiled leader, Sheik Jaber Alahmed Al-Saba, asked that the United States take steps to ensure the U.N. economic sanctions take hold. As the Bush administration vowed to quarantine Iraq, Saddam, in a statement read by a spokesman on television in Baghdad, urged his people to prepare for hardships that may result from the international economic sanctions. He also linked any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Israel seized the occupied territories from Egypt and Jordan in 1967. The White House ``categorically'' rejected Saddam's proposals, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, calling them ``another attempt at distracting from Iraq's isolation and at imposing a new status quo.'' Only the unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait will satisfy the United States, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Circus Says Muscle Man Left to Fight for Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi circus performer whose specialty is pulling out car engines with his bare hands left his French troupe to join the Iraqi army, the circus director said Monday. Zanouk el Habib, 23, returned home because he was worried about his family and wished to fight if Iraq went to war, said Pierro Bidon, director of the Archaos Circus. Bidon said Zanouk left Aug. 7. He did not know if the Iraqi national had been reunited with his mother and three sisters, who live near Baghdad. Zanouk is 6-feet-9 and weighs 375 pounds. Bidon said he hired Zanouk after watching him destroy the interior of a bar in Barcelona, Spain. The director said Zanouk worked as a merchant seaman before joining the circus, based in southern France.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Citizens Express Hope for Further Collaboration With U.S.
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens on Monday expressed hope that the new cooperation between the United States and Soviet Union in the Persian Gulf crisis will lead to further collaboration. ``It seems everyone has finally understood, as they should have long ago, that only joint efforts can bring something positive,'' said Svyeta Buzenkova, 20, a Muscovite interviewed on Red Square. She suggested the two superpowers combine efforts in cultural pursuits, space research and other areas, and said she believed the warming relations will only improve. ``I think people now are ... finding it more and more interesting to talk to each other,'' Ms. Buzenkova said. Army Lt. Alexander Soldatov said he regretted the years that the Soviet Union sent millions of dollars in weaponry and military aid to Iraq. The Kremlin cut off arms shipments after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``It's too bad that those are our weapons there,'' he said. ``I wish they had never been sent.'' After the invasion, Secretary of State James A. Baker III joined Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow for a rare joint statement condemning the invasion and urging a worldwide arms embargo on Iraq. The Soviet Union has two warships in the Persian Gulf but so far has declined to join U.S. efforts to interdict Iraqi shipping. Soviet officials say they would consider participating in a naval interdiction sponsored by the United Nations. Victor Borovik, a retiree who lives in Moscow, praised the U.S.-Soviet cooperation in the Middle East following decades of superpower competition in the oil-rich region. ``I don't think we should be suspicious any longer of the United States,'' he said. ``We need to continue to take joint measures to put out the fire in case of any military conflict. ``We need to prevent bloodshed and sit down for talks to resolve this,'' he said, standing on the sloping drive between the Kremlin and St. Basil's cathedral. ``But they are aggressors and should be stopped.'' Borovik and others echoed their government's cautious approach to taking military action against Iraq. ``Our military absolutely should not get involved in a military conflict,'' he said. ``I hope the Soviet Union uses its best efforts for a peaceful resolution ...The globe has shed too much blood.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Australian Ships Head for Persian Gulf to Help U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Pakistan announcing troops to be sent to Saudi Arabia. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `British Foreign;' minor editing thereafter.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos SYD1,2
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Australia said today they will help the United States interdict Iraqi shipping, but France said it would not join the barricade because that would make it a ``co-belligerent'' in the Persian Gulf. The Netherlands said it would send two frigates to the area as a symbol of solidarity, and Pakistan announced it would send troops to Saudi Arabia to join thousands of U.S. forces already there as a defense against Iraqi troops massed in southern Kuwait at the Saudi border. No date for departure or number of troops were given by the Pakistani Foreign Ministry. Earlier today, official Egyptian sources said the first Syrian ground forces were expected in Saudi Arabia before Tuesday, but Saudi sources said only that the Syrians are expected this week. British Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave announced this afternoon that sailors would board any vessel attempting to break economic sanctions against Iraq, imposed in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait. ``If there is evidence of sanctions-busting, the Navy will take the necessary steps,'' Waldegrave told a news conference. The Foreign Office said Britain was responding to a request from the Kuwaiti government in exile that it take steps to insure the effectiveness of sanctions authorized last week by the U.N. Security Council. President Bush said Sunday he would use any means necessary to enforce the United Nations' embargo. ``I consider interdiction of shipping to be in accord'' with U.N. sanctions, Bush told reporters Sunday. Asked if the shipments of food would be interdicted as well, Bush said: ``Just watch. Everything.'' Iraq imports about 75 percent of its food, including basic foodstuffs like rice and meat. In Paris, a government spokesman told reporters that a U.N. trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait, occupied by at least 130,000 Iraqi troops, does not extend to intercepting shipments of oil by the government of Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. Any attempt by French warships to stop tankers would make France a ``co-belligerent'' in the oil-rich region along with Iraq, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Dutch government did not immediately announce whether its two ships, which may not arrive until September, would interdict Iraqi shipping. ``The Dutch military presence contributes to international solidarity in discouraging further Iraqi aggression,'' said the letter from the Dutch cabinet to the Parliament. Added a spokesman for British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, ``Certainly we haven't mentioned blockade at this stage, or interdiction.'' He did not rule out a future change in policy. Mrs. Thatcher is taking a vacation in England, and her spokesman in London said he did not know whether she and Bush had discussed the U.S. plan. ``Economic sanctions are indeed the way it should be played initially,'' the spokesman said, on condition of anonymity. ``I think the idea of sending our forces down there is very much a deterrent. The primary bite should be the economic sanctions.'' A spokesman at Australia's Foreign Ministry did not hestitate to use the term ``blockade.'' He said, also on condition of anonymity, that the aim of the naval force was to prevent any supplies going into or out of Iraq. The Soviet Union has two warships in the gulf, but has said it would consider joining a blockade only under U.N. auspices. Vladimir Polyakov, Moscow's new ambassador to Egypt, told reporters in Cairo that 8,000 economic and military advisers were in Iraq but none took part in the conquest of Kuwait. Three thousand Egyptian soldiers had arrived in Saudi Arabia by Sunday, the vanguard of a 10,000-member Arab League force, including Syria and Morocco that the league last week agreed to send. About 1,000 more Egyptian troops were scheduled to arrive today, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. military effort in the Middle East, said Sunday the deployment of American forces was running ahead of schedule. Up to 50,000 U.S. troops are expected to arrive in Saudi Arabia in the coming weeks. U.S. officials said as many as 250,000 could be sent, depending on how the Iraqi threat unfolds. Schwarzkopf said American forces are outnumbered by the Iraqi troops, who continue to pour into Kuwait. The Iraqi occupation force is estimated at 130,000 to 170,000 men. The U.S.-led multinational force and the Arab League force will apparently be coordinating their operations under the Saudi military. The British frigate HMS Battleaxe also arrived in the gulf region Sunday, joining the destroyer HMS York and the frigate HMS Jupiter, the Ministry of Defense said. Three Royal Navy minesweepers depart for the gulf from Scotland today. A squadron of Tornado fighters is in Saudi Arabia, another of Jaguar warplanes is in Oman, and weapons, spares and equipment have been flown to the gulf in Hercules transport planes, the Ministry of Defense said. The United States already has nine ships in the gulf, seven in the Mediterranean, and aircraft carriers and their battlegroups in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean. Canada, Denmark and West Germany have also committed ships. In Ankara, Turkey, Parliament on Sunday gave the government permission to declare war and send troops into combat if Turkey is attacked. Turkey has moved squadrons of jet fighters to bases near the Iraqi border.

DOC.HEAD: North Sea Oil Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: Workers at 70 North Sea oil installations went on a 24-hour strike Monday, their fourth work stoppage in 11 days. A spokesman for the Offshore Industry Liaison Committee, which seeks recognition as a union and improved safety standards, said at least 7,000 workers were participating. Two oil companies hit by the action said the number of strikers was much lower. British Petroleum said 76 of 1,435 workers at 19 of its installations walked out. Shell U.K. said 200 of its 2,000 oil workers did so. The oil companies said production was not affected. A total work stoppage would affect 10,000 workers on 100 platforms. British workers in North Sea oil operations are members of assorted unions, and the Liaison Committee wants to represent all of them. Nearly 400 workers were continuing an 11-day-old sit-in at Shell's Brent Field in the East Shetland basin. They are refusing orders to return to shore, said Keith Clyne, a spokesman for the Liaison Committee. He said 2,000 men had been fired for participating in work stoppages since the strikes began Aug. 2. A spokesman for the Offshore Contractors' Council said claims of poor safety conditions were a ``media gimmick.'' ``This industry this year will spend 750 million pounds ($1.4 billion) on safety enhancements,'' he said. ``Safety is taken extremely seriously.'' The world's worst oil platform disaster occurred in the British North Sea in July 1988, when an explosion and fire at the Piper Alpha platform killed 167 men. A helicopter crash that killed six oil workers July 25 was the latest of several aircraft accidents in the oilfields over the past four years.

DOC.HEAD: In Desperate Move, Palestinians Support Saddam Hussein
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied lands are celebrating President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as a savior who can win back the West Bank and Gaza Strip and restore Arab pride by teaching the Americans a lesson. The euphoric support for Saddam has replaced the widespread despair gripping Palestinians since Middle East peace efforts broke down and their 32-month uprising against Israel lost momentum. It also has united the PLO _ already closely allied with Saddam _ and Moslem fundamentalist factions that have been at each others' throats during the uprising. Pro-Saddam sentiments reached near-frenzy Monday, a day after Saddam said he would only consider pulling out of Kuwait if Israel withdrew from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Thousands marched in pro-Saddam rallies in the West Bank and celebrated him as a national hero who would deliver by force what diplomacy failed to achieve. In the West Bank's largest city, Nablus, some 2,000 people chanted ``Saddam, we are with you until victory!'' and waved Iraqi flags and posters of the leader. In the town of Jenin, about 1,000 marchers urged Saddam to attack Israel with chemical weapons. Leading pro-PLO activists said the outbursts are a measure of the frustration over failed peace efforts. They blamed the United States for not forcing its close ally, Israel, to make a deal with the Palestinians and give up occupied land. ``People here are frustrated that there is no solution to their plight. That explains their enthusiastic support for somebody who might find that solution,'' said Radwan Abu Ayyash, head of the Arab Journalists Association in the occupied lands. ``The Palestinians are anti-American, not pro-Saddam,'' Abu Ayyash told The Associated Press. He said Americans applied a double standard by demanding Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait while accepting Israel's continued occupation of territories won in the 1967 Middle East war. ``People are wondering why the Americans are suddenly Rambo in the Persian Gulf, and where was Rambo in 1967,'' Abu Ayyash said. Faisal Husseini, another leading pro-PLO activist, said Saddam has given Palestinians new hope by linking Israeli and Iraqi withdrawals. ``If there is one way to solve our problem, it is through Saddam's initiative. It would solve all problems of international legitimacy in the area,'' Husseini said. Many Palestinians said the Persian Gulf crisis is the final blow to efforts by Secretary of State James A. Baker III to broker peace talks between the Israelis and Palestinians. Husseini once tentatively backed the Baker plan, which called for preliminary talks in Cairo to discuss an offer by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to hold elections in the occupied lands. But he said Shamir's refusal to accept the Baker plan has forced the Palestinians to give up. The Palestinians' support for Saddam, meanwhile, closed one of the few channels of communication between Israelis and Palestinians. Israeli doves from the Labor Party, led by elder statesman Abba Eban, decided Sunday to suspend all meetings with Husseini and other leaders until the Palestinians denounce Saddam. ``My colleagues and I cannot possibly have a fruitful discussion with Palestinians who applaud the brutality of Saddam,'' Eban said in a telephone interview. Doves from Labor and other left-wing parties have been meeting regularly with Palestinian leaders to find common ground for peace negotiations. Officials in Shamir's government said they were not surprised by the Palestinians' pro-Saddam stance. Shamir's government views the new Palestinian militancy as proof the PLO cannot be a partner in negotiations. It also reduces U.S. pressure on Israel to launch peace talks. Among the Palestinians, meanwhile, there were only a few voices warning against support for Saddam. ``The Palestinians are now sitting in Saddam's boat. If the boat sinks, you can say goodbye to the Palestinians,'' said Zuhair Dubi, a respected pro-PLO journalist and mosque preacher from Nablus. ``A defeat of Saddam will set the Palestinian cause back for decades.'' Palestinian economist Hisham Al Khatib warned that the wealthy gulf states, angered by the Palestinian position, may fire many of the estimated 800,000 Palestinians working there, and throw them out. Hundreds of Palestinians, who were vacationing in the West Bank at the time of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, have already been barred from returning to their jobs in Saudi Arabia, Abu Ayyash said. Palestinian workers in the gulf send about $250 million a year to relatives in the West Bank and Gaza. If the funds dry up, it would be a serious blow to the Palestinian economy, already badly shaken by the uprising. But the warnings are not dampening the euphoria, which has quickly assumed religious overtones. Moslem fundamentalist groups have stirred up emotions by calling for a jihad, or holy war, against U.S. forces deployed in Saudi Arabia. The Moslems compare the Americans to the Christian Crusaders who invaded the Holy Land in the 11th through 14th centuries before being defeated by the Arabs. ``We call on Iraq to attack the heart of Tel Aviv if Iraq is attacked by the Western crusaders,'' said a leaflet distributed Monday in the Gaza Strip by the fundamentalist group Hamas. The Islamic Supreme Council, the highest Moslem authority in Jerusalem and the occupied lands, called on all Arabs to send money and weapons to Iraq to fight the ``U.S. conspiracy against Islam.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede MONROVIA
Rebel Leader Offers to Discuss Cease-fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with rebel leader willing to discuss cease-fire, adds byline, changes dateline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Charles Taylor agreed today to meet with Gambian leader Sir Dawda Jawara to discuss West African calls for a cease-fire in Liberia's civil war. It was the first time Taylor agreed to such talks. Taylor's maneuver will likely delay deployment of a five-nation West African task force mobilizing in neighboring Sierra Leone. The force was expected to move into the besieged Liberian capital of Monrovia this week to force a truce in the war. Taylor earlier said his troops would fight any peacekeeping force. Also today, about 200 foreigners, including one American, left Monrovia to rendezvous with U.S. Marine helicopters in Buchanan, the rebel-held port about 90 miles southeast of Monrovia. More than 200 Marines from warships off the Liberian coast were airlifted to Monrovia on August 5 to evacuate Americans and protect U.S. installations. Washington has said they would not intervene in the war. On Sunday, President Samuel Doe reversed an earlier promise to step down by October and said he wants to stay in office for at least a year after the regional force moves in to halt the fighting. Taylor has repeatedly demanded Doe's immediate resignation. A communique from the rebels said Taylor accepted an invitation from Jawara and would meet him in Banjul, the Gambian capital. The communique was issued at Taylor's headquarters in Harbel, 35 miles east of Monrovia. The communique said Taylor also would talk with Nigerian leader Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, Ghana's Flt. Lt. Jerry Rawlings and Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni, who is current chairman of the Organization of African Unity. ``It is the president's (Taylor's) considered view that ECOWAS (Economic Community of West Africa) has a role to play, and (there is) an even wider one for the OAU,'' the statement said. ``He is convinced that a meaningful solution can be worked out.'' Leaders of the Economic Community of West Africa decided last week to send troops to halt the 8-month-old civil war that has left at least 5,000 people, mostly civilians, dead. The force will include troops from Ghana, Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria and Sierra Leone. Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana is commander in chief of the West African force. At least 18 civilians were killed Sunday when government soldiers attacked rebels trying to take an airport. Also Sunday, three Western news agency reporters were detained and beaten by government soldiers who threatened to shoot them as spies after they crossed through rebel lines. Among the reporters was Michael Goldsmith, 68, of The Associated Press. The reporters were brought under guard to Doe's heavily fortified mansion, where they were released and met with a government spokesman, who apologized for the soldiers' actions. The rebels have accused Doe of corruption and human rights abuses during his 10 years in power. Two rebel groups, one led by Taylor and the other by Prince Johnson, together control most of the nation's territory. Doe's statement that he will remain in office reverses an earlier offer he made in May to resign before elections scheduled for October. Doe's insistence on remaining in power will also go against West African leaders' plans to install an interim government in Liberia to organize free elections. The West African plan bars any of the warring parties from participating in the interim government. Rival rebel leader Prince Johnson has agreed to the West African plans. Johnson has also said he is not interested in leading Liberia, while Taylor has appointed a rebel government of which he is president. Taylor said he is opposed to holding elections in the country for four or five years.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Several Thousand Demonstrate in Support of Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand Sudanese shouting anti-American slogans marched through Khartoum on Monday in support of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and demanded the withdrawal of foreign troops from Arab lands. The demonstrators marched to the American Embassy, where they handed an unidentified embassy official a memorandum protesting the U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia. ``Down, down U.S.A., go away C.I.A.! Shame on your American Arab agents! Strike strike Saddam! Forward, forward Saddam!'' chanted the demonstrators, carrying pictures of the Iraqi president. They then marched to the Iraqi Embassy and handed an embassy official a memorandum of support. It was the second pro-Saddam, anti-American demonstration in Khartoum since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. At an emergency Arab summit held in Cairo, Egypt, on Friday, Sudan expressed reservations about sending Arab troops to protect Saudi Arabia and other gulf countries from an attack by Iraq. Sudan's military ruler, Omar Hassan Ahmed el-Bashir, met Monday with PLO chief Yasser Arafat. At the Arab summit, the PLO also expressed reservations about deploying Arab troops to the gulf region. ``The United States is determined to escalate the crisis,'' Arafat said upon his unexpected arrival in Khartoum. El-Bashir said he and Arafat discussed ``the continuation of efforts to find a solution for the crisis following the failure of the recent Cairo Arab summit to find an outlet from the explosive situation in the gulf.'' He warned that the present situation could have ``dangerous consequences.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Returning to Washington for Pentagon Briefing, Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after graf 13, bgng, The purpose xxx to UPDATE with White House saying it will not interdict medical supplies, picks up 14th graf pvs, Bush called ...; DELETES old graf 17, Pressed on..., now redundant
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will break off his vacation Tuesday to return to Washington for two days of briefings on the crisis in the Persian Gulf and on the budget deficit, the White House said today.
