White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the embargo against Iraq was holding and he defended the U.S. plan to cut off even food shipments, saying the United States does not want to feed Saddam Hussein's ``war machine.'' On Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait, Fitzwater criticized Iraqi reports that foreigners were free to leave Kuwait as Iraq had claimed. ``We now have cars lined up at the Saudi border who are unable to get out,'' said Fitzwater. Earlier in the day, Bush telephoned the president of Venezuela to discuss the crisis and world oil production. Bush plans to return to his oceanfront summer home Wednesday after a military briefing and speech to Pentagon employees, Fitzwater said. Bush arrived in Maine Friday for a scheduled 25-day vacation, but said then that the standoff in the Middle East would probably require him to go ``back and forth'' to the White House. Fitzwater, briefing reporters at a seaside hotel near Bush's Walkers Point home, said Bush will leave for Washington around noontime Tuesday and meet with his top advisers on the budget and efforts to forge a deal with leaders of Congress on reducing the deficit. Bush will hold a news conference to discuss the budget problems after his session with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, budget director Richard Darman and others, Fitzwater said. He will go to the Pentagon Wednesday morning for a full briefing on the military situation in the Gulf, where Bush has sent an estimated 50,000 troops, squadrons of fighter jets and a large flotilla of ships to defend Saudi Arabia and pressure Saddam to withdraw his occupying army from Kuwait. The United States is leading international efforts to enforce United Nations-ordered economic sanctions against Iraq, which has 100,000 or more troops massed in Kuwait. ``We assess the impact of the embargo as excellent,'' Fitzwater said. He said the embargo covers food imports as well. ``The purpose of the embargo is to put the pinch on them'' so the Iraqis cannot ``maintain their war machine,'' Fitzwater said. Pressed on whether the United States would impose a total quarantine on shipping through the Gulf of Aqaba, Fitzwater said he did not want to ``telegraph our intentions.'' But he added, ``I think when the president said yesterday `Everything,' that that was quite inclusive and adequate to give notice as to what our intentions are.'' Later, Fitzwater issued a written statement saying the United States would not try to intercept medical supplies to Iraq. ``We do not intend to go beyond the (U.N.) resolution,'' said Fitzwater, who quoted language from the resolution stating the embargo does not include ``supplies intended strictly for medical purposes.'' Bush called Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez today to discuss the Gulf situation and world oil supplies, Fitzwater said. U.S. officials have said Venezuela, a member of OPEC, is stepping up oil production to help offset the cutoff of Iraqi and Kuwait oil. On the embargo, he said, ``To our knowledge ships are not arriving. The embargo is being maintained. The nations of the world are abiding by their commitments. We have had two or three ships in recent hours that have turned away or been turned away or at least have otherwise have not landed with their cargo. We are very optimistic at this point that the embargo will hold.'' Asked about reports that Jordan was letting shipments through, he said, ``we are hopeful that Jordan will comply. They have said they will abide by the sanctions.'' Asked why the United States would block food shipments, Fitzwater said, ``We have obvious humanitarian concerns but we have also very real military concerns and this is a force that is after all threatening many countries of the world. It is a leader who has killed people by his own hand and by his own forces.'' ``We are very much concerned about the safety about our soldiers and our troops in Saudi Arabia and concerned about the other countries of the region,'' he added. ``The purpose of the sanctions and the embargo is to put the pinch on them. It seems fairly obvious to me you don't let foodstuffs and other things go in that are subject to the sanctions. The purpose is not let supplies go in that allow them to maintain the war machine, allow them to maintain their aggressive takeover of Kuwait. You don't give them the essentials that enable them to carry on the war,'' said Fitzwater. Fitzwater had no estimate of what it is costing to keep the American forces in Saudi Arabia. There have been reports from Pentagon sources that it will cost $300 million or more a month. Fitzwater expressed skepticism about such figures, but said, ``Funding will not drive this operation.'' The White House announced Sunday that after a written plea from Kuwait's exiled emir to enforce United Nations economic sanctions, ``the president has decided that the United States will do whatever is necessary'' to isolate Iraq. Bush was on the telephone before dawn Sunday discussing the international effort to isolate Iraq with Syrian President Hafez Assad, often a target of U.S. criticism but in this case an ally. Fitzwater said ``the United States categorically rejects'' Saddam's proposals for withdrawing from Kuwait. The Iraqi leader demanded an end to the international sanctions that have choked off his oil exports, plus a pullout of American and other forces, and an Israeli surrender of the occupied territories on the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Saddam, who has unleashed chemical weapons in the past, warned that ``many will be burned'' if war erupts in the region. Bush, asked during a golf outing if he was pleased that Saddam at least was talking about negotiating, said crisply, ``I didn't see anything ... pleasing in there at all _ none. Nothing.''

DOC.HEAD: Thief Steals Kitchen Sink
DOC.TEXT: A burglar left everything but the kitchen sink in a break-in in northwestern Mississipi. Police said Monday a stainless-steel, double-basined sink valued at $200 was taken from its moorings on the wall in the weekend burglary at the home of George Brooks. Brooks said the theft left him with ``a sinking feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans, Soviets Discuss Legal Systems
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and his Soviet counterpart, Justice Minister Veniamin Yakovlev, on Monday began a week of discussions on American and Soviet legal systems. The meetings between Justice Department officials and the Soviet delegation headed by Yakovlev are a follow up to discussions Thornburgh had in Moscow last fall. As part of perestroika, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev has expressed an interest in developing a legal system that relies on due process rather than arbitrary decisions of bureaucrats. Soviet officials are seeking advice from American legal experts on a number of issues. Among them is the development of a uniform commercial code, which is seen by Western experts as a necessary prelude to more foreign investment in the Soviet Union. In opening remarks, Yakovlev said the attorney general's visit to Moscow last fall ``opened a totally new page'' in the history of U.S.-Soviet relations. ``It's very important that our jurists and our lawyers work closely together,'' he said. Yakovlev said the Soviet concept of the rule of law ``is not so different'' than American thinking. But he acknowledged that ``our juridical systems differ quite a lot.'' The Soviets are particularly interested to ``understand how legislative actions regulate economic functions,'' Yakovlev said. ``This is very pressing for us.'' Thornburgh's remarks sounded a note of U.S.-Soviet solidarity during the current Mideast crisis. ``In this period of stress in the Mideast, it seems particularly significant that our two countries stand shoulder-to-shoulder in the opposition of the naked aggression and the support of the rule of law through the United Nations and other international bodies, Thornburgh said. The Soviet delegation will meet with the various division heads at the Justice Department. On Tuesday, Yaklovlev and Thornburgh will travel to Lake George, N.Y., to address the Conference of U.S. Chief Justices.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Zoo Readies For Elephant Birth
DOC.TEXT: A happy event is imminent, but even though it's at the zoo no one expects the stork to deliver this bundle of joy _ he or she will weigh about 200 pounds. Bozie, an 5,740-pound Asian elephant, is in her 20th month of pregnancy and delivery isn't long off, say officials at the Lincoln Park Zoo. ``We have a thousand things to prepare for,'' said Mark Rosenthal, the zoo's curator of mammals. ``We want to get a viable, healthy baby on the ground.'' Bozie's little one will be only the 16th of its species born in the United States since 1985, and the first for Chicago and the Lincoln Park Zoo. Only 10 of those calves have survived. Officials surveyed zoos all over the world for information about elephant pregnancies. As Bozie's pregnancy progressed, keepers began taking her measurements and weighing her. They even built a new room for the delivery where Bozie, who has gained 800 pounds during her pregnancy, sleeps away from the zoo's other elephants. A suburban Northbrook horse veterinarian who knows how to perform a Caesarean section on an elephant plans be on hand during the birth in case of complications. ``We're all excited,'' Rosenthal said. ``But we're keeping it calm until we see that we have a successful birth. Then we'll probably get real excited.'' The zoo had to go to a lot of trouble to get Bozie in a family way, since it has no male elephants. Bozie was sent to Dickerson Park Zoo in Springfield, Mo., where she and a male elephant named Onyx hit it off. Bozie was returned to the Lincoln Park Zoo after a one-year stay in Missouri.

DOC.HEAD: ``Miss Saigon'' Furor Draws Derisive British Press Comments
DOC.TEXT: The British press is reacting derisively to the refusal by an American actors' union to let the star of the musical ``Miss Saigon'' repeat his performance on Broadway. Film director Michael Winner, writing in The Sunday Express, decried the ``insane decision'' of Actors' Equity to deny Welsh actor Jonathan Pryce permission to headline the hit musical on Broadway. Pryce won an Olivier Award, London's equivalent of a Tony Award, for playing the Eurasian pimp known as ``The Engineer.'' He has appeared on Broadway twice before, winning a Tony in Trevor Griffiths' ``Comedians'' in 1976. Actors' Equity said last week that since ``The Engineer'' is a Eurasian, an actor of Asian descent should play the role. This prompted producer Cameron Mackintosh to threaten to cancel the Broadway production, which has a record advance sale of almost $25 million. The show, a London sellout since September, was to start New York previews in March at the Broadway Theater. The issue is expected to be reviewed at a meeting of Actors' Equity this week. ``This decision took (protectionism) to new extremes,'' said Winner, who has doubled as an actor. He added: ``My roles in America now seem limited to playing middle-aged Jews.'' Winner, a Briton, is middle-aged and Jewish. Sunday Telegraph columnist Oliver Pritchett wrote sarcastically that the union's logic meant sharing ``the plum parts around all the ethnic communities.'' He envisioned several newly titled musicals, including ``Noh, Noh, Nanette,'' ``Hello Bali,'' and ``The Rocky Harare Show'' to employ Japanese, Javanese and Zimbabwean actors. The Peter Tory column in The Daily Express asked: ``Should the role of the Mikado ... now only be taken by Japanese grandees dwelling within the shadows of Mount Fuji?'' ``The implication of the American ban leads to endless silliness,'' he wrote. The Daily Mail wrote: ``This exclusion illustrates the terrible confusion into which this once great melting-pot of a country has descended over the issue of race.'' Reporting on the casting of American actor Richard Gere as a Japanese-American in a forthcoming film, The Evening Standard headlined the article, ``When equity means double standards.'' Not everyone agreed. Rhoda Koenig, an American columnist in The Independent on Sunday, wrote: ``Could Mackintosh's high-minded political stance have been a clever move to get public opinion on his side before the opening and present himself as the underdog rather than the exploiter?'' ``The greatest irony ... is that Americans are being whipped up to get behind a show that presents a tawdry, simplistic version of their involvement in Vietnam,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Won't Advise U.S. Attorney on Barry Re-Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 8th graf to CORRECT typo, fixing to read `no discussions,' sted `on discussions.' ^By RICHARD KEIL
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said today that the decision whether to retry Mayor Marion Barry on unresolved drug and perjury charges will be up to U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. Stephens ``does not need our permission to retry a case,'' said Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian, when asked if the department would participate in the decision. Stephens hasn't yet said whether he plans to retry the case. The mayor, meanwhile, returned to work today on a fulltime basis for the first time since his trial began in June. Barry was convicted of one misdemeanor count of possession of cocaine on Friday by a jury that acquitted him of another simple drug count but deadlocked on 12 other charges, including three felony perjury counts. After a mistrial was declared, Stephens said he would decide by Sept. 17 whether to retry the unresolved drug possession and perjury charges. Eramian said that Justice Department officials in the criminal division stood ready to give Stephens advice _ if sought _ about how to proceed with the Barry case. But the spokesman said the department will not offer unsolicited views on what to do next. ``That is the U.S. attorney's call,'' Eramian said. So far, ``there have been no discussions with main Justice'' about the case, said Eramian. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh ``has not been involved in the case so far in any way, shape or form,'' he said. Barry also planned to drop his Democratic party affiliation today as he weighs whether to run for city council as an independent, aides said Sunday. Barry, who announced in June he would not seek re-election this fall, believes a run for the city council will let him keep a hand in local political affairs, aides said. On Saturday, the mayor said in a speech, ``Now is the time for healing.'' He asked city residents to ``forgive me for any hurt I may have caused ... I hope that any of you who still harbor resentment and vengeance can let go.'' Barry also said of the trial jury, ``Let their judgment be our last judgment.'' In his speech, the mayor acknowledged he had been ``behaving in ways that were not in keeping with the vows I made to my wife'' and said he had sought and received Effi Barry's forgiveness. Regarding his treatment for alcohol and prescription drug abuse, he said, ``There's no shame or disgrace in being addicted to anything. The shame and disgrace is in not making the decision to seek help.'' Barry has been receiving conflicting advice on whether he should run for city council, said aides who spoke on condition of anonymity. Monday is the deadline for switching parties. If Barry becomes an independent, he would have to gather the signatures of 2,000 registered city voters to be placed on the ballot. He would compete for two city-wide council seats with winners of the Republican, Democrat, and Statehood party primaries. Winning a council seat would allow Barry to maximize his future city pension earnings and let him stay active in local politics, which he has dominated since he was first elected mayor in 1978. He was elected to the city council in 1974. Sources said that while some aides believe Barry has been exonerated and should resume his political career, others are wary of antagonizing Jackson or prosecutors. ``The feeling is, `Don't do anything to draw attention to yourself,''' one associate said. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has not yet set a sentencing date for Barry's misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction, which carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. Stephens has said only that the trial evidence will be reviewed before he decides whether to retry the 12 charges, but politics have been intertwined with the case since Barry's Jan. 18 arrest in the FBI sting. During plea bargain negotiations, the mayor has said, Stephens insisted that Barry would have to resign his office as part of any agreement with the government. Meanwhile, a Washington Post survey published Sunday showed that while most of those interviewed believe the government should abandon its prosecution of the mayor, a similar percentage believed Barry should not seek office this year.

DOC.HEAD: Planes, Equipment, Troops Flowing Into Saudi Desert
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following is based on a pool dispatch written by John King of The Associated Press.
DOC.DATELINE: AN AIR BASE IN SAUDI ARABIA (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Every 10 minutes or so, another plane lands in the Saudi desert with U.S. troops and equipment. ``I think our position grows stronger with each day that goes by,'' said Maj. Gen. Don L. Kaufman, chief of the U.S. military training mission to Saudi Arabia and now acting chief of staff for Central Command Forward _ the command operations for U.S. troops. ``The Saudi government has been extremely cooperative,'' Kaufman told a pool of reporters at a briefing Monday, adding that he thinks the Saudis were surprised by the size of the American commitment. ``They are finding that we are not going to allow a handful of Americans to be in harm's way. The numbers are larger, I think, than the Saudis originally anticipated,'' he said. President Bush ordered about 50,000 American troops to Saudi Arabia last week at the request of the Saudi government following Iraq's lightning seizure of neighboring Kuwait. Pentagon sources have said the number could climb as high as 250,000 in coming months. Kaufman said he was aware of no military incident between the Saudis and Iraqis. ``As far as I know it has been very stable,'' said Kaufman. Reporters in a Pentagon pool arrived in Saudi Arabia on Monday and were allowed to interview U.S. soldiers. Under the pool conditions, the names of the soldiers, details of the military equipment and the name of the air base where the interviews took place could not be disclosed. Dozens of military transport planes, vehicles and equipment had already arrived at the base. U.S. forces and equipment were arriving at several places in the kingdom and moving on to various positions, officials said. A 27-year-old sergeant from Claymont, Del., in a support unit from Fort Bragg, N.C., said he had just arrived on a plane chartered from Federal Express and was told to be ready to stay four to six months. ``I called my wife and told her I might be called on, and if I go, just pray we all get out of here safe,'' said the sergeant, who had a gas mask attached to his belt. ``Yes, it's scary, you have to build up the courage and put the fear aside and do what you have to do.'' At Torrejon Air Force base in Spain, where the press pool stopped for refueling, the tarmac was lined with rows of C-141 and massive C-5 transport planes and a wing of F-16 fighters, some carrying Sidewinder missiles. All apparently were headed for the Persian Gulf region. A huge hangar was filled with cots so the troops can catch a nap. Volunteers from the local church handed out drinks and baked goods. One young soldier, shortly after stepping off a C-5 transport plane, said he had little training for desert or chemical warfare. ``So _ should I think I'm coming back?'' he asked. ``I'm pretty scared.''

DOC.HEAD: AP Newsman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Gardner L. Bridge, 83, an Associated Press newsman in Washington and New York for 40 years, died Monday. Bridge died at Arlington Hospital of an intestinal obstruction, his family said. As a reporter in The Associated Press' New York City bureau, Bridge covered such stories as the final gang wars of the prohibition era, the Lindbergh kidnapping, the S.S. Morro Castle disaster and the investigation of Mayor Jimmy Walker's administration. In Washington, Bridge covered the Senate and was assigned to every national political convention from 1944 to 1968. While riding the Thomas E. Dewey campaign train in 1944, Bridge and several others were injured in a train wreck at Castle Rock, Wash. Dewey was not injured. Bridge was born Nov. 2, 1906, in Stockbridge, N.Y., and grew up in Syracuse, N.Y. He began his career with The Associated Press in 1925 as a Morse code operator. At the same time, he attended classes at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. He took a job as a reporter for the Albany Evening News in 1928 and went on to cover the state legislature for the newspaper. Bridge returned to The Associated Press in New York in 1931 as a reporter and later became city editor and bureau chief. He transferred to Washington in 1942 and retired in 1971. Bridge is survived by two daughters, Vivian Bridge of Reston and Regina Steele of Fairfax; two grandchildren and one great grandson. Funeral arrangements were incomplete Monday.

DOC.BYLINE: Massage Spurs Growth in Cocaine-Exposed Premature Infants, Study Says ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Daily massage can speed up the growth of premature babies who were exposed to cocaine in the womb, a study says. As a result, the babies were able to leave the hospital about four days earlier on average than non-massaged premature infants, researcher Tiffany Field said Monday. Faster-growing babies also become more responsive, which promotes interaction with parents, she said. Other research shows that parental involvement helps a child's development in the first year of life, she said. Fetuses are exposed to cocaine when a pregnant woman uses the drug. Such use raises the risk of premature birth. Field is a professor of pediatrics, psychology and psychiatry at the University of Miami Medical School. She reported preliminary results from the study at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association, and discussed it in a later interview. The meeting concludes Tuesday. The study, still in progress, has so far produced data on 16 infants. They were born about 10 weeks before their due dates, weighing about 2.6 pounds. They had to stay 20 days to 30 days in a neonatal intensive care unit. Normally, such children then require about 20 days in the hospital simply to gain enough weight to be discharged, Field said. The massage program took place during this latter period. Infants were massaged with firmness, Field said. ``They love it when you give them a little pressure,'' she said. The routine included 10 seconds of working over the top of the head and down to the neck, and then 10 seconds going the other way, she said. Also massaged were the neck and shoulders, back, legs and arms. The chest and abdomen were avoided because the infants obviously did not like being touched there, perhaps associating it with painful medical procedures, Field said. After five minutes of massage, the babies' arms and legs were moved about for five minutes, and then came five more minutes of massage. The 15-minute sessions were done three times a day for 10 days. The massaged babies gained 28 percent more weight per day after the treatment than a comparison group of 16 premature infants who had also been exposed to cocaine, but who were not massaged, Field said. The difference appeared around the sixth day of the treatment and continued for at least a few days after it ended, when researchers stopped keeping track, Field said. Nobody knows why massage spurs growth, but perhaps it stimulates release of hormones that aid absorption of food, she said. Prior studies of premature babies have shown simply holding or paying attention to them did not cause them to gain weight, Field said. The massage treatment looks promising, said a prominent pediatric researcher, Dr. T. Berry Brazelton of Cambridge, Mass. But he cautioned that ``it has to be done with sensitivity to the baby's condition and responses.'' The massager must ease up in response to signals from the infant, he said. Massage had already been shown to speed up the growth of premature infants not exposed to cocaine, Field said. In one study, a 10-day course of daily massage spurred weight gain by 47 percent. The massaged infants were able to leave the hospital six days sooner, saving substantial sums of money in health care costs, Field said. About 10 percent of births in the United States are premature, amounting to 350,000 a year, according to the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation. Most premature infants weigh less than 5.5 pounds at birth. About 15 percent to 20 percent of premature infants die in the first month after birth.

DOC.HEAD: 29th Anniversary of Berlin Wall Marked in Joint German Ceremony
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Flowers were laid beside a cross honoring a teen-ager who was slain trying to escape to freedom as Germans from East and West on Monday marked the 29th anniversary of the Berlin Wall. The ceremony, the first joint memorial of the Aug. 13, 1961, construction of the Berlin Wall, included a prediction by a local politician that the scar left by the crumbling barrier will never end. East German Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann demanded criminal probes of those responsible for the shoot-to-kill orders at the wall under the former Communist regime. Eppelmann said the now-ousted Communist officials must be brought to justice ``in a fair way.'' Communist border soldiers killed 80 East Germans making dashes for freedom at the wall, while hundreds of others were caught and imprisoned for trying. Germans are engaged in an emotional debate over whether the soldiers themselves should be brought to trial. ``The open wound is closing,'' said prominent West Berlin city councilor Erich Paetzold at the ceremony. ``But a scar will last forever.'' He spoke beside a rough-hewn cross erected in memory of 18-year-old East Berlin worker Peter Fechter, who was shot and bled to death while trying to escape in 1962. His death has come to symbolize the bitter separation that followed the collapse of Nazi Germany after World War II. East Germany's Communists suddenly started erecting the wall, stunning the world 29 years ago, to halt the flow of refugees to the West. Paetzold said a part of the wall will be preserved ``so that we don't forget what happened here, so that no one forgets what happened here.'' Despite Paetzold's promise, it may be difficult to find a suitable memorial site. Many of the most famous stretches of the wall have been torn down since last fall's reforms swept East Germany and other countries in Eastern Europe. Other sections have been hacked away by entrepreneurs and souvenir-hunters. East German and West German newspapers were filled with recollections of the wall Monday. They included a picture of the wall's mastermind, Erich Honecker, shown talking to East German troops the month after the wall was built. Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years before his ouster last October. Honecker, 77, is under investigation for possible murder charges stemming from the deaths of those who tried to flee to the West. On Nov. 9, Honecker's desperate successors opened the wall in hopes of halting another exodus that already numbered 200,000. East Berlin's democratically elected mayor, Tino Schwierzina, reminded the 300 listeners at Monday's ceremony that the Berlin Wall caused widespread suffering. ``The situation in the German Democratic Republic makes this increasingly clear,'' Schwierzina said. ``We who are living behind the almost disappeared wall need quick and effective help.'' Schwierzina said the nation's economy was in ``catastrophic'' condition. East German demands for money from Bonn have led to tensions between the two countries as they head into the last stretch before unification, scheduled for December at latest. The representatives of the two halves of Berlin spoke at a cross set up in honor of Fechter after his Aug. 17, 1962 death. Fechter bled for nearly an hour before his body was hauled away. ``Here where Peter Fechter died, we can feel how much suffering the wall caused,'' said the East Berlin mayor. A weathered photograph of the young man lying in agony is tacked to the cross' dark wood. More than a dozen large flower arrangements were placed by the cross. Although the wall has disappeared there, windows on the Eastern side still have the bars that kept people from jumping to freedom from nearby buildings. In years past, the Communist East Germans marked the wall's anniversary with bombastic military parades that drew the wrath of the Western Allies. More than 2.5 million East Germans fled to the West from 1949 until the wall went up. Communist border soldiers killed more than 200 people attempting to flee from East Berlin or other parts of East Germany to the West.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Race, Stadium Issues Head Colorado Primary
DOC.TEXT: A sales tax increase to build a Denver baseball stadium steps up to the plate Tuesday in Colorado's primary election. Voters will also chose between Josie Heath and Carlos Lucero for the Democratic nomination for U.S. Senate. Republican state Sens. Wayne Allard and Jim Brandon are vying for the 4th Congressional District seat. Democrat Gov. Roy Romer faces no opposition in the primary. His GOP opponent, John Andrews, also is unopposed. Secretary of State Natalie Meyer projected a turnout of about 35 percent of the state's 1.8 million eligible voters. Voters in six Denver metropolitan-area counties will decide whether a sales tax of 0.1 percent should be levied to raise $139 million over 12 years to build a baseball stadium. Denver is bidding for one of two baseball franchises to be awarded this year by the National League. Baseball proponents hope approval of the stadium tax question will lure a major-league team. Weekend polls showed voters about evenly split on the issue. Opponents have said the tax would amount to a public subsidy of private business, and they have noted that no potential owners of a Denver major-league franchise have yet stepped forward. Heath, 52, a former Boulder County commissioner, led Lucero in polls published over the weekend that showed her lead ranging from 59-21 percent to 41-32 percent. Lucero, 49, a lawyer, had made an aggressive assault on the savings and loan scandal the centerpiece for his campaign in recent weeks, hoping to overcome a 2-to-1 Heath lead in June. The winner will meet U.S. Rep. Hank Brown, R-Colo., who is vacating his 4th District seat after 10 years to run for the Senate. Sen. Bill Armstrong, R-Colo., is stepping down. Most polls show Brown would easily beat either Heath or Lucero in the Nov. 6 general election. Allard and Brandon are vying for the right to succeed Brown in the 4th District. The winner faces the Democratic nominee, state Rep. Richard Bond of Greeley, who is unopposed Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Aides Say U.S. Commander `Saw It Coming'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Late last month, 350 officers at U.S. Central Command Headquarters in Florida held a training exercise _ a hypothetical crisis requiring American military action in the Middle East. According to a spokesman, the drill code-named ``Internal Look `90'' was devised by Central Command's chief, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf III, to ``test our ability to deal with a contingency in which a threat overflowed its banks and challenged the interests of the United States.'' Five days later, Iraqi president Saddam Hussein's armed forces rumbled into neighboring Kuwait, and people around the Tampa headquarters were asking whether ``the bear,'' as Schwarzkopf is called, had known something they didn't. ``It's almost exactly the scenario of IL `90,'' said Capt. Ronald Wildermuth, chief spokesman for the 56-year-old Schwarzkopf. Schwarzkopf took over in 1988 as commander of U.S. military affairs in the explosive region stretching from North Africa to Pakistan. Schwarzkopf, a West Pointer with four stars, a master's degree in guided missile technology and the build of a pro football tackle, is no stranger to crisis. He was second-in-command of U.S. forces in the Grenada invasion in 1983. A decade earlier, he led an infantry battalion during the bloodiest phase of U.S. involvement in Vietnam. Schwarzkopf himself was wounded twice and won three Silver Stars for valor and a host of other medals. But he was probably best known for his personal involvement with the family of a soldier killed by errant American artillery _ an episode described in the book and film ``Friendly Fire.'' While none of that has made H. Norman Schwarzkopf III a household name, the name was already famous in the early 1930s, when Col. H. Norman Schwarzkopf led the controversial investigation of the Lindbergh baby kidnapping. The elder Schwarzkopf subsequently turned up as a U.S. Army colonel in Iran, where he organized a national police force that helped thwart a Soviet-backed communist insurgency at the end of World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Calls For Energy Savings, Cites Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Trade Ministry asked Japanese on Monday to work in sweltering offices and use mass transit to prepare for a possible oil crisis because of the Persian Gulf situation. About 70 percent of Japan's oil comes from the Middle East. Trade officials are proposing wide-ranging measures for government agencies, private companies and individual households to conserve energy. The proposals, expected to be approved by the Cabinet on Tuesday and take effect immediately, include setting office building thermostats no lower than 82 degrees and reducing office lighting by one-third. ``The situation is not yet so serious because Japan has a very large petroleum reserve,'' said a trade official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But we ought to be better prepared for the possible worst-case scenario.'' Individual citizens will be encouraged to use public transportation. People who continue to drive will be asked to go no faster than 50 mph on highways. Although the proposal does not call for penalties to be imposed for failing to comply with the measures, government guidelines generally are widely followed. The trade official said the ministry also decided on stricter measures to be implemented if the country's oil reserves, now estimated at enough for 142 days, deteriorate. Those steps would include limiting both gas station operations and late-night television broadcasting, officials said. ``We are trying to be cautious not to repeat the panic of the second oil crisis in 1978,'' the official said, referring to the oil crunch caused by the outbreak of the war between Iran and Iraq. ``The confusion occurred because we were not too well-prepared back then.''

DOC.HEAD: It's 37 States in 90 Days for India Bikers
DOC.TEXT: An adventure-loving traveler from India thinks the United States is a fascinating place, and can't understand why Americans themselves don't see more of it. Satish Ganapathy and two coworkers from India plan to ride 90,000 miles through 37 states in 90 days on two old, Indian-made motorcycles. ``We cannot see any place else like this on Earth,'' Ganapathy said. ``This is a fun-filled country. There are so many things to see. ``We have heard that many people in the United States have not seen their own country, which is very saddening. We've seen every nook and cranny of India. Here, people do not know their own country. ``If I lived in Harrisburg I would have seen the rest of the United States before I was 35.'' The chance that their two motorcycles could break down adds to the thrill. ``We believe in adventure,'' Ganapathy, 40, told The Patriot-News in Harrisburg while visiting last week. ``We may find that we may fail physically, or the motorcycles may fail. We do not know.'' Ganapathy, Stanley Rose, 28, and Arun Khadse, 32, workers at an Indian power plant, set out from New York City on July 28. They'll cross the hot Texas flatlands and challenge California's jammed freeways. They'll visit Yellowstone National Park, the Grand Canyon, the nation's Capitol and Disneyland. The trip, which their employer helped sponsor, already has thrilled them. They've toured Independence Hall and marveled at the size of the enormous chocolate factory in nearby Hersey. And the chandeliers in Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, N.J., were magnificent, even though the building hardly looks like its wondrous namesake in India, they said. ``You could spend 10 days in that casino,'' Ganapathy said. The best thing has been the way strangers have treated them, they said. While staying two days at the home of a friend's cousin in Lower Paxton Township, the three men went for a walk and an American couple said ``Hello.'' That rarely happens in their home town of Bombay. ``Even if they don't know you they say `Hello' to you,'' Rose said. ``Back home, if I don't know you I don't say anything to you. People are very warm here.''

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Claims 450 Killed in Lhasa in March 1989
DOC.TEXT: A former Chinese functionary claims that security forces killed more than 450 Tibetans in the capital of Lhasa in 1989, the Observer newspaper reported. The Chinese government has reported that about a dozen people were killed on March 5 and March 6 of last year, the newspaper said in its Sunday edition. The Observer's report was based on films an documents supplied by Tang Daxian, a former Chinese journalist now living in Paris. It said Tang had a copy of a report from the Public Security Bureau and the Tibet Military District Command dated March 11, which said that by then, ``387 Lhasa citizens have been killed ... the majority by bullets ... 721 were injured, 2,100 have been arrested or detained ... 354 have disappeared ... 82 religious people have been killed, 37 injured, 650 arrested or detained.'' Tang, 36, was in Tibet representing the Chinese Journalists' Association, the State Council, the United Front Department and other government offices, the newspaper said. Tang said he left Beijing in May 1989 after being warned that he might be arrested for furnishing high-level information about government deliberations to demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. The Observer said Tang's father, Tang Hai, once headed the Tibet section of the United Front Department, which supervises non-Communist organizations. Tang said Chinese authorities were alarmed when a Tibetan flag was flown above the Jokhang temple in Lhasa on Feb. 7, 1989, and the crackdown culminated in the bloodshed of early March. Tang said police in Lhasa received these orders from their commander in Beijing, Gen. Li Lianxiu: ``The special task force should immediately produce 300 people dressed as ordinary citizens and monks. They are to cooperate with the plain-clothes police to complete the task of creating a provocative atmosphere along the Barkhor (central market) on the morning of 5 March. Their tasks are: to burn down the Darshing prayer pole on the northeast of the Jokhang temple; to destroy and ransack the granary in Chenguan district, provoking citizens to steal the grain, and provoking people to rob the Tibet-Gansu Commerce Corporation of its goods.'' On March 5, Tang said, police dressed as civilians set the Darshing prayer pole on fire, and police shot and killed eight people among an outraged crowd that gathered. Tang said police operations were suspended in the afternoon because of foreign witnesses. On March 6, Tang said, most foreigners in Lhasa had been isolated in a hotel. He said police made an advance, but retreated under a barrage of stones. He said Tibetans charged after them with sticks and bricks, straight into an ambush set up by police firing automatic weapons from rooftops. Tang claimed that 300 people were killed in the first 10 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Nations Well-Armed With U.S. Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The Mideast is bristling with billions of dollars worth of modern weapons, much of the arsenal provided by the United States. That includes Kuwaiti missiles now in the hands of Iraq. Many of the arms transfers to the Mideast have been financed by low-interest, long-term U.S. loans. Israel, at nearly $1.9 billion this year, and Egypt, at almost $1.3 billion, are the world's biggest recipients of such aid. Other nations, such as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, pay cash for U.S. weapons. Both the aid program and the cash sales are aimed at supporting friendly governments in the region and assuring the free flow of oil. That overriding interest caused President Bush to dispatch U.S. military forces to the Persian Gulf last week to shield oil-rich Saudi Arabia from the threat of an attack by Iraq, which overran Kuwait Aug. 2. Pentagon officials say that while the United States sold arms to Kuwait only infrequently, its arsenals included some U.S. Hawk anti-aircraft missiles and several thousand U.S. Tow anti-tank missiles. All are now believed to be in Iraqi hands. Most of Kuwait's fighter aircraft, including two squadrons of French-built Mirage F-1s and several dozen American Skyhawk warplanes, are believed to have been flown to safety in Saudi Arabia. Before it was attacked, Kuwait had arranged a $1.8 billion purchase of U.S. FA-18 fighter aircraft plus anti-ship and anti-aircraft missiles. But the aircraft were not scheduled for delivery until 1992 and a Pentagon official, who asked not to be named, said that if Kuwait remains in Iraq's control the United States has no obligation to deliver them. Over the last 20 years, just $1.5 billion in U.S. weaponry was transferred to Kuwait, a small fraction of the arms sent to other Mideastern nations. Saudi Arabia has been the biggest customer for U.S. arms, with $23 billion in deliveries over that period. Israel has received $11 billion in weapons; Egypt, $6 billion. Washington has sold Saudi Arabia much of its modern weaponry and is helping that nation modernize its military capability. Shortly after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the United States acted to dismantle congressional obstacles to arms deliveries to Saudi Arabia. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney waived a legislative restriction limiting to 60 the number of sophisticated F-15 warplanes Saudi Arabia is allowed to have. The Pentagon official said the Saudis will now be allowed to have 70 F-15s. The Saudis previously made a $3 billion purchase of U.S. TOW anti-tank missiles, which are now being produced, the official said. Last year, the Saudis bought 320 M1A2 tanks, which have yet to be built, for $3 billion. Major Saudi arms deals this year include more than $1 billion for the modernization of the oil-rich kingdom's national guard and another $1 billion to modernize the Saudi fleet of AWACS early-warning aircraft. In Israel, the United States is trying to improve that nation's defensive capability through a naval modernization program, which includes the construction of submarines, the Pentagon official said. Israel is also developing and recently tested the Arrow defense missile, which is designed to destroy incoming missiles. Eighty percent of the cost of the program is being borne by the United States. Egypt has become a major recipient of U.S. military aid since it became the first Arab nation to recognize Israel in 1979. Egypt is now buying Harpoon anti-ship missiles. More modest U.S. aid, mostly in the form of military training and basic gear, is provided to Jordan _ $47.8 million this fiscal year _ and to other countries in the Middle East. For the next fiscal year, the Bush administration has asked Congress for permission to make $4.3 million in arms-sales loans for U.S. allies in the Mideast.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lifts Limit on Soviet Business People
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in a bid to bolster U.S.-Soviet trade, on Monday lifted a long-standing ceiling on the number of Soviet business people permitted to live and work in the United States. Until now, only 69 Soviets were allowed to reside in America while pursuing business deals. Now there will be no limit. Bush called upon Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to match his move with ``reciprocal improvements in the climate for American business in the U.S.S.R.'' He also cautioned the Soviets against trying to slip in spies on the pretext of doing business. ``This action is taken as an expression of our policy to build a more normal economic relationship with the Soviets,'' Bush said in a statement issued from his vacation home here. It is ``consistent with our interest in expanding business contacts and trade with the U.S.S.R.,'' he said. ``We have made clear to the Soviets that we retain the right to reconsider our decision should there be evidence that this opportunity is being misused for intelligence gathering or other inappropriate activities,'' the president said. Bush proposed closer economic ties with the Soviets at the Malta summit last December, and he and Gorbachev signed a trade agreement in Washington in June during their second summit. Bush noted that the United States is eager to provide the Soviets with expertise on how to make lasting market-oriented reforms in their ailing economy. ``Our business people in the U.S.S.R. and Soviet business people here play an important role in this process. The time has come to eliminate obstacles to commercial presence in both of our countries and to allow the number of resident business people to grow in tandem with the expansion of our economic relations,'' Bush said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-NYC Power Outage, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0584,0497
DOC.HEAD: Power Outage Socks Lower Manhattan, Disrupting Some Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with some stock exchanges halting trading for the day; to add details on injuries, color, evacuations at World Trade Center, hospital losing power; report of PCB contamination unfounded. A version slugged PM-Power Outage moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: A fire knocked out power to hundreds of offices in the city's financial district today, disrupting stock market trading and stranding hundreds of people in skyscraper elevators, authorities said. Consolidated Edison officials issued an urgent appeal for other customers to reduce electrical usage because of the danger other parts of the system would become overloaded. Temperatures in the city were in the middle 80s. Eight firefighters were taken to area hospitals suffering from smoke inhalation, chest pains and burning sensation in their throats, officials said. The New York Stock Exchange remained unaffected by the outage, spokesman Ray Pellechia said. But officials at the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and Commodity Exchange said they had to halt trading for the day. The fire at Con Ed's Seaport substation was reported shortly before noon, said Fire Department spokeswoman Marilyn Bernard. Hundreds of people were stuck in elevators at the World Trade Center for up to 2{ hours, said D. Joy Faber, a spokeswoman for the operator of the twin 107-story skyscrapers. By 2:40 p.m., people were evacuated from all but one elevator. The complex was operating on emergency power. ``My legs are buckling. I feel so sore,'' secretary Ethel Levine said after walking down 33 floors. More than 100 firefighters, including a decontamination and hazardous materials unit, were on the scene. ``It's very, very heavy smoke conditions,'' Bernard said, with ``power losses all around.'' Earlier reports of possible PCB contamination were unfounded. A spokeswoman for the city environmental department said records show there were no PCB's used at the electrical substation where the fire occurred. Con Ed spokesman Dan Walden said some high voltage cables were knocked out by the fire. Initially only 500 customers were affected but two other feeder cables became overloaded and were also knocked out, causing the blackout to spread, he said. A Con Ed customer can be an entire building, so the number of people affected is many times higher than the number of customers. The blackout area includes Wall Street and several large office skyscrapers. Beekman Downtown Hospital was operating on emergency generator power, said spokeswoman Maureen Flatley. She said lights are being shut off to conserve power and the air conditioning was shut off. Concern that continued electrical usage by others would overload more cables and spread the blackout prompted an emergency plea for cutbacks. The cause of the fire was not immediately known. Some subway trains were either being halted north of the blackout area or rerouted to other lines, the Transit Authority said.

DOC.HEAD: Half In U.S. Fear Gas Crisis as a Result of Middle East Conflict
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Half the American public fears the Iraqi conflict will create an oil crisis in the United States, with rising prices and long lines at the service station, an Associated Press poll has found. Respondents to the national survey overwhelmingly blamed the recent surge in gasoline prices on oil company greed, not the Middle East tensions. But many foresaw true shortages and still higher prices in the next few months. Despite those fears, and despite widespread expectations of a U.S.-Iraq war, the poll found strong support for the use of U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia against possible Iraqi attack. Sixty-four percent voiced approval. The survey of 1,004 adults was conducted Wednesday through Sunday, after President Bush's announcement he was sending troops and Iraq's announcement it was annexing Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. Several polls since Bush's speech have found Americans rallying to his side. Support for the use of U.S. troops has ranged from 63 percent in a poll conducted Tuesday and Wednesday to 81 percent in a one-day poll Wednesday night. Support for Bush personally is roughly as high. Seventy-seven percent in a poll Friday to Sunday by ICR Survey Research Group generally approved of the way he has been handling the situation. And two-thirds said his reaction has been ``about right,'' rather than too tough or too weak. Concerns underlie the support, however. In the AP poll, also conducted by ICR, 33 percent said the United States is ``very likely'' to become involved in a war with Iraq. An additional 39 percent called war ``somewhat likely.'' Approval of the U.S. troop commitment varied among some groups in the population. Republicans were more supportive than were Democrats and independents _ 74 percent, compared with 61 and 63 percent, respectively. College-educated Americans also were more supportive of the use of U.S. troops. And most strikingly, women were far less supportive than men of the troop commitment, 51 percent to 79 percent. Beyond his aid to Saudi Arabia, Bush has said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``will not stand.'' But poll respondents were less clear on that outcome: Just one-third expected an international economic embargo of Iraq to succeed in forcing it out of Kuwait. And many did not favor a military alternative. Thirty-five percent backed the use of U.S. troops to try to push Iraq out of Kuwait, and even fewer _ 27 percent _ favored bombing Iraqi military targets to force it from Kuwait. On oil, 86 percent said oil companies were taking advantage of the situation when they raised gasoline after Iraq attacked Kuwait; just 6 percent called the increases legitimate, with the rest unsure. But 52 percent said they believe the situation in the Middle East is likely to create real oil shortages in the next few months, with rising prices and long lines at the service stations. The AP poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. ICR, of Media, Pa., is part of AUS Consultant Cos.

DOC.HEAD: Salvage Crews Stop Leak, Sop up Mess of Latest Oil Spill
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Salvage crews sucked up oil from the Houston Ship Channel on Monday after the third large oil spill in as many months in or near the busy shipping channel. The Coast Guard said at least 21,000 gallons of oil spilled Sunday when a barge buckled at a dock owned by Lyondell Petrochemical, a former Arco Petrochemical subsidiary that was spun off as an independent company. The barge was being loaded with fuel oil. Coast Guard Cmdr. Rex Prosser said crews contained the spill within a few hours and by Monday morning had transferred the barge's remaining 609,000 gallons of oil to another barge. The salvage crews ran into difficulties Monday. ``The major problem is that the oil is sitting on the bottom of the water,'' said Prosser, chief of Houston port operations. ``We're trying to bring in some underwater dredges to remove the oil from the bottom of the turning basin.'' Lyondell spokesman David Harpole said salvage crews used high-pressure water sprays to help with the cleanup. ``Water is being sprayed into the channel to generate some turbulence to push the oil into the shore where the vacuum trucks and skimmers can get to it,'' Harpole said. Coast Guard officials said the spill area was surrounded by refineries and other industrial plants, so concern about the environment is minimal. The 295-foot barge owned by Ingram Barge Co. of Nashville buckled at midship, creasing the center of the vessel and spilling oil from both sides. Crews put temporary patches over a 2-foot fracture on the barge's starboard side and a 3-inch split on its port side. Prosser blamed human error for the spill. ``They were loading the barge and the tankermen put too much weight _ it was a very heavy cargo _ in the two center tanks, and it caused the barge to buckle,'' Prosser said. On Friday, the Coast Guard completed a nearly two-week cleanup of a 700,000-gallon oil spill that happened July 28 when a Greek tanker collided with two barges under tow in the ship channel. On June 8, the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg spilled 3.9 million gallons of Angolan crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico off Galveston when an explosion ripped the vessel, killing four members of the crew and injuring 17 others.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Second Swiss Hostage Released to Syrian Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with release confirmed, Erriquez heading for Syria, edits to conform and delete dated material. Picks up 6th, `The first...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers in south Lebanon today freed Swiss hostage Elio Erriquez after 10 months' incarceration and handed him over to Syrian officials, Red Cross officials said. Erriquez was to be taken tonight to Damascus by the Syrians so he can be turned over to the Swiss Embassy and returned home, Red Cross officials here said. He was the second Swiss hostage released since last week. Earlier today, the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said it released Erriquez, a 24-year-old orthopedic expert, but gave no details, causing confusion in the Mideast and at home. Red Cross chief delegate Artur Bisig said he had been awaiting confirmation of the reported release. And in Geneva, neither the Swiss Foreign Ministry nor the International Committee of the Red Cross had been able to confirm the release. But with the latest release, 14 Westerners remain hostage in Lebanon, including six Americans. The first Swiss captive, Emanuel Christen, 33, was released by the same group Wednesday. Both hostages were working with a Red Cross clinic near Sidon when they were kidnapped. The group's announcement today was delivered to a Western news agency along with a photograph of Erriquez, showing him clean-shaven and wearing a white T-shirt. The group said the Swiss hostages were freed in response to efforts by Syrian president Hafez Assad, Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid, and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. The statement also paid ``particular tribute to Mustafa Saad for efficient role to ensure a success'' of the latest release. Saad heads a leftist Sunni Moslem militia that has governed Sidon since the outbreak of Lebanon's civil war in 1975. Saad had told reporters Saturday Erriquez would be freed soon. Erriquez and Christen were kidnapped Oct. 6 by masked gunmen near a Red Cross center for artificial limbs in Sidon, the provincial capital of South Lebanon, 40 miles south of Beirut. On Wednesday Christen was handed to the command of Syrian peacekeeping troops in Lebanon. He was then taken to the Swiss Embassy in the Syrian capital of Damascus and flew home the next day. Police had blamed the abductions on Fatah-Revolutionary Council, a radical guerrilla group led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The group disclaimed any involvement in the affair. The Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said in today's statement it has no connection to Abu Nidal's group or any other Palestinian guerrilla faction. In addition to six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian are believed held in Lebanon. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East Correspondent for The Associated Press. Anderson was kidnapped March 16, 1985. On Sunday, a senior Shiite Moslem leader in Beirut appealed for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to release 15 Shiite Moslems imprisoned for the bombings of the U.S. and French Embassies in Kuwait. The release of the imprisoned men has long been a key demand by Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, a Shiite group that holds American hostages Anderson and educator Thomas Sutherland. ``The 15 reportedly have been moved to Baghdad and they should be freed,'' said Hussein Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, an umbrella for several hostage-holding factions.

DOC.HEAD: Britain and Australia to Assist in Multinational Force Against Iraq
LaserPhotos LON4,SYD1
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Australia joined the U.S. effort to cut off all shipping from Iraq on Monday, while Pakistan pledged to send troops to protect Saudi Arabia from invasion by Iraq. The Netherlands announced its ships would sail to the Persian Gulf to enforce economic sanctions but would not say if this included participation in U.S. efforts to interdict Iraqi shipping. France and Belgium, which both sent ships to the region, also remained noncommittal on whether they would take part in the U.S.-led force. A well-informed French source said any attempt by French warships to stop Iraqi oil shipments would make it a ``co-belligerant'' in the region. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said no decision had been made. The aircraft carrier Clemenceau, guided-missile cruiser Colbert and supply ship Var on Monday were headed for the Suez Canal, French defense sources said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has said American forces in the gulf would intercept Iraqi oil to enforce a U.N. embargo imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. President Bush said Sunday he would use any means necessary to enforce the embargo. In London, Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said British sailors would board any vessel attempting to break the embargo. ``If there is evidence of sanctions-busting, the navy will take the necessary steps,'' he told a news conference. The Foreign Office said it was responding to Kuwaiti requests for help by ensuring the effectiveness of the U.N.-authorized sanctions. Three British minesweepers left Scotland on Monday for the eastern Mediterranean, and C-130 Hercules transport planes were flying to Saudi Arabia and Oman, using a Royal Air Force base in Cyprus as a staging post. Twenty-four strike aircraft and 1,000 British servicemen are also being sent to the region under ``Operation Granby,'' the largest military deployment since Britain's war with Argentina in the Falklands. Frantic work was under way to prepare the aircraft for combat in desert conditions, defense ministry sources said. The Dutch government announced Monday that it would dispatch two frigates to the gulf around Aug. 20, but it did not immediately say whether the warships would participate in the multinational cutoff of Iraqi shipping. Belgium was sending two minesweepers and a support vessel to the Mediterranean. The Belgian Cabinet said it had not decided whether to integrate the Belgian contingent into the U.S.-led multinational force. Australia's Foreign Affairs Department spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said his country was behind the U.S. effort. ``We are part of a force to enforce the United Nations Security Council sanctions on Iraq,'' he said. The spokesman said it will take the Australian vessels three weeks to reach the gulf. Pakistani leaders agreed Monday to send an undisclosed number of troops to Saudi Arabia after a series of high-level meetings with the Saudi deputy foreign minister. The Foreign Ministry in Islamabad said up to 150,000 Pakistanis are believed to be in Iraq and Kuwait, most of them oil workers. Iraq's ambassador, Ismail Hamoodi Hussein, told Pakistan's state-run news agency Monday that Pakistanis in Iraq ``have no wish to leave, but they are free to leave whenever they want.'' Between 1983 and 1987, Pakistan stationed 5,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia under an agreement between the two nations, a defense ministry spokesman said. The agreement expired in 1987. Pakistani soldiers would join 3,000 Egyptian troops already in Saudi Arabia. The Egyptians are the vanguard of a 10,000-strong Arab League force to include Syria and Morocco. Up to 50,000 U.S. soldiers are expected to arrive in Saudi Arabia in the coming weeks and U.S. officials have said up to 250,000 troops could be sent. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. military effort in the Middle East, said American forces are outnumbered by the Iraqi occupation force, estimated at between 130,000 and 170,000 men. The U.S.-led multinational force and the Arab League force were expected to coordinate their operations under the Saudi military.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Considers Case Against British Rock Band, CBS Records
DOC.TEXT: It's now up to the judge to decide whether subliminal messages exist on an album by the British heavy metal band Judas Priest and, if so, whether such messages drove two fans to enter a suicide pact. Lawyers for the band and CBS Records deny the claim in the case before Washoe County District Court Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead. ``There were unique circumstances there for Raymond Belknap and James Vance which did not include subliminal stimuli,'' defense attorney Suellen Fulstone argued. ``Hundreds of thousands of people have listened to this album with no adverse effect.'' The youths reportedly made a suicide pact two days before Christmas 1985 after drinking beer, smoking marijuana and listening to the 1978 album ``Stained Class'' repeatedly. Belknap, 18, held a sawed-off shotgun in his mouth and died from a single blast Dec. 25, 1985. Vance, then 20, sought to do the same, but only blew away the lower part of his face. Horribly disfigured, he fathered a child and lived for three years before dying on Thanksgiving Day 1988, of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medications. The lawsuit claims subliminal phrases on the album _ particularly ``do it'' _ tout suicide and pushed the youths over the edge. Subliminal messages _ defined as being below the threshold of consciousness and apprehension _ supposedly take effect subconsciously by repetition. Band members and defense lawyers maintain the purported ``do its'' are a combination of a huff of breath by lead singer Rob Halford and the sounds of drums and guitars. ``All the court has to do is listen,'' Ms. Fulstone said. ``There are no `do its' on this album.'' The judge, who heard the case without a jury, gave no indication of when he might rule in the case, but some believe it may be as early as this week. The defense argued during the four-week trial that alcohol and drug abuse, family violence and trouble with the law predestined the youths' fate. Ken McKenna and Vivian Lynch, representing the youths' families, asked the judge for upwards of $6.2 million in damages for pain and suffering. Ms. Lynch, representing the Vance family, sought between $4 million and $5 million, in part to compensate the family for nearly $500,000 in medical bills. McKenna asked for $1.2 million on behalf of Belknap's family.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Say They Worry About Iraqi SAMs, Not Aircraft
LaserPhotos NY20, NY22, NY23, LON9, LON11, LON103
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD USS INDEPENDENCE IN THE GULF OF OMAN (AP)
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy pilots honing their skills for a possible clash with Iraq say their biggest worry is not Baghdad's combat-seasoned air force, but its array of Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles. Since this 80,000-ton carrier with about 70 warplanes arrived off the Arabian Peninsula on Aug. 5 as part of the massive buildup of foreign forces in the region, some of its pilots have been flying nightly ``CAP'' or combat-air-patrol missions over the Persian Gulf. Their job is to help screen the nine U.S. warships in the gulf, and several thousand American ground troops sent to man positions around airfields and several key sites along the coast of Saudi Arabia. In interviews with reporters who visited the Independence as members of a Pentagon news media pool, the pilots said they have yet to encounter any Iraqi aircraft and are never closer than 200 miles to Iraq. That leaves them well out of range of Iraq's formidable arsenal of anti-aircraft guns and missiles. Standard military references say Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's forces have more than 300 surface-to-air missile launchers of at least eight different types. Most are Soviet-designed. Some date back to the 1960s when North Vietnam shot down scores of American raiders with missiles like the radar-guided SAM-6, which has an 11-mile ceiling. Iraq also has the SAM-9, SAM-13 and SAM-14, all of them medium or short range _ two miles to six miles. They are designed to pursue the infrared ``signature'' of a speeding jet. Iraq also has the ROLAND, a French-designed SAM. Some of the missiles were used in the war with Iran, but with limited effect as Tehran's force of U.S.-built warplanes was depleted by age and a shortage of spare parts. In the interviews, Independence combat pilots said they respected their Iraqi counterparts for their war experience, but doubted they would challenge the superior American aircraft and training. ``I have a hard time thinking they'd want to do that. They have a lot of experience and not many of us have been in combat, but we're not Iran either,'' said one pilot of an F-18 Hornet fighter-bomber. Said another 29-year-old Hornet pilot, ``I do feel that our biggest threat to losing aircraft to the Iraqis is from their SAM platforms, as opposed to their air-to-air (fighters),'' he said. A senior commander, who like the others could not be identified by name under the terms of the interviews, said there were relatively few ``dog-fight'' encounters in the gulf war and those that did occur were probably ``chance encounters where neither guy got more than one shot.'' He said the speed and armament of the F-14 Tomcats flying the patrol missions gave them a clear edge over Iraq's French-built F-1 Mirage fighters. Although some sailors grumbled about the tension of waiting for something to happen, the carrier's crew of some 5,000 seemed generally in high spirits. Capt. Robert L. Ellis Jr., commander of the Independence said his crew, most of whom are 18 to 22 years old, ``weren't thinking about combat,'' when they embarked on their current tour of duty at San Diego on June 23. ``But now they have a sense of pride that their country has responded and they are the ones on the front line,'' Ellis said. In addition to the fighters on patrol missions, other aircraft thunder constantly off the carrier's steam catapults on aerial refueling sorties and night landing practices. Small groups of pilots observe and evaluate their colleages as the gray jets roar in at maximum power against the wind to catch a tail-hook on one of the four arresting tables stretched across the deck. Most make it the first time, but occassionally one overshoots the cables and screams off again, hook scrapping the bare deck in a great shower of sparks.

DOC.HEAD: Postmaster Defends Nursing Home Mail Policy
DOC.TEXT: Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank, responding to complaints from senior citizen advocates, defended his agency's policy of refusing to automatically forward nursing home residents' mail when they move. But Frank said in a letter to Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., released Monday that he was disturbed by reports that well-traveled nursing home residents' mail was being left behind. ``I understand you are aware of places where improper mail forwarding has caused a hardship for nursing home residents. I am very concerned with such reports and can assure you the Postal Service is committed to resolving any problems which may exist,'' Frank said. The Postal Service and the Senate Special Committee on Aging have agreed to collaborate on a campaign to ensure that nursing homes are re-addressing the mail of residents who have left, the committee said. Also, Frank said the agency has formed an internal committee to determine if policy changes are needed. Because all residents of a nursing home are at the same address, the Postal Service says the home should be the agent for their mail. The mail is delivered in bulk _ like at prisons, hotels and summer camps _ and distributed by the institution. While other people may submit change-of-address cards to local post offices, nursing home residents must rely on the institution to write their new address on individual letters. Then, the post office delivers it at no extra charge. Heinz, the Aging Committee's ranking Republican, questioned the policy in a March letter to Frank, and a Florida elderly-rights advocate told Congress that some mail was not being forwarded and the policy ``treats nursing home residents like they were in jail or something.'' But Frank defended the policy as ``cost-effective and practical.'' ``Single point delivery permits management of the nursing home, with specific knowledge of each residents' needs and condition, to properly handle their mail and complete delivery at the best time and in the most appropriate manner,'' Frank said. Allowing residents to file address forwarding cards would mean postal employees sorting mail would need a record of each person in the home, Frank said. He said that is not practical because of high resident turnover. Also, some incapacitated residents might have problems obtaining and completing a change-of-address card, Frank said. Heinz was reviewing Frank's letter, said aide Isabelle Claxton. In the meantime, Claxton said the Postal Service has agreed to cooperate with the Senate panel in writing to more than 10,000 nursing homes certified by the federal government under Medicare and Medicaid. The letters will explain to homes their obligation to ensure that mail is forwarded.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Reports Border Skirmish; India Denies It
DOC.TEXT: Indian soldiers tried to capture a mountain outpost, starting a firefight with Pakistani soldiers along the cease-fire line dividing disputed Kashmir, Pakistan said Monday. India denied a battle took place. The Defense Ministry said the attack on a remote outpost in the Himalayas occurred Sunday, the day after talks on easing border tensions adjourned. It claimed there were Indian casualties, but did not say how many. Earlier Monday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman reported no progress in the talks, which adjourned without a definite date for resumption. India, a predominantly Hindu country, and Moslem Pakistan have been uneasy neighbors since their creation in the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule. Tensions have been heightened by a Moslem separatist uprising in India's part of Kashmir. ``The war threat has never receded,'' said an official of Pakistan's Defense Ministry, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``This could be an isolated incident or it could lead to escalation.'' Indian soldiers used artillery, anti-tank guns and mortars in attacking the outpost 60 miles northeast of Muzzaffarabad, capital of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, and were driven off with mortar fire after about an hour, the Defense Ministry said. ``Our forces repulsed the attack and inflicted casualties on the intruders,'' one official said. In New Delhi, an Indian government spokesman said: ``It's not true. We have not attacked. We have not used any artillery. We have not suffered any casualties.'' He also cannot be identified under briefing rules. Skirmishes and small arms fire are frequent along the U.N.-monitored line in Kashmir, over which the two nations fought wars in 1948 and in 1965. The attack was reported to U.N. military observers in New Delhi and Islamabad, the Defense Ministry said. The official described the alleged attack as an attempt to divert world attention from the secessionist movement in Indian-held Kashmir. India accuses Pakistan of arming, training and harboring Moslem militants fighting in Indian Kashmir, which the Pakistanis deny. Pakistan contends India is using brutal force to crush an indigenious independence movement. The uprising has cost more than 950 lives since Indian forces cracked down in late January. Tensions increased last spring in the 43-year-old dispute over Kashmir, a former princely state both nations claim, and their armies face each other acros the cease-fire line.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Slates Meetings on Gulf, Budget Deficit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet with his senior economic advisers Tuesday to review the costs of the Persian Gulf conflict and prepare for next month's negotiations with the Democrats on the budget deficit, the White House said Monday. The gulf crisis has already pushed up oil prices, creating a further drag on a sluggish U.S. economy veering closer to a recession. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has said the conflict could bring the economy's already-anemic growth rate ``closer to zero,'' although he says a recession is not inevitable. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the White House remains ``hopeful that the Democrats are operating in good faith and that we'll be able to reach an agreement.'' ``We think it's even more important that we reach an agreement now because there needs to be a unity of purpose in this country, not only about the conflict in the gulf, but also about our spending issues and about where the budget is going,'' Fitzwater said. Bush, who had planned to interrupt his vacation anyway to return to Washington for a Pentagon briefing, first will go to the White House Tuesday to meet with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, budget director Richard Darman, economic adviser Michael Boskin and others. Fitzwater said Bush ``wants some preliminary accounting of the Persian Gulf'' conflict, and whether it may require changes in the administration's proposal for reducing next year's deficit by $50 billion. ``The plan that we had ready to put on the table still represents our best view, but we're prepared to make changes if we think it's necessary,'' said the spokesman. Bush and his senior advisers will ``be talking about cutting expenditures, overall budget figures, taxation policy _ all those kinds of questions,'' Fitzwater said. The budget negotiations begun three months ago came to a temporary halt in early August, having produced little except an agreement to come back to the table when Congress and Bush return from their summer vacations after Labor Day. Fitzwater said that Bush has no plans to meet with the budget negotiators again until then. But Bush ``probably will speak out'' in the interim about the budget, he said. The president said last week he no longer felt constrained to hold his peace about the Democrats. Brady, in interviews last Friday, said the surge in oil prices could halve the U.S. growth rate this year from 1.5 percent to 0.75 percent. He said events make it ``all the more important to move apace'' on budget cuts. The administration estimates a fiscal 1991 deficit of $169 billion, not counting an estimated $62 billion more in savings and loan bailout costs. The negotiators have been trying to cut the deficit by $50 billion next year and $500 billion over five years. Bush acknowledged in late June that ``tax revenue increases'' were necessary, and word subsequently leaked that the Republicans favored raising taxes on alcohol and limiting deductions for state and local taxes. The Democrats refused to come forward with a plan of their own. Bush plans to return to Maine Wednesday after a briefing and a speech at the Pentagon.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Administrator Freezes Hiring, Anticipating Budget Impasse
DOC.TEXT: Federal Aviation Administrator James Busey announced Monday a freeze on some hiring and said contingency plans are being made for sharp cuts if Congress fails to pass a fiscal 1991 budget. Following White House instructions for all departments to plan for cuts, Busey told 50,600 FAA employees they might face mandatory furloughs without pay for 2{ days each two-week pay period and that national air traffic would have to be reduced. Busey was speaking of a worst-case scenario in the event that automatic spending cuts of 31.9 percent, known as ``sequestration,'' take effect Oct. 15. That would occur only if Congress and the White House fail to agree on a package of tax increases and spending cuts by Oct. 15. The immediate hiring freeze applies only to non-safety-related jobs, Busey told employees in a speech broadcast by closed circuit to 30 FAA facilities around the country. Busey said automatic cuts affecting FAA would total about $2.5 billion a year if they went into effect. He said this would lead to reductions in equipment purchases, suspension of permanent transfers, suspension of training programs, curtailment of some contracts, release of all temporary employees and support only for safety activities. The FAA would no longer be able to maintain safety in the skies at current levels, and flights by airlines, businesses and others would have to be reduced, Busey said.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Labor Force Down From Last Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of workers employed by farmers showed a seasonal increase in July but was down about 8 percent from a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Monday. A quarterly report said the hired work force on farms was estimated at 1,106,000 workers during the week of July 8-14, up from 833,000 in April. But that was down from 1,197,000 in the work force in July 1989. Those did not include 356,000 ``agricultural service'' workers provided by crew chiefs and labor contractors. In April, those totaled 203,000 workers, and in July 1989 they were estimated at 351,000. Showers and thunderstorms were widespread during the July 8-14 survey week over much of the eastern half of the nation, the report said. Heavy rains and flooding were common in some areas. Average pay for all workers hired directly by farmers was $5.30 per hour, up from $5.23 per hour a year earlier but below the average of $5.54 in April, the report said. For workers hired by contractors, there was no national wage rate available. However, workers in California were reported at $5.82 per hour, compared with $6.59 in April and $5.80 a year earlier in July 1989. Florida workers averaged $6.11 per hour, compared with $5.93 in April and $5.55 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Wedding Chapel Swamped as Soldiers Depart for Middle East
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
