DOC.TEXT: When Marines started preparing to leave for the Middle East, Shirley Cowart's phone began ringing at 5:30 a.m. Cowart performs marriages at a wedding chapel two miles from the main gate of the Twentynine Palms Marine Base, 130 miles east of Los Angeles. ``I've been doing weddings at 1 o'clock in the morning at home in my yard'' said Cowart. ``It's very, very emotional. I think their happiness is just a cover-up. They are all just very scared.'' Deborah and Cpl. Marc Castaneda got married Wednesday, even though they had planned a big church wedding for September. Castaneda, 23, left for the Middle East on Sunday. ``I've been crying since Tuesday, the minute I found out that guys from Twentynine Palms might be going and that my husband might be going with them,'' said Mrs. Castaneda, 30. ``I spent my honeymoon preparing my husband's will and power of attorney.'' Melinda Davis, 31, and Cpl. Lee Swain, 21, exchanged vows at the desert chapel Sunday. He knew he was heading to the Middle East, but was unsure when. ``I'm a little fearful ... but I don't think I'm gonna die. I'm more fearful for my friends,'' Swain said. The base normally has a military population of about 10,300, with 9,100 dependents.

DOC.BYLINE: AIDS Programs for Women Must Address Other Concerns, Researchers Say ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Programs to help women avoid AIDS also must address other problems the women see as more immediate, researchers said Monday. ``Talking about condoms with someone who doesn't have a place to spend the night is absurd,'' said Gloria Weissman of the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Rockville, Md. She and other researchers who are studying prevention of AIDS in women discussed the topic at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association. AIDS infection ``is hardly a primary concern for a woman who is hungry, without a place to spend the night or to put her children to bed, or without clothing to keep her warm,'' Weissman said. ``Unless some of these basic and immediate needs can be addressed, it seems not only hopeless but also foolish to be talking about risk reduction and life-saving measures,'' she said. The virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome can infect a person who injects drugs with a contaminated needle or has sex with an infected person. Several programs around the country are trying to block those routes of infection for women. One problem is that there is no device entirely under a woman's control that lets her protect herself from infection during intercourse, said Judith Cohen of the University of California, San Francisco. For many women at risk of infection, it can be dangerous to insist that her male sex partner use a condom or to refuse to have sex, she said. ``They come back the next day as a medical emergency. You just don't do that in some households,'' she said. Leaving a sexual relationship that poses a threat of infection can mean giving up rent money and a food supply, she said. In comparison to those immediate threats, concern about AIDS is ``kind of down the road,'' she said. Prevention programs must address issues of strategies to persuade men to put on condoms, she said. As for drug treatment programs, Weissman said most require that a woman find somebody else to care for her children during treatment, which few women can afford. And if a woman gets her drug-using male sex partner into treatment, she must then forgo his economic and emotional support, Weissman said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs of Esther Rolle item in AM-People with UPDATE on injuries. Picks up 3rd graf pvs., `She was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Actress Esther Rolle, the strong-willed matriarch in the 1970s hit television series ``Good Times,'' was in serious but stable condition following a single-car accident that killed a Texas woman, authorities said. Miss Rolle, 69, was in the intensive care unit at University Medical Center Monday following the Sunday afternoon accident. She suffered lacerations of the head and face, fractured ribs and a bruised heart, said hospital spokesman Dale Pugh. She was a passenger in a northbound car that rolled over on Interstate 15 near the California border, Nevada Highway Patrol troopers said. The driver was identified by the Clark County coroner's office as Paulene Hopkins, 70, of Marshall, Texas. She was pronounced dead at the scene. Two other passengers suffered minor injuries. Miss Rolle recently appeared as the housekeeper Idella in the Academy Award-winning film ``Driving Miss Daisy.''

DOC.HEAD: Interdiction: Put The Pinch On Iraq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his top aides refuse to define an ``interdiction of shipping,'' but the unspoken message to skippers is their ships could be boarded, shot at, or disabled if they trade with Iraq, military experts said on Monday. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said no formal instructions had been sent to U.S. warship commanders as of Monday afternoon but shipping was being monitored in the tense waterways near Iraq. ``We are keeping an eye on all ships in the region,'' Williams said. He declined to specify exactly what U.S. commanders would be told to do, but that the goal of the effort was to comply with the U.N. mandated sanctions against trade with Iraq. Williams said the Pentagon was working on ``precise plans'' for the ``operations, logistical, legal'' aspects of the interdiction effort. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, with Bush in Kennebunkport, Maine, said on Monday: ``We have had two or three ships in recent hours that have turned away or been turned away, or at least have otherwise not landed with their cargo.'' Purposely, Bush and other administration officials avoid using the word blockade _ since that is widely considered by international law to be an act of war. A former commander of the U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. George Crist, said any interdiction mission will be easily accomplished by the U.S. Navy forces in the region. Dozens of American vessels have been posted in the Mediterranean, Red Sea, Persian Gulf, and at the mouth of that strategic waterway _ all able to monitor the comings and goings of shipping to and from Iraq, he noted. Using international radio frequencies, U.S. commanders will query them about their destinations and cargoes, Crist told CBS News. ``If it is going to Iraq, then we'll ask them to steer clear. If they keep going, we may board to see what their papers look like, where are they going, what kind of cargoes they have,'' Crist said. If the captain of the ship decides he wants to continue in spite of the questioning, the U.S. commander will move his ship in such a way as to prevent the further passage of the cargo ship ``and advise him nicely would he mind going to another port,'' Crist said. If that doesn't work, ``we'll probably fire a shot or two just to get his attention. If necessary, we'll actually land people on the ship and move him. We also can disable the ship, shoot off the rudder, and he can't go any place,'' the general said. A U.S. military commander familiar with the day-to-day instructions given to officers confirmed Crist's account of how a commander might handle such a situation if so directed. And while U.S. warships have no standing orders, ``it's generally up to the commander to decide what to do,'' he said. The officer knows to ``accomplish his mission with the lowest level of force possible _ interdiction means that you physically interrupt the progress of a ship or vessel. You put your ship in such a position that you cause another ship to alter its behavior,'' the official said. Ideally, a public warning of the possible use of force might cause most shippers to halt activities of their own accord _ or even cause insurers to withdraw coverage, the official said, resulting in a halt of shipping without a shot ever being fired. The military official said the monitoring Williams' spoke of referred to the vast array of intelligence gathering methods available to U.S. forces around the world. ``It's the cargos, not the ships, that are important,'' he said. ``We have ways of knowing what's on those ships, if it's relevant.'' A delicate international legal situation arises, because a halt in shipping to and from Iraq will most probably mean dealing with ships from third-party nations, the official pointed out. Another question to be answered is the treatment of ships in other ports around the world with cargo bound for Iraq, another official said. ``And a third worry is freedom of navigation, if anyone tries to interfere with the movement of any ships in the region's choke-points,'' the official said. ``Our intent to maintain freedom of navigation in the region.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III caught officials by surprise on Sunday when he said U.S. officials intended to slap an immediate trade embargo around Iraq and that its oil tankers would be stopped at sea. The statement sent the Pentagon's strategists and legal experts scurrying to define for its military commanders just what steps can be taken to put a choke hold on Iraq's lifeline of oil, commerce and foodstuffs. White House spokesman said the purpose of the sanctions and the embargo ``is to put the pinch'' on the Iraqis, and that means ``not let supplies go in that allow them to maintain the war machine, allow them to maintain their aggressive takeover of Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Umbilical Blood Transfusion Given To Cure Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old boy got a transfusion of umbilical cord blood from his newborn sister Monday in an attempt to cure a rare and deadly form of leukemia. It was the first time such a transfusion had been attempted. In the past, bone marrow transplant has been the only treatment to increase survival for patients of leukeumia, a cancer of the white blood cells. If the transfusion works, doctors said, it could lead to the creation of a bank of such blood that could be transfused into children who might die before a sibling donor would be old enough to donate bone marrow. The patient, Michael Sancilio, of Virginia Beach, Va., was diagnosed in April as suffering from juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia. It cannot be controlled by drugs and usually kills within one year of diagnosis. When Michael's sister, Christina, was born May 1, doctors collected blood from the cord, hoping she would be a suitable donor. They couldn't wait to use her bone marrow because such a transplant can't be performed on children under six-months old, and doctors feared Michael could die by then. ``The odds were we thought he had the chance of surviving for a couple of months but it was unknown when the disease would accelerate and become life-threatening,'' said Dr. John Wagner of the Johns Hopkins Oncology Center. ``We decided to go ahead and take the chance on the cord-blood rather than waiting till the donor was old enough.'' Michael's parents and his brother, Tony, 7, weren't compatible donors. Wagner injected three syringes of cord blood into a vessel near Michael's heart as the boy dozed in his bed Monday, Wagner said. The boy had undergone eight days of chemotherapy to destroy his cancerous marrow. The transfused cells from Christina are expected to enter his bones and begin forming cancer-free bone marrow in 30 days, Wagner said. Cord blood transplants have been performed successfully twice in France and once in Cincinnati to treat a different disease, Fanconi's anemia, Hopkins doctors said. Blood in the umbilical cord provides nourishment and oxygen to a fetus while being carried inside the mother, and so differs from the baby's or the mother's blood. Dr. Richard Champlin, chief of the bone marrow transplant program at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, said the transplant could have long-term significance. ``In the long run it could provide the potential to protect and store umbilical blood from every baby and create a bank of cells for transplantation that could be used if a patient didn't have a donor within the family,'' he said. ``We hope it may be able to increase the number of donors available for patients, but it has to pass this test first,'' Wagner said. The transplant carries the same risk as a bone-marrow transplant. The recipient's immunity from infection is lowered during the procedure, and the body often rejects foreign cells. Umbilical cord-blood is particularly rich in stem cells, which the transplant recipient's body uses to form marrow. But the blood could only be transplanted to young children, because it doesn't contain enough stem cells to build marrow in the bodies of adolescents or adults, Champlin said. The transplant also raises ethical questions, said Dr. Jeff Malatack, a pediatrician at Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh. In suburban Los Angeles, parents conceived a baby last year to serve as a donor for their cancer-stricken daughter. Anissa Ayala, 18, was expected to receive a bone-marrow transplant from her baby sister, Marissa, in late summer or in the fall. ``Is the parent in the right position to offer the procedure be done on a 6-month-old to save a 4-year-old? The question will come up within families. What if it comes up with an unrelated baby?'' said Malatack. Malatack posited, for example, that if parents found umbilical cord blood in a bank from a baby they thought had similar tissue to their sick child, they might try to approach that child's parents about a possible bone marrow transplant. ``Someone could say, `I'd like to use your baby to put to sleep and do a bone marrow harvest so a baby in some other area of the country could benefit,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Max Bergerre, Dean of Vatican Reporters, Dead at 86
DOC.TEXT: Max Bergerre, a French journalist who covered the reign of six popes, died Sunday of cancer in a Rome clinic. He was 86. The dean of the Vatican press corps, Bergerre began reporting from the Vatican in 1931, at the time of Pope Pius XI, for the French news agency Havas. After World War II, he worked as Vatican correspondent for Agence France Presse. In recent years, he helped cover the Vatican for the Italian news agency ANSA and had worked up until the time he entered the clinic last month. He is survived by his wife and two children. Funeral services were scheduled for Tuesday in Rome.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Woman May Get Dodge Pickup for Rejecting Car
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio woman who turned down a $17,000 Honda she won on a game show because it was non-union will receive a new car _ union made, of course _ from the AFL-CIO, the labor federation said Monday. Last week, Pamela Richards told game show officials ``I don't want that Honda. I am union,'' when she won an Accord on the Ohio lottery show ``Cash Explosion Double Play.'' She took a $1,000 cash prize instead. The AFL-CIO was moved by her comments, especially since the game show bleeped over them, said Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the 14.2 million member federation. The union decided to give Richards a car. ``What we're trying to do is show that that's the point of view of a lot of people in this country, and they can't get their message out,'' Hardesty said. The Honda that Richards rejected was made at a plant in Marysville, Ohio., where labor leaders contend the Japanese automaker has used union-busting stunts to keep the United Auto Workers from organizing workers. Richards, a 23-year UAW member who lives in Risingsun, Ohio, wants a Dodge Dakota pickup, Hardesty said. Top-of-the-line Dakota trucks sell for between $16,000 and $20,000. Earlier Monday, a car dealer in Huntington, W.Va., offered to loan Richards a 1990 Imperial, a $28,000 luxury sedan, for a year. ``The stand she took to buy American was really remarkable,'' said Frank Horney, president of Huntington Chrysler Imperial. Richards said her four-driver family has four cars, but several of the vehicles are in poor condition. ``I'm excited. I never knew it was going to go this far,'' she said after being told of Horney's offer.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Rejects Saddam's Peace Proposal
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iranian leaders on Monday rejected Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's proposal linking a settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis in part with resolution of a border dispute with Iran, Tehran television reported. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Foreign Ministry spokesman Morteza Sarmadi as saying ``linking the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Iran to other international issues corresponds neither to international norms nor to Iraq's alleged commitment to United Nations Resolution 598.'' The U.N. resolution halted the bloody eight-year war between Iran and Iraq in August 1988. But subsequent peace talks have been deadlocked, and no formal peace treaty has been signed. In a statement Sunday, Saddam suggested that all problems of occupation in the Middle East be resolved together. Saddam indicated he might withdraw his forces from Kuwait if Israel withdrew from occupied Arab territories and Syria pulled its soldiers out of Lebanon. He also called for a settlement of the border dispute with Iran, including a mutual withdrawal of forces on both sides of the boundary. The Iraqis insist that a 1975 treaty drawing part of the mutual border at midstream in the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway is null and void. Baghdad claims sovereignty over the full strategic waterway that links the port of Basra with the gulf. Sarmadi said Iran complied with U.N. Resolution 598 by withdrawing its forces to internationally recognized borders. But he said ``parts of Iranian territory, since then, have remained under Iraqi occupation in defiance of the resolutin and all international regulations.'' He was referring to Iranian territory captured in the closing weeks of the war that Baghdad has refused to relinquish until Tehran agrees to grant full Iraqi sovereignty over the Shatt.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan-Iraq Oil Pipeline, Road Transport Running Normally
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM2
DOC.TEXT: A visiting U.S. congressman said Monday chances were slim of forcing Iraq to quit Kuwait without Jordanian sanctions. The Iraqi oil pipeline and road transport between Jordan and Iraq were reported operating normally. Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, D-N.Y., said immediately after conferring with Crown Prince Hassan, brother of King Hussein: ``We have two overriding interests at present and the first is to secure the effective cooperation of Jordan in the implementation of sanctions against Iraq. ``The second is to preserve the stability of this country.'' He spoke to The Associated Press on the Basman royal palace grounds. Iraq's pipeline to Jordan terminates at desert outpost H-4, about 30 miles southeast of Amman. Tanker trucks load the petroleum there and drive it to the Red Sea port of Aqaba for export. Some oil is kept for Jordanian domestic use. The line is apparently Iraq's last remaining oil export outlet following the closure, in effect, earlier Monday of a pipeline across Saudi Arabia. Information Minister Ibrahim Izzeddine reiterated Monday that Jordan intends to abide by the mandatory U.N. Security resolution imposing sanctions on neighboring Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion and annexation of Kuwait. ``But it is still premature now to decide what sanctions will be imposed,'' Izzeddine said, in view of Jordan's heavy economic dependence on Iraq. In Jerusalem, Israeli officials warned Jordan Monday not to transfer Iraqi exports through Aqaba, saying that would violate blockading of Iraq. Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, deputy chief of the Israeli Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, described Aqaba as Iraq's ``lifeline.'' Official sources at Jordan's Ministry of Commerce, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the pipeline was continuing to operate normally Monday. Solarz said he and Hassan discussed the Persian Gulf crisis ``and the implication for Jordan-American relations as well as the peace process between Israel and the Arab world.'' ``I think it is important that sanctions take effect forthwith . .. because they are the last and only remaining way to bring about a resolution of the crisis without the use of force,'' Solarz said. ``If sanctions don't work we will be confronted with the necessity of making a choice between capitulation and escalation and that is a choice very much in our interest to avoid.'' He said that ``if Jordan refuses to cooperate in the sanctions . .. there will be little hope of forcing Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait.'' Saddam is president of Iraq. Hassan said later on Jordanian television that ``we are under pressure from all sides from those who want to tell us how to conduct our affairs.'' ``Jordan will be enormously hurt when it applies sanctions against Iraq,'' he added, speaking in English in an interview with a visiting Australian TV correspondent. An Iraqi tanker was turned away when it tried to load at the Saudi pipeline's Red Sea terminal. An Iraqi pipeline through Turkey was shut earlier. The Commerce Ministry sources said Jordan imports nearly $300 million worth of Iraqi oil a year _ one-sixth of it by pipeline and the rest overland by tankers. They said the pipeline was used for much larger quantities during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war when Iraq's gulf ports were blockaded, but were unable to give its total capacity. AP photographer Yousef Allan at Jordan's border post of Ruweishid, 210 miles northeast of Amman, reported commercial traffic normal across the border. He said a truck or tanker crossed into Jordan every three or four minutes. Official statistics indicate that 40 percent of Jordan's exports go to Iraq, mainly agricultural products. Ministry officials said unemployment here, now at 16 percent, would go up 10 to 12 more percentage points if Jordan imposes sanctions. Jordan is also used extensively as a transit point for Iraqi-bound goods. Aqaba port officials reached by telephone said they received no instructions to stop unloading ships with Iraq-bound transit cargo, and unloading of these ships was continuing normally.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BEIRUT
Second Swiss Hostage Freed in Beirut, Arrives in Syria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of handover, former hostage's comment, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers in south Lebanon freed a Swiss hostage after 10 months of captivity, releasing Elio Erriquez to Syrian officials there who took him to Damascus and handed him over to the Swiss ambassador early Tuesday. ``I am happy, very, very happy,'' Red Cross worker Erriquez, 24, said at the Foreign Ministry before being whisked away by Swiss Ambassador Eric Pfister minutes after his arrival in the Syrian capital. Another Swiss hostage, Emanuel Christen, 33, was freed on Wednesday. Like Erriquez, Christen was an orthopedic technician with the International Committee of the Red Cross. Both men were kidnapped on Oct. 6, in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. In Beirut, a late-night communique from a group calling itself the Organization of the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said Erriquez was handed over on Monday to a representative of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, chief of Syria's military intelligence in Lebanon. The group said earlier that Erriquez was freed at the behest of Syria, Libya and Algeria. Syria's state minister for foreign affairs, Nasser Qaddour, turned the hostage over at 12:03 a.m. Tuesday after he was driven from Lebanon. Erriquez, wearing a white shirt and white pants, looked pale but well as his ordeal ended. He was driven to Pfister's residence in Damascus. There was no word on when he would leave Syria. In Geneva, his mother Graziana Erriquez, had agaonzied for hours Monday before receiving official confirmation her son was free. ``Waiting for definite word was bad,'' she told a reporter. ``I had been waiting all day long. But now, I am very happy.'' A brief, handwritten statement in Arabic from the kidnappers was delivered to a Western news agency at 11 p.m. Monday, with an authenticating photograph of the hostage. It said: ``The Organization of the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads announces that the release of the second Swiss hostage Elio Erriquez has been accomplished. He was handed over to a representative of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan.'' The statement said the two Swiss were freed in response to efforts by Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Chadli Bendjedid of Algeria and by Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. It gave no details. Masked gunmen seized Erriquez and Christen last October near a Red Cross center for artificial limbs in Sidon. Lebanese police had blamed the abduction on Fatah-Revolutionary Council, a radical guerrilla group led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The group denied the accusation. The Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said Monday it has no connection with Abu Nidal or any other Palestinian faction. Erriquez' release left 14 Western hostages in Lebanon, most of them held by underground Shiite Moslem extremists loyal to Iran. The captives are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Most have been held three years or more. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. The kidnappers' statement on Monday paid ``particular tribute to Mustafa Saad for efficient role to ensure a success'' of the release. Saad heads the leftist Nasserite Popular Organization militia, which has controlled Sidon since the outbreak of the Lebanese civil war in 1975. The Swiss Foreign Ministry and the Red Cross have denied any deal was made to win Christen's release. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said last week the release may have been a result of France's decision last month to pardon Anis Naccache and four other members of a pro-Iranian assassination team.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Firefighters Work To Save 1,600 Homes From Forest Fires
DOC.TEXT: One raging forest fire threatened about 1,600 homes Monday in northern California and three major blazes remained out of control in Yosemite National Park. Fourteen major fires and several smaller ones burned across California on Monday. The biggest fire _ the Campbell complex in Tehama County _ had charred about 114,000 acres, officials said. But firefighters' top priority was a smaller Tehama County fire, the 17,500-acre Finley Lake fire east of Red Bluff, which threatened 400 homes in the town of Manton, 200 in Mineral and an additional 1,000 in the general area, officials said. Loren Newman, a 73-year-old Manton resident, said he hadn't planned to leave his home. But as firefighters cut a 30-foot wide firebreak across his property Monday, he was reconsidering. ``I usually don't get too excited about fires, but this one has me hemmed in,'' he said. ``There's fire to the west, to the south and to the east.'' Elsewhere in the West, smaller fires burned in Oregon, Alaska, Washington, Idaho and Utah. About 1,200 soldiers from the Army's 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis near Tacoma, Wash., shipped out Monday to help fight fires in Oregon, Maj. John Lundberg said. They were to help dig fire lines and relieve fatigued crews battling two big blazes near Burns, Ore. It is the third summer in a row Fort Lewis troops have been used to battle fires. They were fought fires in Yellowstone National Park in 1988 and the Baker, Ore., area last summer, Lundberg said. An estimated 1,200 Army soldiers from the 4th Infantry Division at Fort Carson, Colo., were expected to arrive in Tuesday in northern California, where a long drought has heightened fire danger. Firefighting in northern California was hampered by an inversion layer _ a layer of cool air holding hot air down _ that held in smoke, creating hot and hazy conditions. Airplanes that bomb the fires with a mixture of fire retardant and fertilizer to encourage new growth were unable to fly Sunday or Monday, officials said. Because of the thick smoke, fire officials had to bring in helicopters with infrared sensors to identify ``hot spots'' and map them for ground crews. On the Finley Lake fire, firefighters worked Monday to create a two-mile-long defense line in Manton, burning out a swath that hopefully would counter the northbound forest fire and keep it from destroying several homes. ``Manton is our main concern this afternoon. There's up to 400 homes and 1,000 people in that area,'' said Paul Bertagna, California Department of Forestry spokesman. The fire also was nearing Lassen National Forest near Mineral and Lassen Volcanic National Park to the north. Manton residents hadn't been evacuated by midday but residents were advised to be ready to leave officials said. Manton resident Sally Beezley decided to leave her home. ``I was really calm until last night,'' she said. ``But when you see the flames, everything changes. ``The tops of the trees were on fire, and it was close enough so you could feel the waves of heat.'' Farther south in the Sierra Nevada range, three major fires still raged Monday in Yosemite National Park, where an estimated 17,000 acres had been charred. Yosemite has been off-limits to tourists since Friday. Flames in the park were within two miles of Merced Grove, a stand of giant sequoia trees up to 2,000 years old, and also within two miles of the Badger Pass ski area, the oldest ski resort in California. The sequoias were treated with fire retardant, but their thick bark usually protects them from fire, allowing dthem to reach their advanced ages. Flames were about 10 miles from landmarks like El Capitan, Half Dome and Yosemite Falls. Since Aug. 3, more than 200,000 acres of California forest has burned, mostly as the result of 31,108 lightning strikes, forestry officials said. A total of 127 structures had been lost as of Monday, including 42 from the Finley fire, Collier said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Demands Arab League Reconsider Move to Cairo
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz urged the Arab League to reconsider its decision to transfer its headquarters to Cairo, Egypt, the official Iraqi News Agency said Monday. Also, Iraqi news reports monitored Monday in Nicosia said Iraq has started special ``Voice of Arab Egypt'' broadcasts calling for an uprising against the government of President Hosni Mubarak and attacks on ``imperialist'' targets. The broadcasts started Saturday on frequencies of Iraq radio's domestic service. A program with the same name was introduced by Iraq radio after the late Egyptian President Anwar Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in 1977, which led to the Camp David peace agreement with Israel. The program was later discontinued. Iraq and Egypt have been at odds over Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Egypt has sent several thousand soldiers to Saudi Arabia as part of a pan-Arab force to deter Iraqi aggression. In a statement carried by the Iraqi News Agency, Aziz said the Arab League's decision to move its headquarters from the Tunisian capital of Tunis to Cairo must be reconsidered due to Mubarak's ``biased running'' of last week's emergency summit to discuss the Iraqi invasion. Twelve of the 21 League members voted at the summit to send an Arab force to the gulf region to protect Saudi Arabia and other threatened states from a possible attack by Iraq. Most League members also supported U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The manner in which Mubarak ran the meeting was a ``violation of the prevailing methods and norms in inter-Arab relations,'' Aziz said in the news agency report, which was monitored in Nicosia. Aziz, who attended the summit, accused Egyptian leaders of violating the Arab League charter, particularly an article which requires unanimity for adopting measures against a member state. He said the Iraqi delegation would raise the issue at the next meeting of the Arab League's Council scheduled for September in Tunis and demand that the headquarters remain in Tunisia. The League headquarters moved from Cairo to Tunis in 1979 after Egypt's membership was suspended for signing the peace treaty with Israel. Last year, the suspension was lifted and the headquarters is to move back to its former building on the Nile River this fall. Also Monday, Saddam asked Iraqis to treat Egyptians in his country with kindness, regardless of differences between their countries over the Gulf crisis. There are about 2 million Egyptians in Iraq, mostly workers who immigrated during the Iran-Iraq war. ``We call on all Iraqis, due to the present situation, to treat all Arab citizens well regardless of their rulers' stand,'' Saddam said in a letter addressed to the Iraqi people. Contents of the letter were reported by the Iraqi News Agency. ``All Arab citizens are your brothers. It is normal to say that not all Arab rulers were of our choice. Part of them were chosen by foreigners,'' Saddam said. ``We call on you specially to treat Egyptian citizens with the level of my affection and with the level of their kindness and their love to Iraq,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Working Tours for Budapest, Prague, Warsaw Journalists
DOC.TEXT: Eight reporters and editors from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland were named Monday for three-month working sessions on newspapers in the northeastern United States and Los Angeles. They are scheduled to arrive in September as the first Times Mirror fellows, selected by a panel of editors from the Times Mirror newspapers, the Times Mirror Center for The People and the Press said. The journalists from countries in transition from communism to democracy will begin their U.S. sojourns with two weeks of orientation at the Center in Washington, followed by assignments covering government, business, economics, the arts and people for Times Mirror Co. daily newspapers. The Washington center organizes public opinion surveys and other studies on issues relating to the press, politics and public policy. The fellows, their home and U.S. publications: Krystyna Lubelska, an editor and writer on social problems for the Polish national daily Zycie Warszawy of Warsaw, will work at the Los Angeles Times. Vladimir Matejovsky, a commentator and foreign affairs correspondent of Mlada Fronta, of Prague, a newly independent Czechoslovak national daily. The Baltimore Sun. Emoke Nagy, a literary and performing arts critic of Magyar Nok Lapja, Budapest. New York Newsday. Witold Pasek of Warsaw, an investigative reporter for Gazeta Wyborcza, daily linked to Poland's Solidarity movement. The Morning Call of Allentown, Pa. Pal Reti of Budapest, head of the Opinions department of Hungary's World Economic Weekly (Heti Vilaggazdasag). The Hartford Courant. Tomas Smetanka, foreign editor of Lidove Noviny, Czechoslovakia's leading post-communist daily. Newsday, Long Island, N.Y. Ivana Stepankova, a commentator and diplomatic writer of Mlada Fronta. The Los Angeles Times Washington bureau Eniko Tegyi, a cultural reporter and theater critic of Nagyar Nemzet, a Hungarian national daily. The Advocate of Stamford, Conn., and Greenwich Time of Greenwich, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Triggers Locally Heavy Rain From Plains To Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Locally heavy rain was triggered Monday by a cold front extending from the southern Plains through the Ohio Valley to the eastern Great Lakes. During the day Monday, 1.70 inches of rain fell during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT at Jacksonville, Ark.; 1.43 inches fell at Fort Sill, Okla.; 1.24 inches at Cincinnati; 1.18 inches at Mansfield, Ohio; and 1.11 inches at Youngstown, Ohio. In Arkansas, 3.85 inches of rain fell overnight at Shirley in the northwest part of the state, 3.10 inches was reported at Damascus and 2.00 inches fell at Jasper, the National Weather Service. Across northwestern Ohio, 2 inches of rain fell in many spots during the 24 hours up to Monday afternoon, the weather service said, with 2.64 inches reported at Elmore, southeast of Toledo, and 2.06 inches at Toledo. Parts of northern and central Indiana received between 1{ and 2 inches of rain with the passage of the cold front. Monticello got 2.20 inches in the 24 hours up to Monday afternoon. In western New York state, over the 24 hours up to 9 a.m. EDT, rainfall included 1.65 inches at Lancaster, 1.40 inches at Alden and 1.37 inches at Williamsville. Other heavy rainfall amounts reported over the 24 hours up to 8 a.m. EDT were 2.30 inches at Lincoln, Neb.; 1.83 inches at Erie, Pa.; 1.60 inches at Indianapolis; 1.54 inches at Niagara Falls, N.Y., and 1.53 inches at Fort Wayne, Ind. In the Southwest, low pressure in the upper atmosphere continued to threaten parts of Arizona with locally heavy rain. Behind the cold front, the morning temperature on Michigan's Upper Peninsula at Negaunee, near Marquette, chilled to a record low of 39. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 35 at Marquette, Mich. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 60 in California at Arcata and the Vandenburg Air Force Base to 98 at the Meridian (Miss.) Naval Air Station.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: No Contradiction Between U.N. Embargo, U.S. Quarantine
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and U.N. officials said Monday there was no contradiction between the United Nations' resolution that imposed a trade embargo against Iraq and President Bush's statement that food be included in American quarantine efforts. Iraq, roundly condemned internationally for its Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait, imports three-quarters of its food for its 17 million residents. Both the U.N. embargo against Iraq and the U.S. quarantine include all foodstuffs and grain shipments, except in cases of distress and humanitarian aid, U.N. and U.S. officials said Monday, speaking on condition of anonymity. The officials emphasized there was no contradiction between the U.N. resolution, adopted Aug. 6, and Bush's statement Sunday that food would be included in quarantine efforts. The U.N. resolution only exempts food from the embargo ``in humanitarian circumstances.'' It bars the import of food to build up Iraqi stocks and allows it only when there is serious need. Bush said that food would be covered in U.S. efforts to interdict commercial vessels bound for Iraq, but added that in some cases of severe deprivation and need there might be exemptions. The language in the convoluted U.N. resolution has given rise to confusion about inclusion or exclusion of food, and U.N. officials declined to interpret the language, saying the resolution stands for itself. But privately they said the resolution imposes an embargo on all foodstuffs, except in dire circumstances. Canada reportedly ordered a grain vessel bound for Iraq to return recently, diplomats said. Section C of the U.N. resolution says that U.N. member states should prevent: ``The sale or supply by their nationals or from their territories or using their flag vessels of any commodities or products, including weapons or any other military equipment, whether or note originating in their territories but not including supplies intended strictly for medical purposes and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs, to any person or body in Iraq or Kuwait or to any person or body for the purposes of any business carried on in or operated from Iraq or Kuwait, and any activities by their nationals or in their territories which promote or are calculated to promte such saleor supply of such commodities or products.'' The resolution also bans financial dealings with Iraq except those intended exclusively for medical or humanitarian purposes and ``in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs.''

DOC.HEAD: Red Tape Battle Evolves Over Chemical Warfare Clothing
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A small Tennessee company is fighting the Pentagon's plan to reduce the size of its $20 million contract for chemical protective suits that soldiers might need in the Middle East. Only weeks before U.S. troops headed to Saudi Arabia to counter Iraq and its threat of chemical warfare, the Army notified Camel Manufacturing Co. its contract would be reduced from 327,000 protective suits to 81,000. The Army claimed that Camel _ one of four companies that makes the suits for the military _ was slow to start making the suits. Company officials blame the government for the delays. Rep. James H. Quillen, the senior state Republican in Congress, wrote Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Monday seeking review of the Camel case. The letter ``stressed how important it is, especially during the Mideast crisis, that the contract be turned around,'' Quillen said. ``Let them finish the number of suits that they have been awarded.'' Company officials are worried they won't have enough capital to keep the 250-employee Newport, Tenn., factory open past September. Camel already has spent most of the $3.5 million advanced on the $20 million order. But company president Ben Bower said Monday that both Turkey and the United Arab Emirates were negotiating to buy suits from the company. The suits resemble camouflage fatigues, but are lined with charcoal-impregnated foam that acts as a filter to absorb poisons. Life inside the suits is roughly 10 degrees hotter than outside, but that's a small price to pay for survival, Bower said. ``They are not designed to be worn under normal circumstances,'' he said. ``They are totally impractical for any other use.'' Camel, which has been producing tents, field packs and similar goods for the military for 60 years, is one of only a few companies supplying the Army with chemical protection suits. The others are Sac & Fox, of Oklahoma City, Okla.; Isratex, of New York City, and National Apparel Co., of Birmingham, Ala. ``This is the first time we made these suits,'' Bower said. ``As a matter of fact, the government came to us and asked us to participate in this project.'' The government had no comment Monday. ``Normally, we are very up-front about contractual matters as a matter of public record,'' said Linda Nichols, spokeswoman for the Defense Logistics Agency, an arm of the Pentagon. ``But the way things are right now, we are being very careful about what we say.'' In cutting the order, the government cited delays in production at the Newport plant, Bower said. Production was scheduled to start in July 1989 but didn't begin until February. About 7,500 suits have been made so far. In full operation the plant is supposed to make 50,000 suits a month. Camel contends it would have started production sooner except for delays by the Army's Defense Personnel Support Center in Philadelphia in inspecting the cloth used in the suits. Bower said his company's contract allowed the center 30 days to inspect the materials. Instead, it took six months, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal O'Connor to Hear New Anti-Abortion Campaign
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 Roman Catholic bishops holding an unusually secretive meeting get their first glimpse Tuesday of a new anti-abortion campaign put together by a public relations firm. An official of the company hired by the bishops, Hill and Knowlton, said Monday they shouldn't expect anything startling. ``There's nothing new in this business, only new ways of packaging,'' said Phil Armstong, a Hill and Knowlton senior vice president. The two-day meeting of the National Council of Catholic Bishops is closed to the press. Church officials said they didn't plan to release a text of a speech that was to be delivered Monday by Cardinal John O'Connor, the archbishop of New York and chairman of the Bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities. Monday's program included conferences, speeches and anti-abortion films, according to a participant who spoke on condition of anonymity. The talks included one titled ``Abortion: Big Business.'' The film titles included ``Living Proof: A Visual Encounter with the Unborn'' and ``Adoption: The Option of Love.'' The Hill and Knowlton campaign is designed to ``reframe the abortion question for both the Catholic community and the general public,'' said Julie Sly, spokeswoman for the California Catholic conference. Sly defended the meeting's secrecy, especially involving the Hill and Knowlton presentation. ``They regard this as any other corporation that buys public relations services,'' she said. ``They won't release a working report to the public. It could undermine their campaign.'' Armstrong said company's presentation would ``basically involve research into public attitudes and show them how to better communicate the pro-life message.'' The bishops also retained the Wirthlin Group, a leading Republican polling firm that helped Ronald Reagan win his 1980 presidential campaign. That firm also was expected to deliver a report Tuesday. The hiring of Hill and Knowlton drew criticism from Eugene Kennedy, a professor of psychology at Loyola University in Chicago. ``The bishops have found a way to drive the money changers back into the temple,'' said Kennedy, who has written extensively on the Catholic Church in America. ``They are making a terrible mistake. They are playing in the ballpark of the pro-choice people and abandoning their real strength, which is spiritual and pastoral.''

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine-Poisoned Man Declared Brain Dead
DOC.TEXT: A man who drank a cocaine-laced soft drink from Colombia was declared brain dead Monday. A life support system for Maximo Rene Menendez was to be turned off Tuesday, according to an order signed by Dade County Judge Robert Newman. Menendez, 25, drank the contaminated bottle of Pony Malta on July 26 and immediately collapsed. He has been in a coma since the incident. The Food and Drug Administration recalled a shipment of the drink, and so far FBI laboratory technicians have found 20 bottles containing up to several ounces of cocaine each. Drug Enforcement Administration officials have said they believe the bottles were part of a drug-smuggling scheme gone awry. No suspects have been identified in the case, although police are looking for the owners of Miami Sweet, which imported the drink. The bottles were not intended for export and carried false labels, according to the Cerveceria Bavaria S.A., the Colombian company that manufactures the drink. State Attorney Janet Reno said she was consulting with Metro-Dade police about filing murder charges, but did not expect any decision before Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: 500 Americans Slip Out of Kuwait, Defying Iraqi Ban
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng: ``But a...'' to CORRECT day to Saturday; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng: ``She said...''
DOC.TEXT: About 500 Americans have quietly slipped out of Kuwait since the Iraqi conquest of that country, circumventing an Iraqi attempt to prevent Westerners from leaving, the State Department said Monday. The departures have lowered the official estimate of Americans in the Iraqi-held country to 2,500, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Other officials said the estimate is subject to change because precise numbers in such circumstances are hard to come by. The officials, insisting on anonymity, said fleeing Americans have been able to take advantage of lax Iraqi security at the final check point on Kuwaiti territory and enter the relative safety of Saudi Arabia. But a Briton, David Thomas Croskery, who apparently tried to flee by the same route was shot to death on Saturday by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. Ms. Tutwiler said the administration was ``shocked and extremely concerned'' by the incident. She said there were rumors on Sunday that all foreigners were being allowed to leave but the administration has been told that only Africans, South Asians and Latins are being given such permission. Iraqi broadcasts indicate that Arabs and East Asians also have been allowed to depart as well. False news reports about the opening of the Kuwait border with Saudi Arabia to all foreigners prompted 40 to 50 carloads of Americans to head for the frontier, Ms. Tutwiler said. She urged the media to report such developments with caution because the carloads of Americans were turned back at the border, their disappointment aggravated by ``blistering heat.'' The attempted exodus may have been the result of an Iraqi broadcast on Sunday saying the authorities have been instructed to ``facilitate the travel of the Arabs and foreign residents in Kuwait and other cities of southern Iraq.'' Southern Iraq is the term Iraqis have used to describe what was once Kuwait. Besides the Americans stranded in Kuwait, there are an additional 500 to 600 who have not been given permission to leave Iraq. With airports closed in both countries and borders sealed to Westerners, the Bush administration has become increasingly concerned that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may try to use the Americans to his political advantage. Still, the administration has refused to call the Americans in the two countries hostages. No demands have been made in return for their release. Foreigners fleeing Kuwait have given mixed reports on the situation there. Some accused Iraqi troops of rapes and other abuses but others said the Iraqis were well disciplined. On the diplomatic front, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly flew to Syria on Sunday for additional consultations after visits to Egypt and Saudi Arabia over the weekend. Ms. Tutwiler said the meeting with the Saudi officials ``was part of our ongoing cooperative efforts with the Saudi government to confront the threat from Iraq and to work towards the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and the restoration of the legitimate government there.'' She said there are conversations almost hourly with Iraqi officials in Baghdad and Washington on the situation concerning the Americans in Kuwait and Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has called Iraq's refusal to allow the Americans to leave a ``violation of norms.'' Baker had been scheduled to leave for his Wyoming ranch late last week for a vacation but plans to remain here until Thursday. ``A full communications package will be traveling with him, and should the need arise, he can be back in Washington in approximately four hours,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Marines Evacuate 97 Foreign Nationals from Liberia
With AM-Liberia
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists aboard the USS Saipan off Liberia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith is among them.

U.S. Marines flew helicopters into rebel-held territory in Liberia on Monday to evacuate 97 foreign nationals, including at least four Americans, fleeing heavy fighting in the capital Monrovia. The evacuees, who included the Spanish ambassador and the papal nuncio to Liberia, were airlifted during the morning from the port of Buchanan, which is controlled by rebel leader Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front. In addition to the Americans, the evacuees included at least 16 Spaniards, 15 West Germans, as well as smaller numbers of citizens of India, Lebanon, Switzerland, France, Britain, Holland and Guinea. There were also 21 Liberians, mostly dependents of U.S. citizens. ``We are very happy to be here. Our trip was extremely difficult,'' said Manuel de Luna, the Spanish ambassador. His nervous face showed signs of relief as he sat in the admiral's parlor on board the Saipan, moored four miles off Buchanan for the evacuation operation. The foreigners _ many of whom sought refuge in the West German, Spanish and Italian embassies _ had been trapped on the battle line in Monrovia's eastern suburbs, where heavy fighting broke out Friday after Taylor's forces attacked government troops. Rebels told local residents to leave the area. The foreigners left Sunday night in a convoy bound for Buchanan, about 90 miles southeast of Monrovia. The rebels insisted that the Marines arrive unarmed to carry out the evacuation from a beach in Buchanan. While heavily armed rebel troops patrolled the beach, the evacuees waited in a tropical storm for the helicopters to carry them to safety. Among those evacuated was Jeanette Carter of Colorado, who lectures in anthropology at the University of Liberia in Monrovia. ``People were petrified that the government forces would start using rockets to get the rebels out of the area'' in Monrovia's eastern suburbs, she said. ``We were frightened of being accused of being rebel sympathizers by the government. That was a realy worry in case the rebels withdrew from an area and the government forces returned,'' she said. Efforts to ferry the evacuees on by helicopter from the Saipan to Freetown, Sierra Leone, had to be abandoned because of heavy rain. U.S. Public Affairs Officer Matthew McGrath told reporters in Freetown that only eight of the evacuees were flown to the Sierra Leone capital on Monday. The Saipan, an amphibious assault helicopter carrier, is one of four Navy ships off Liberia with a contingent of about 2,100 Marines. More than 200 Marines were airlifted to Monrovia on Aug. 5 to evacuate Americans and protect the U.S. Embassy. Washington has said they would not intervene in the war in which rebels are seeking to oust President Samuel Doe. Prior to Monday's operation, the United States had only evacuated those foreign nationals who could reach the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia. The Marines also rescued American employees at a Voice of America relay station and U.S. Omega ship-tracking station behind rebel lines after the evacuations began.

DOC.HEAD: Disbanded East German Secret Police Blamed in Refugee Killings
DOC.TEXT: Two publications alleged Monday that East Germany's now-dismantled ``Stasi'' secret police murdered a leading human rights activist and a star athlete after they fled to West Germany. The newspaper Die Welt and the weekly pictorial magazine Bunte said East Germany's ousted security chief, Erich Mielke, ordered the deaths. West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel prosecutors will investigate ``confidential tips'' regarding such killings, but that ``it's not yet known whether these tips correspond with the facts.'' Mielke, 82, is in jail pending investigation of charges he abused his power and jailed people for criticizing the old communist government. Rights activist Michael Gartenschlaeger, 32, was killed May 1, 1976, while trying to dismantle self-firing guns erected along the two Germanys' frontier to deter escapes to the West. At the time he was believed to have been shot by regular East German border guards. Die Welt said Mielke's secret police found out in advance what Gartenschlaeger was up to and had a ``special commando squad'' waiting for him. Soccer player Lutz Eigendorf, 26, died in a car crash near the West German city of Braunschweig on March 5, 1983. Die Welt and Bunte said East German agents poisoned Eigendorf before the accident. Eigendorf was a former star performer for the East German national soccer team. Die Welt said Mielke was infuriated by Eigendorf's 1979 defection to West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Review Photos of Battered Jogger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with jury recessing for the day without a decision. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Jurors also...
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the case of the Central Park jogger finished a fifth day of deliberations Monday without reaching a verdict in the vicious gang rape that left her near death. Three teen-agers are charged in the case. Before recessing for the day, the jury asked to review photographs of the victim, including one that shows her on a respirator at a hospital, her head bandaged and her body battered. Jurors also asked for a ruler and a piece of string. They did not explain why they wanted those items. But observers at trial-level state Supreme Court noted that a Central Park map was in the jury room and speculated they would use the ruler and string to measure distances in the park. Defendants have given differing accounts of where the attack took place. Later, the jury asked for more photographs of the jogger and the crime scene, including aerial photos. Defendants Raymond Santana, 15, Antron McCray, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery in separate attacks on a woman jogger and two male joggers during an April 19, 1989, gang rampage in Central Park. According to prosecutors, the woman was jumped and dragged into the woods, where she was gang-raped, bashed with a brick and a pipe and left to die. The jogger is back at work as an investment banker but her sight, balance and smell are impaired.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents File Referendum Petitions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with petitions filed, quotes. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Infuriated Italian-Americans...
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a paid Martin Luther King holiday for state employees filed petitions Monday seeking a statewide vote on the issue. The holiday opponents needed 43,350 verified voter signatures in order to force the referendum. The petition filed with the secretary of state's office carried 71,000 names. Former Gov. Evan Mecham, a leader of forces opposing a paid King holiday for state workers, told cheering supporters that the slain civil-rights leader was amply honored by an unpaid Sunday holiday Mecham proclaimed as governor. ``I call on everyone to pledge to support the people's right to make the decision and to abide peacefully by that result of the people's vote, regardless of which way it goes,'' Mecham said. Mecham's successor, Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford, issued a statement meanwhile urging that voters approve the paid holiday and predicting that business could suffer if the paid holiday is rejected. The issue has been a sore point in Arizona since 1986, when Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a King holiday. Mecham, who took office in 1987, rescinded the holiday before it could take effect. The ensuing uproar included marches, tourist boycotts and convention cancellations. The furor also fueled a petition drive against Mecham, but he was removed by impeachment on other grounds before the recall vote could be held. In 1989, with backing from Mofford, legislators created a paid King Day for state workers by cashing in the state's paid Columbus Day holiday. Infuriated Italian-American groups joined forces with conservatives who believe there shouldn't be a holiday named for King, and gathered enough signatures to force a vote on the bill in the November's election. Supporters of a paid holiday the third Monday in January marking King's birthday went back to the Legislature this year and got a new bill passed. This one would restore Columbus Day as a paid holiday and keep King Day as a paid holiday. It also would knock the referendum on the King-for-Columbus swap off the ballot. But the 1990 bill is subject to referendum, just like the 1989 one, and opponents of King Day were given 90 days in which to gather at the 43,350 signatures required to force a referendum. Some of those who worked on the 1990 referendum drive said they believed there shouldn't be a holiday in King's honor because he was too liberal and because of stories about his personal life. Others said declined to take a position on King but believed voters should have the chance to decide whether to create and pay for the holiday. If the 1990 petitions contain enough valid signatures, both the 1989 and 1990 laws must be placed on the ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Randy Stone and Holly Powell Win Television Casting Emmys
DOC.TEXT: Casting directors Randy Stone and Holly Powell have won television Emmys for their work a miniseries or special for their casting of CBS-TV's ``The Incident.'' The award winners, named on Friday, were decided by a special jury of members of the casting executive peer group of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. The casting category winners are announced in advance of the actual ceremonies Sept. 16 at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. The casting Emmy will be presented to Stone and Powell during a Sept. 15 creative arts banquet and awards ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Arguments Heard in Challenge to NEA's Anti-Obscenity Pledge
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge was urged Monday to void an anti-obscenity pledge that artists and institutions must sign before they can get grants from the National Endowment for the Arts. U.S. District Judge Louis Stanton heard oral arguments in a lawsuit by the New School for Social Research against the government agency. The New School alleges that the pledge is unconstitutionally vague and violates free speech and due process. Stanton was to issue a written later. New School's attorney, Floyd Abrams, argued that the requirement violates the Constitution because grant recipients have to speculate as to what the endowment considers obscene. ``They have to tell us what is expected of us in a constitutionally permissive way,'' Abrams said. He also charged that the right to freedom of speech was infringed because he said the anti-obscenity ban adopted by Congress last October was designed to suppress speech the lawmakers found offensive. Assistant U.S. Attorney Allan Taffet, arguing for the endowment, made a brief presentation in which he argued that the NEA was merely enforcing legislation adopted by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Intensify Diplomatic Activity in Persian Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin intensified its diplomatic activity regarding the Persian Gulf crisis Monday, meeting with U.S., British and Chinese envoys and questioning the Iraqi ambassador on the exodus of Soviets from the region. A Foreign Ministry spokesman meanwhile expressed skepticism over the latest offer by Iraq's President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov met U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock, British Charge d'Affaires David Logan and Chinese Charge d'Affaires Zhang Zhen to discuss resolving the conflict in the gulf region, Tass news agency reported. No details of the meeting were disclosed. Igor Belousov, the Soviet official instructed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to oversee the evacuation of Soviet citizens from Kuwait and Iraq, messaged the Iraqi leadership on the matter, Tass said without elaboration. It said Belousov also received Iraqi Ambassador Ghafil Jassim Hussain and questioned him on the evacuation. Nearly 9,000 Soviets, including military specialists, are among the foreigners caught in the two countries following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh told reporters the Soviet Union ``continues its contacts with Iraq to convince it ... that the actions taken by Iraq are futile and that it should pull out its troops.'' The Soviet Union did not join the United States in rejecting Saddam's offer to pull his troops out of Kuwait. Saddam on Sunday linked any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Israel took the territories from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War. The United States and Israel quickly rejected the offer but the Soviet Union waited a day and did not condemn it. ``We have to see whether the realization of the conditions are realistic, and it's doubtful that it's really possible to implement the conditions,'' Gremitskikh said. Saddam's administration received more weapons from the Soviet Union than any other country. While the Kremlin has condemned his invasion of Kuwait, it is trying not to antagonize Arab nations and for years has strongly supported their demand for Israel to withdraw. The Soviet Union has sided with the United States overall in the conflict, jointly supporting U.N. sanctions against Iraq and stopping weapons supplies to its old ally. On the growing U.S. military presence in the gulf, Gremitskikh said it was important that the United States ``does not overstep the sensible limit which is necessary to ensure Saudi Arabia's sufficient defense.'' The Defense Ministry said in a statement Monday that Soviet military help to Iraq was not to be used against third countries. It said this country ``in recent times supplied only defense technology'' to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Seventh Depression Becomes Tropical Storm Fran
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Fran gathered strength in the western Atlantic Monday and was bearing down on Grenada and Trinidad and Tobago, forecasters said. The season's seventh tropical depression had dissipated Sunday but regained its shape and sped west at 25 mph with top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 6 p.m. EDT, Fran's center was near 9.3 degrees north latitude and 55.4, minutes west longitude, or about 400 miles east-southeast of Trinidad. Tropical storm-force winds of at least 39 mph extended 175 miles from Fran's center. The government of Trinidad and Tobago, which weathered an unsuccessful coup attempt by radical black Moslems two weeks ago, issued a tropical storm warning for its territory as well as Grenada and other nearby islands in the southeastern Caribbean. A tropical storm watch was in effect for several islands to the north: Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said hurricane specialist Hal Gerrish. The storm was expected to keep to its path and strengthen slightly Tuesday, Gerrish said, but its progress across the Atlantic was expected to slow. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30th.

DOC.HEAD: Hungry Crowds Raid Food Trucks in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Crowds of hungry shantytown dwellers have begun raiding trucks carrying food and stripping fields of produce on the outskirts of Lima and other Peruvian cities, news reports said Monday. The incidents occurred after the government of new President Alberto Fujimori announced harsh austerity measures last Wednesday to control Peru's 3,000 percent annual inflation rate and its debilitating fiscal deficit. Food prices have tripled and in some cases quintupled with the elimination of subsidies. Radioprogramas, Peru's leading radio station, reported that armed gangs were robbing cars and trucks traveling the Central Highway to the Mantaro Valley, located in the Andes 120 miles east of Lima. The valley, one of the most fertile agricultural zones in Peru, is Lima's breadbasket. Maoist Shining Path guerrillas have been trying for several years to disrupt agricultural production there to heighten the chaos already reigning in the country. Wholesalers in Lima said Monday that they had halted business in the valley because of reports of attacks on food trucks and looting in Jauja and Huancayo, the two largest cities in the area. Meanwhile, radio stations in the coastal city of Chiclayo, 410 miles northwest of Lima, reported crowds of several hundred people were robbing trucks carrying agricultural produce on the Panamerican Highway south of the city. A newspaper in Trujillo, Peru's third largest city 300 miles north of Lima, said crowds were raiding farmland around the city, stripping the fields of tubers, cauliflower, tomatoes, carrots and sweet potatoes. Another mob broke into Trujillo's principal slaughterhouse and made off with more than 100 sides of beef, pork and lamb. In Lima, several hundred people with picks and shivels pulled potatoes and produce from fields in farm districts on the north and east sides of Lima before dawn Saturday. News reports also said 40 people, some with revolvers, halted a truck before dawn Sunday 12 miles north of the capital and stole 400 chickens being taken to market. The food riots have stepped up in part because the government has yet to implement its emergency food program, critics said Monday. Prime Minister Carlos Hurtado Miller, who announced the austerity measures last week, said the government would provide more than $400 million in emergency food for Peru's poor the remainder of the year. At least 7 million Peruvians _ one-third the population _ live in extreme poverty, and four of five adult aged people lack steady jobs. Government-assisted soup kitchens say their budget has been cut in half. Shantytown community organizations complain they have received no government aid, despite Hurtado's pledge.

DOC.HEAD: Surrogate Mother Files Suit in Custody Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with suit being filed, full names of defendant couple. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `Van Deusen...
DOC.TEXT: A surrogate mother on Monday began a custody battle with the couple whose test-tube fetus she is carrying, saying they were callous about her health and wouldn't provide a good home for the child. Anna Johnson, 29, is seeking custody of the baby that she could deliver in one to two months. Attorneys on both sides of the case said it might establish a new legal definition of parenthood. ``It is Anna and her body that are responsible for this child. ... It is Anna's position that she is the biological parent,'' although she didn't provide the baby's genetic material, said Johson's attorney, Diane Marlowe. Johnson, a licensed vocational nurse, is on disability leave because of complications of the pregnancy that twice hospitalized her, once to receive medication to stop contractions. In the lawsuit she filed in Santa Ana superior court Monday, Johnson also sought child support and damages for emotional distress. The couple, in their mid-30s and identified in the lawsuit as Mark and Crispina Calvert, provided the sperm and egg to create the embryo that was then transferred from a laboratory dish to Johnson's womb. Mrs. Calvert was unable to carry a child because she had a hysterectomy. At a news conference, they denied Johnson's allegations they had ignored her medical needs and failed to make timely payments. Mrs. Calvert said Johnson had tried to speed up payment of the $10,000 fee that she was to receive for carrying the baby, which the couple said is a boy. ``I was surprised that she did this to us,'' she said. ``We thought that we had a good relationship after all I've done for her.'' ``Chris and Mark both feel their child is being held hostage,'' said attorney Christian Van Deusen. ``This is still a miracle baby. The end results will be worth going through what we're going through,'' Calvert said. ``The problem is not money. The problem is fetal neglect. And they will have to address that in court,'' said Richard Gilbert, another of Johnson's attorneys. A single parent with a 3-year-old daughter, Johnson said she had seen the surrogate contract as a way to put herself through graduate nursing school. She and Mrs. Calvert, also a nurse, worked at the same hospital in the Orange County city of Santa Ana. Van Deusen said Johnson's effort to pursue custody of a baby that has no biological relation to her is unprecedented. ``It's definitely going to be new ground turned,'' said Van Deusen. ``This is where the arguments will have to focus: what constitutes parenthood?'' Gilbert agreed. Although California law presumes that the birth mother is the legal parent, a judge has discretion in deciding a case, he said. ``I'm sure this will be one of the most difficult decisions the judge will ever have to make,'' Gilbert said. In the highly publicized Baby M custody case in New Jersey, the child was conceived by a surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, with the sperm of a man whose wife couldn't have a baby. Whitehead decided to renege on the arrangement, prompting a bitter custody fight. It was won in 1988 by the father, William Stern, and his wife, Elizabeth, who live with the 3-year-old girl in Tenafly, N.J.

Eds: Because of computer trouble at the National Weather Service, we have not received the data for the evening weather tables. At this time we do not know whether the data will be available this evening.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Two Die as Protesters Clash With Police
DOC.TEXT: Security forces opened fire on protesters Monday at the start of a two-day strike over government-imposed price increases. Police said two people were killed and two others wounded. The general strike, organized by nine unions, paralyzed this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. Stores, factories and government offices were closed and most public transportation was halted. Police said about 300 people were arrested in the capital of Santo Domingo and four other cities. In Santo Domingo, one man was killed and two were injured when police and soldiers opened fire on protesters who erected flaming barricades and threw rocks and bottles at cars, according to police. Security forces also used tear gas and clubs to disperse protesters. Police said another man was killed during a similar violent demonstration in San Cristobal, 17 miles west of the capital. Unions organized the nationwide work stoppage to protest steep price rises for basic consumer goods announced Wednesday by the government of President Joaquin Balaguer. The announcement prompted three days of violent protests in which five people were wounded by police, stores were looted and 200 people were arrested, according to police. Balaguer, 83, who is to be inaugurated Thursday to a second consecutive four-year term, lifted government subsidies, causing prices to rise, as part of an austerity program recommended by the International Monetary Fund. Gasoline prices rose by 83.6 percent, flour 95.8 percent and sugar 75 percent, among other increases. The government said Saturday it would announce later this week price freezes on 30 items to offset the increases. In 1984, during the last austerity program implemented by a government, disturbances lasted three days and more than 100 people died. The conservative Balaguer narrowly defeated his longtime leftist rival, former President Juan Bosch, in a disputed election May 16.

DOC.HEAD: 300 Arrive Home from Saudi Arabia; Others Recount Escapes
With AM-Gulf-Americans, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 300 weary wives and children of oil workers flew to Houston from their adopted Saudi homes on Monday, and a businessman who fled Iraq after the Kuwait invasion said he would form a group to help stranded Americans. A State Department spokeswoman said Monday that about 500 Americans have managed to flee Kuwait since Aug. 2. Among them were a Las Vegas dance troupe, guests of the Kuwaiti royal family, who were awakened before dawn by their hosts to flee across the burning sands to Saudi Arabia. Another woman described being led across the border by a Bedouin guide. The group that arrived in Houston on a 20-hour flight from Riyadh via Amsterdam included 8-year-old Nathan Gildersleeve, who said he left his father behind in Saudi Arabia ``because I missed my mother.'' ``It's good to be home,'' said Linda Gunter of El Paso. ``We just wish our husbands were with us.'' Aramco Services Co., a petroleum services firm, arranged for the flight to return children home for the fall school term and to allow others concerned for their safety to come home. Michael Saba, a businessman who was in Baghdad at the time of the invasion, said he would use his connections in the region to help stranded Americans get out through a group he is forming called the Coming Home Committee. ``Of course, all of us who were kind of stranded in Iraq were tense, waiting to see what was going to happen,'' said Saba, president of GulfAmerica International Business Services of Champaign, Ill. ``But, I do want to point out that the Iraqis treated us very well.'' Saba said he has visited the families of Americans still stranded in Iraq and Kuwait and would work with the State Department and private humanitarian groups. ``We feel strongly that private efforts need to be made,'' said Saba. ``We'll be working as individuals and we're accepting donations to pay for phone calls, postage, tickets home and the like.'' Saba and another U.S. businessman paid $100 on Wednesday for an eight-hour taxi ride from their Baghdad hotel to the border between Iraq and Jordan, then hitchhiked across the Jordanian desert to Amman. Saba said Iraqi troops stopped the taxi once and checked passports, but made no effort to prevent him from leaving. Many foreigners stayed behind because they were unsure whether the border was open, Saba said. Iraqi declarations on the subject have been contradictory and confusing. Saba said he was staying at the Sheraton Hotel at the time of the invasion, and was moved by the government to the Rashid, a luxurious hotel with beautiful grounds, a swimming pool, a gourmet restaurant and bowling alley. He recalled lighter moments such as eating Del Monte bananas in the hotel lounge while listening to a piped-in song with the lyrics: ``Please release me, let me go.'' A seven-member American dance troupe, staying in a beach villa as the guests of the Kuwaiti royal family, were awakened moments after the Iraqi invasion by their hosts and helped to flee, said Shirley Rankin, the mother of one of the dancers. Suzette Rankin, 19, of Las Vegas, and the other dancers were in Kuwait to give a performance for the U.S. ambassador and the emir of Bahrain, Mrs. Rankin said. It was the 19-year-old's first trip overseas, her mother said. ``Needless to say we didn't expect this much of an adventure,'' she said. A Saudi hotel at first refused to allow the dancers to register because they were unaccompanied, Mrs. Rankin said. But the intervention of a British diplomat resolved the quandary. Ramona Magee, 30, of San Diego, said a Kuwaiti Bedouin had helped her and a British companion, Anita Rawlinson, escape from Kuwait to Saudi Arabia shortly after the invasion. ``We drove south across the desert on hard sand to avoid the main roads,'' Magee, a marketing manager for a Kuwaiti firm, said in a telephone interview from London with The San Diego Union. The group was at once point turned back from the Saudi border, but Iraqi soldiers finally let them pass, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Israeli Commander Ordered Beatings as Punishment
DOC.TEXT: A general testified on Thursday that Maj. Gen. Amram Mitzna, former army commander of the occupied West Bank, ordered Palestinian rioters beaten as punishment, in violation of army policy at the time. Brig. Gen. Benny Tahan also told a military court he heard Mitzna order demonstrators' limbs broken, according to Israel radio. Mitzna was West Bank commander when the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule began in December 1987. Tahan was a defense witness for Col. Yehuda Meir, 37, who is being court-martialed on charges of ordering soldiers to break the bones of Palestinian detainees. Meir faces 20 years in prison if convicted. The trial resumed Monday after a vacation recess. The radio said Tahan testified, ``I heard with my own ears Mitzna order beatings to deter and punish. ... He even used the expression `break their hands and legs.'' Israeli military authorities introduced beatings to deter Arab demonstrators a month after the uprising began. The practice was phased out after proving ineffective and drawing criticism. As a prosecution witness, Mitzna testified in May that beatings were to be administered solely to disperse protestors and control detainees. He described Meir's actions as ``blacker than black.'' Meir swore that former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin gave orders in January 1988 to break the bones of Palestinian inciters as punishment. He said Mitzna attended meetings with Rabin and did not object to the ``policy of the beatings.'' Military prosecutors say soldiers acting on Meir's orders arrested about 21 Palestinians in two West Bank villages in January 1988, took them into nearby fields, bound and gagged them and beat them with rifles and clubs. At least 12 of the Palestinians reportedly suffered broken limbs. Also Monday, unidentified security sources said they foiled a plot last June to explode a car bomb at Jerusalem's government compound that houses the prime minister's office, Israel television reported. It quoted them as saying Wail Mohammed Salameh, 31, a Jordanian citizen, was charged with planning to steal a car, fill it with 66 pounds of dynamite and blow it up as workers were leaving for home.
