The TV report said he was caught a week before the planned attack, and that according to the charge sheet, Salameh was trained and sent by Fatah, the mainstream faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Scrambles to Ready Three Warships for Persian Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Trucks filled the navy dockyard Monday as Canada scrambled to get three warships ready for duty in the Persian Gulf region. ``I don't think there was a flatbed truck in the country east of Winnipeg that wasn't used this past weekend for this operation,'' said navy Capt. Roger Chaisson, who commands 1,700 civilian workers at the ship repair unit. Four Phalanx anti-missile guns were among the issue sent to Halifax after Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced Friday the ships would join a multinational fleet. The guns, whose computers and twin radars direct up to 3,000 rounds a minute at incoming missiles or aircraft, were stored at Saint John, New Brunswick, and Lauzon, Quebec, for frigates still under construction. One Phalanx each will be put aboard the destroyers Athabaskan and Terra Nova. Two will be mounted on the supply ship Protecteur. Dockyard workers were toiling around the clock in shifts. The commodore heading the task force, Ken Summers, said he expected the vessels would leave Halifax by the middle of next week. The ships are 18 to 30 years old. The navy's senior surgeon, Capt. Larry Myette, was assembling a team of 15 to 20 doctors, nurses and technicians. They were equipped to treat everything from food poisoning to combat injuries, including chemical weapons, he said. Iraq reportedly has mass quantities of chemical arms such as mustard gas, which it reportedly used on Kurdish separatists and during the Iran-Iraq war.

DOC.HEAD: Seventh Depression Becomes Tropical Storm Fran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `At 6 p.m....,' to UPDATE with storm's 9 p.m. position.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Fran gathered strength in the western Atlantic Monday and was bearing down on Grenada and Trinidad and Tobago, forecasters said. The season's seventh tropical depression had dissipated Sunday but regained its shape and sped west at 25 mph with top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 9 p.m. EDT, Fran's center was near 9.4 degrees north latitude and 56.3 degrees west longitude, or about 330 miles east-southeast of Trinidad. Tropical storm-force winds of at least 39 mph extended 175 miles from Fran's center. The government of Trinidad and Tobago, which weathered an unsuccessful coup attempt by radical black Moslems two weeks ago, issued a tropical storm warning for its territory as well as Grenada and other nearby islands in the southeastern Caribbean. A tropical storm watch was in effect for several islands to the north: Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said hurricane specialist Hal Gerrish. The storm was expected to keep to its path and strengthen slightly Tuesday, Gerrish said, but its progress across the Atlantic was expected to slow. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30th.

DOC.HEAD: Electrical Fire Knocks Out Power in Lower Manhattan
Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with power out for several days, rush hour hellish; picks up 8th graf pvs, `The new...
LaserPhoto NY39
DOC.TEXT: An electrical fire knocked out power to the skyscrapers of Manhattan's financial district Monday, disrupting stock trading, stranding people in elevators and sending thousands home early through traffic-snarled streets. Consolidated Edison said power could be out for several days in a commercial area of roughly 50 square blocks. The midday cable fire at a Con Ed substation spewed plumes of black acrid smoke into the air over the southern tip of Manhattan. Workers poured out of buildings like the World Trade Center and South Street Seaport in search of pay phones and cool drinks. Many subway lines and commuter tunnels were stalled or shut down; thousands walked across the Brooklyn Bridge and rush-hour ferry service began early. The outage affected 4,150 customers, mostly businesses employing tens and possibly hundreds of thousands of employees. After issuing a plea for consumers to cut energy use, the utility restored power to about three-quarters of the affected area by 5 p.m. by re-routing current through other substations, said Con Ed spokeswoman Pat Richardi. But power could be out for several days in one mostly commercial area, Richardi said. No power in tall buildings also generally means no water, since the pumps aren't working, the utility said. The section stretches from just below the Brooklyn Bridge to Wall Street and from William Street to the East River. It includes such landmarks as the South Street Seaport and the Fulton Fish Market. Monday afternoon, pedestrian traffic was so thick it overflowed from the sidewalk onto the street, which was clogged with buses and taxis. Traffic lights were shut off so police directed traffic by hand. ``The evening rush hour is ruined,'' said Transit Authority spokesman Jared Lebow. ``We have so many trains backed up, it's like putting water through a eye dropper.'' The New York Stock Exchange was unaffected by the outage, spokesman Ray Pellechia said. But the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and Commodity Exchange all halted trading for the day at 1 p.m. Hundreds of people were stuck in elevators at the World Trade Center for up to 2{ hours, said D. Joy Faber, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority, which operates the 110-story twin skyscrapers, the tallest buildings in the city. ``My legs are buckling. I feel so sore,'' secretary Ethel Levine said after walking down 33 floors. Steve and Carol Holett, visiting from Los Angeles, were on the 36th floor of 1 World Trade Center when the lights began blinking and then went off for good. They decided to walk down because they didn't want to spend their only day in town stuck in an office. William Unroch, stuck inside his high-rise home at Battery Park City, was not as lucky. ``It's horrible here. All the gas is off, the water is off, everything is off. I'm trapped here on the 35th floor. I can't get out of my apartment. I'd have to walk down 35 flights.'' Others made the best of the situation. ``It's the first time I've walked across the bridge. It's pretty nice,'' said Joseph Eckart, an insurance company employee who strolled the Brooklyn span that crosses the East River, holding hands with his girlfriend, Angela Rizzica. ``We feel like it's seventh grade and we've gotten a day off,'' said engineer John Gratten. The fire at Con Ed's Seaport substation on Front Street was reported at 11:50 a.m. and escalated to a four-alarm fire by 3 p.m., said Fire Department spokeswoman Joe McGee. It was declared under control at 5:25 p.m. The cause wasn't known, McGee said. Some 125 firefighters, including a decontamination and hazardous materials unit, helped fight the fire. Seventeen firefighters were treated for smoke and exhaustion, said Marilyn Bernard, a Fire Department spokeswoman. Experts tested for dangerous gases, but Tina Casey of the Department of Environmental Protection said later that tests had been negative.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Gov't Resigns, Parliament Elects New Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: The government of Soviet Armenia resigned Monday, and the republic's parliament elected a nationalist as the new prime minister, the Tass news agency reported. Lawmakers elected Vazgen Manukyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement, as prime minister by a vote of 170-35, Tass said. He replaces Vladimir Markaryants, who submitted his resignation earlier in the day, along with that of his government, Armenian radio reported. Manukyan, 44, was nominated as prime minister by Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan, who on Aug. 4 was elected to his post by the parliament. Both new leaders were prominent figures in the Armenian National Movement and the Karabakh Committee, a group seeking Armenian control over the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is inside neighboring Azerbaijan. With Manukyan's election, Ter-Petrosyan told the parliament, ``We have proved we have a strong power that should become a guarantee of stability of the political situation in the republic,'' the Interfax news service reported. Manukyan is expected to form a new cabinet within a month, Tass said. Hundreds of people have been killed the last two years in ethnic clashes between Christian Armenians and Moslem Azerbaijanis over control of the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. The mostly Armenian region has been controlled by Azerbaijan since the 1920s.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Leave Two Dead, 2,000 in Shelters
DOC.TEXT: Storms and flooding have left two people dead and forced almost 2,000 people to flee to temporary shelters in the northwestern state of Sonora, officials said Monday. Roads were flooded in the Gulf of California port of Guaymas, isolating it from other towns inland, said Mirolava Villa, a spokeswoman for the Guaymas police. The dock was still open. Many people were being housed in temporary shelters, churches and schools, she said. Scores of wooden homes were destroyed. Although the rain had stopped by Monday afternoon, some Guaymas streets were under 10 feet of water, Ms. Villa said. Flooding was less severe in the nearby city of Empalme, which is at a higher elevation, she said. The main road to the popular tourist community of San Carlos was open. Many of those rescued and taken to shelters were traveling on Highway 15 between Guaymas and Hermosillo, the capital of Sonora about 70 miles to the north. Parts of the road were under water. More than 400 medical and volunteer assistants were flown in to Guaymas, said Beatriz Rodriguez Samudio, a Red Cross volunteer in Guaymas. Food and other necessities were also being airlifted into Guaymas. Most telephone lines were either out of order or jammed by calls, and many residents were communicating by radio, she said. Guaymas is about 230 miles south of the Mexico-U.S. border city of Nogales.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Lords to Keep Truce Despite Killing of Cartel Member
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers said Monday they will hold to the cease-fire they declared last month despite the killing by police of Gustavo Gaviria, a major leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel. The pledge came in a statement sent to local news media and bearing the letterhead the ``Extraditables,'' as the cartel calls itself. The statement said Gaviria was unarmed and was executed by police last Saturday, not killed in a shootout as officials said. ``Arrest warrants have become execution orders,'' it claimed. Gaviria, considered the No. 3 man in the cartel, was shot by members of an elite anti-narcotics police unit at his luxury apartment in southern Medellin. The Extraditables said they still would continue the truce they declared July 27 in their year-old war against the government. ``Our cease-fire is indefinite and our desire for peace is unshakable,'' the statement said. Officials had feared terrorist attacks would follow Gaviria's killing. After his death, police in Medellin and the capital, Bogota, were put on maximum alert. The cartel has been blamed for killing about 500 Colombians the past year in bombings and assassinations. Police operations director Gen. Octavio Vargas said in statements published in a Bogota newspaper Monday that authorities had wanted to capture Gaviria alive, hoping he could lead them to Pablo Escobar, boss of the Medellin cartel. Vargas said security troops tailed Gaviria for 20 days, finally moving in because they feared he would discover the secret intelligence operation against him. Observers say drug traffickers may be waiting to see if Colombia's new president, Cesar Gaviria (no relation to Gustavo), will continue extraditing accused drug smugglers to the United States _ a fate the drug lords fear most.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Files Suit Challenging Rap Group Ban
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit Monday challenging a sales ban on ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' the album by rap group 2 Live Crew. The suit filed in Richland County Circuit Court asks for a prohibition on arrests for the sale of the album. It also asks that a judge decide whether the album is obscene. Richland prosecutor Jim Anders, who in June threatened to prosecute those selling the album, is named as the defendant. Three record stores have joined the ACLU as plaintiffs, said Steve Bates, executive director for the South Carolina ACLU. Anders welcomes the suit's request for a determination on whether the material is obscene, he said, adding, ``I think it ought to apply statewide.'' Joe Watson, prosecutor for Greenville and Pickens counties, has also threatened prosecution of stores who sell ``Nasty.'' Bates said the record ``has significant literary, artistic and political values that reflect the African and Afro-American heritage of a large segment of our population.'' He acknowledged that 2 Live Crew's use of raw and sometimes violent sexual imagery in songs like ``Me So Horny'' made it ``tough to argue this.'' By South Carolina standards, Anders said, the album is obscene. The ACLU is a group that wants ``anything to go,'' he said. A person found selling obscene material under state law could be subject to a maximum fine of $5,000 and five years imprisonment. The group has been at the center of a First Amendment-obscenity battle since June, when group members were arrested in Hollywood, Fla., after they performed songs from the album in a nightclub. A federal judge in Florida declared the album obscene. Selling ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has also been banned in the city of Aiken, and the city of Charleston in July kept a city-owned outlet from selling tickets to a 2 Live Crew performance at a private auditorium. The controversy is helping 2 Live Crew's sales nationwide. The group's ``Banned in the U.S.A.'' album, a free-speech anthem based on the Bruce Springsteen song, ``Born in the U.S.A.,'' has sold nearly a million copies.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 5.6 Rattles South-Central Alaska
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to restore dropped word miles.
DOC.TEXT: A moderately strong earthquake shook the Kenai Peninsula south of Anchorage Monday, knocking objects from store shelves and rattling residents as far as 400 miles away, authorities said. The quake measured 5.6 on the Richter scale, according to the Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer and the Alaska Earthquake Information Center in Fairbanks. A quake of that magnitude is capable of causing considerable local damage in the right conditions. Those agencies and police in Homer and the other main peninsula town of Kenai said there were no reports of damage or injuries. ``Everything was dancing _ it felt like the roof was coming in,'' said Fran Skaggs, who works at Ulmer's Rexall drugstore in Homer. ``There were quite a few things falling off the shelves,'' Skaggs said. ``We didn't lose anything _ there's just a few piles of things here and there that need to be cleaned up.'' The quake, at 3:04 p.m., was centered between Homer and Ninilchik, said Charlotte Rowe, a seismologist at the Earthquake Information Center. The area _ a popular vacation spot some 110 miles southwest of Anchorage _ is one of the more populous parts of the sparsely settled state. It was felt strongly in Anchorage and also in Fairbanks, 400 miles to the north. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., gave the quake a Richter reading of 5.3, said spokeswoman Pat Jorgensen. Dispatcher Sam Brown of the Kenai Police Department said she hadn't received any calls about the earthquake. ``We felt a big jolt and things started shaking pretty good,'' she said. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Says Blood-Alcohol Not Enough to Judge Impairment
DOC.TEXT: Evidence of alcohol in the blood doesn't always mean a person is impaired, a behavioral scientist testified Monday at the trial of three former Northwest Airlines pilots charged with flying while intoxicated. James Wilson, a psychology professor at the University of Colorado at Boulder, testified for the defense that impairment by alcohol varies from person to person. Some test subjects, he said, have been unimpaired with a blood-alcohol content as high as .10 percent, he said. ``Everybody is different,'' he said. ``A lot of people dosed (with alcohol) are steadier than a lot of people sober.'' Wilson's testimony in the trial of Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse, 1st Officer Robert Kirchner and flight engineer Joseph Balzer conflicted with the testimony of a prosecution witness. Herbert Moskowitz, also a behavioral scientist, told the federal jury last week that all people are impaired beginning with alcohol concentrations as low as .01 percent. The three pilots are accused of flying a Boeing 727 on March 8 from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities while under the influence of alcohol they drank the night before at a lounge in Moorhead. Blood-alcohol tests taken two hours after Flight 650 landed showed blood-alcohol concentrations of .13 percent for Prouse, .08 percent for Balzer and .06 percent for Kirchner. The pilots are being tried in U.S. District Court on charges of operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. The case marks the first time that commercial pilots have been tried under the 1988 federal law provision prohibiting operation of a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol. Unlike state drunken-driving laws, the federal law doesn't specify an illegal blood-alcohol content. To find the pilots guilty, jurors must conclude they were impaired by alcohol despite their apparently solid performance. Prouse has said he is an alcoholic with a built-up tolerance. Wilson testified that there are three types of tolerance to alcohol: chronic, acute and innate. People who drink heavily can develop chronic tolerances and the children of alcoholics are sometimes innately tolerant of the drug, he said. In addition, people can become more tolerant to alcohol during a single drinking session, he said. He said all three types of tolerance can be at work in the same person, making it possible for a drinker to be unimpaired after significant doses of alcohol. Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega asked Wilson if he thought it would be safe for a pilot with a blood-alcohol content of .15 percent to fly a passenger jet. ``Very possibly,'' Wilson said. She asked if it would be more safe if that pilot was an alcoholic. ``Quite likely,'' he said. Thomas Burr, an expert on alcohol testing who also testified Monday for the defense, said alcohol impaired only about half of the people he has seen tested to have blood-alcohol concentrations between .05 percent and .08 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Earth First! Disavows Organization
DOC.TEXT: One of the founders of Earth First! is leaving the radical environmental group because he believes it is being pulled too far to the left, he said in a report published Monday. Dave Foreman, 42, told the Santa Rosa Press Democrat the group has been tilted beyond its environmental ethic into a ``leftist'' arena by ``yippies and hippies.'' Foreman, who once supported Republican Gov. Barry Goldwater, said he doesn't want any hard feelings with his fellow environmentalists. ``I just want a no-fault divorce,'' Foreman said. Foreman's disavowal seemed to threaten a split within Earth First!, a loose-knit movement that hasn't got a formal membership list but circulates a monthly journal to at least 15,000 people. Foreman maintained that the movement's emerging leaders, including the Northern California promoters of the Redwood Summer campaign to disrupt logging, are ``more interested in the wildness within than the wildness out in the forests'' He said he began to pull back from his highly visible role in Earth First! a few years ago, partly because of his disenchantment with the growing influence of activists like movement co-founder Mike Roselle of Berkeley and Judi Bari of Mendocino County. ``I'm not feeling we share the same style,'' Foreman said. ``We have very different strategies.'' Earth First! is generally split into two factions, one of which wants to stick to the original goal of disrupting activities seen as harmful to nature. The other, based in Northern California, prefers more traditional peaceful protests but also would broaden its activism to wider social issues. Several followers and key organizers, including Foreman, are either under indictment or face possible criminal charges stemming from pipe bombings, tree spikings and an alleged plot to shut down nuclear plants in Arizona, California and Colorado. In May, Bari and group member Darryl Cheney were injured when a pipe bomb exploded in her car. ``Dave Foreman wants Earth First! to remain small, pure and radical. I want it to be big, impure and radical,'' said Bari. She said she wants to go beyond ``eco-defense tactics'' like tree spiking and vandalizing heavy-duty logging equipment. ``Profound social changes don't come about without a mass movement,'' she said. Roselle accused Foreman of ``red-baiting,'' and said he was ``a retired old man out on the lecture circuit.'' ``We don't need Foreman in Earth First! if he's going to be an unrepentant right-wing thug,'' Roselle said. ``We're going to keep doing what we think is best, and that's raise these issues and confront the industries that are trying to exploit our last wild lands.'' Foreman, a former lobbyist, helped found Earth First! a decade ago with four other conservationists. He said he may issue a public letter of resignation this week. Despite the leadership split, Roselle said, the fast-changing Earth First! movement retains a ``formidable grassroots nationwide network that's intent on saving wilderness and old-growth forests. That's been our priority and will remain so.''

DOC.HEAD: War Of Wills in Persian Gulf as Quarantine Clamps Oil Flow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with New York Times report on transfer of confiscated Kuwaiti gold, currency to Baghdad. Picks up 4th pvs, `Fitzwater said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM2,NY33,NY101
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf war of wills settled into one of economic attrition Monday as an Iraqi oil tanker was unable to dock or load at a Saudi Arabian port. A barricade of U.S. warships stood ready to block all trade with Iraq. ``The purpose of the embargo is to put the pinch on them'' so the Iraqis cannot ``maintain their war machine,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``You don't give them the essentials that enable them to carry on the war,'' Fitzwater said. He said the embargo covers food imports as well as military supplies and other goods. An international quarantine was imposed against Iraq for its lightning conquest of Kuwait and its massing of troops near Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest oil reserves. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein launched the Aug. 2 blitzkrieg in a dispute over oil, land and money. The New York Times in Tuesday's editions reported Iraq had transferred $3 billion to $4 billion in confiscated gold bullion, currency and goods from Kuwaiti institutions to Baghdad, sizeably increasing its financial reserves. The paper quoted Arab bankers in London and the gulf in its report. Fitzwater said the naval barricade against Iraq had forced two or three ships to turn back at sea, and ``the embargo is being maintained'' on shipping into and out of Iraq. Pakistan voted to send troops Monday to help defend Saudi Arabia, joining ground forces from the United States, Egypt, Morocco and Syria. Squadrons of warplanes and a multinational armada, joined Monday by warships from Belgium and the Netherlands, have also massed in the region since the invasion. ``I think our position grows stronger with each day that goes by,'' said Maj. Gen. Don L. Kaufman, chief of the U.S. military training mission to Saudi Arabia. He said planes ferrying U.S. troops and equipment were landing every 10 minutes or so at a base in the desert. Saddam called for a ``holy war'' against the Saudi royalty and Western forces now gathering. Over the weekend, he asked Iraqis to cut their meat consumption by half and refrain from hoarding food. Black marketeers will be executed, he warned. The Iraqi tanker al-Qaddisiyah, which can hold 900,000 barrels of oil, was prevented from docking at the Saudi terminal at Yanbu on the Red Sea because tugs necessary to guide ships did not appear, according to Saudi diplomatic sources who spoke on the condition of anonymity. If tankers cannot load, it cuts off, in effect, Iraq's last major oil export outlet _ a pipeline across the Arabian peninsula from Iraq. Turkey closed two pipelines carrying Iraqi oil last week. However, a smaller Iraqi pipeline to Jordan was reported operating normally Monday. Earlier, two other tankers voluntarily joined the boycott. Ships from Norway and India were scheduled to fill up at the Yanbu terminal, but the customers did not show up after the U.N. resolution. Also, the Iraqi oil tanker Tarik ibn Ziyad was denied access to a Portuguese repair yard and cruised toward international waters, officials said in Lisbon. The work was contracted before the crisis, but Portugal said it would violate a trade embargo. Economic sanctions against Iraq were imposed by the United Nations and endorsed by 12 members of the Arab League. Besides the pipeline, normal road transport was reported continuing between Iraq and Jordan, a friendly neighbor on Iraq's western border. Jordan's main exports to Iraq are agricultural. Iraq is heavily dependent on oil exports to buy food _ it imports about three-quarters of its basic foodstuffs _ and supplies for its 17 million people. An international quarantine is designed to hurt Iraq economically and force it to withdraw from Kuwait. In an Associated Press poll, 64 percent of the Americans contacted supported Bush's decision to commit U.S. troops to protect Saudi Arabia. However, 86 percent said oil companies were taking advantage of the situation when they raised gasoline prices, and 52 percent said they believe the gulf crisis is likely to create real oil shortages and long lines at service stations. Meanwhile, the Japanese Trade Ministry made some belt-tightening proposals to save oil. It asked that office thermostats be set no lower than 82 degrees and that lighting be reduced by one-third. About 70 percent of the country's oil comes from the Middle East. President Bush said the U.S. Navy would halt Iraqi tankers to ``stop the oil from coming out.'' Britain and Australia also said they would help interdict Iraqi ships. The United States said such action is authorized by the U.N. vote condemning Iraq's invasion, but referred to it as an interdiction rather than a blockade, which is a word used in time of war. Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Maine, will return to Washington Tuesday for two days of talks on the gulf crisis and the U.S. budget deficit. In a related development, Bush ordered Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to fly to Saudi Arabia on Friday and meet with the kingdom's leaders, the Pentagon said Monday. It will be his second trip to the region since the invasion and followup blockade. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Monday only the Security Council has the right to impose a blockade. The Security Council is awaiting a report from a special committee about compliance with the embargo before deciding whether to call for a blockade to enforce the embargo. Both the U.N. embargo and the U.S. quarantine include all foodstuffs and grain shipments, except in cases of distress and humanitarian aid, U.N. and U.S. officials at the United Nations emphasized on Monday, speaking on condition of anonymity. In Jordan, border officials said 30 Soviets and four Germans crossed from Iraq after an overland journey through the desert. Up to 3,100 Americans are among the foreigners trapped inside Iraq and Kuwait. The State Department said Monday about 500 Americans quietly slipped out of Kuwait after the Iraqi conquest, lowering to 2,500 the official estimate of Americans still there. Up to 600 Americans remain stranded in Iraq. A trickle of American diplomatic personnel was allowed to leave Iraq but ``it does not appear that any non-official citizens are being allowed to leave,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Yemen on Monday backed Saddam's peace initiative that linked a settlement of the gulf crisis to Israel's withdrawal from Arab territories occupied in the 1967 war. Israel and the United States rejected the idea. Tehran TV, monitored in Cyprus, said Iranian leaders on Monday rejected Saddam's proposal linking a settlement of the crisis in part with resolution of a border dispute with Iran. Thousands marched in pro-Saddam rallies in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and celebrated him as a national hero who would deliver by force what diplomacy failed to achieve. Several thousand Sudanese marched Monday through Khartoum in support of Saddam and demanded the withdrawal of foreign troops from Arab lands. The demonstrators marched to the American Embassy where they chanted ``Down, down U.S.A., go away C.I.A.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenwich Residents Speak Out About Signs
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 people showed up at a public hearing Monday night to support a millionaire who spray paints real estate signs and to tell town officials they want all such signs eliminated. Rene Anselmo, who was charged last month for spray-painting a real estate sign, drew cheers and applause as he told town residents the signs are unsightly and should be banned. ``The fault is with the town for 90 percent of this pollution,'' Anselmo said, referring to the signs. The signs are just the ``tip of the iceberg'' in the destruction of the town's pristine landscape, he said. ``They (Greenwich residents) didn't move here to live in a sea of signs,'' he said, drawing loud applause. He cited chain link fences as another aesthetic problem troubling this elite suburb of New York City. He also recently offered to replace, at his expense, metal highway signs with more attractive, wooden ones. The town's Board of Selectmen called Monday's public meeting after the recent outcry over Anselmo's arrest on July 3. The 64-year-old owner of a television satellite company became an instant folk hero when he obliterated a real estate sign with spray paint and was charged with third-degree criminal mischief in the incident. Out of dozens of speakers, only one supported of signs. Benjamin Rowe of Preferred Properties said Anselmo had painted one of his signs. ``Mr. Anselmo is probably a saint to everybody, but I'm the guy who's had his sign painted on, so I don't love him,'' Rowe said. At that point, someone in the crowd yelled, ``Take up a collection.'' The town's zoning regulations say homeowners can place signs on their land, but cannot place them on town-owned property, which is the land adjacent to the road. Anselmo, who has lived in town for 23 years, last year donated $40,000 to the town to plant trees and pays annually for the planting of flowers on town property. After his arrest, Anselmo submitted to the town's zoning enforcement officer a list of 127 signs he deemed offensive. He has pleaded innocent and a trial in the case is set for Aug. 24 in Stamford Superior Court. The charge carries a maximum penalty of a $1,000 fine and six months in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Aug. 6-13:
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Journalists Travel to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. journalists left aboard an Air Force cargo plane Aug. 12 for Saudi Arabia to join American troops. Before leaving the United States, they were briefed by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. Central Command, at MacDill Air Force Base near Tampa, Fla. Journalists had protested to the Pentagon that U.S. troops arrived in Saudi Arabia without American reporters allowed into the country to cover their activities. Defense Department officials had promised to work on the matter. Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, then moved toward that country's border with Saudi Arabia. On Aug. 7, the United States dispatched troops to Saudi Arabia to defend the oil-rich kingdom against a possible Iraqi incursion. But no pool of American news reporters was organized to accompany the American forces to view the situation first-hand. U.S. officials said Saudi officials established the ground rules that kept U.S. journalists out of the kingdom. When U.S. forces invaded Panama last December, a small group of American journalists accompanied the troops. The reporters were selected in advance by their employers and pledged to keep their movement secret to protect the security of the military operation. But journalists complained that the Pentagon pool did not work in Panama, where reporters were kept away from the action. The arrangement was set up after the U.S. invasion of Grenada, when journalists were kept away from the Caribbean nation entirely. Journalists from The Associated Press, Reuters, United Press International, Scripps-Howard News Service, Cable News Network, National Public Radio, the Milwaukee Journal, the Los Angeles Times and Time Magazine are in the pool.
DOC.HEAD: Middle East Crisis Boosts Network News Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Public interest in the Middle East crisis boosted the ratings for the three network evening news shows by 15 percent Aug. 6 through Aug. 8, a CBS research executive said. The 24-hour Cable News Network also said its coverage has boosted ratings, with the highest daily average recorded on Aug. 8 _ a 1.5 rating that represents 831,000 homes. It was more than double CNN's audience this quarter. That rating, based on Nielsen audience estimates, was CNN's highest since its coverage of the U.S. invasion of Panama last December, said CNN spokesman John Bianchi. ``The American public is definitely interested in the (Middle East) story,'' said David Poltrack, CBS senior vice president for research, citing preliminary overnight ratings from 24 major cities. ``CBS Evening News'' had the biggest increase, up 22 percent in overnight ratings compared with those for the same three-day period in the preceding two weeks, he said. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' and ``NBC Nightly News'' were up 16 percent and 8 percent, respectively, he said. ``It's conceivable that the three network news ratings will beat'' those of this week's prime-time programs when the week's national ratings are averaged out, ``and based on these numbers it should,'' he said. CBS anchorman Dan Rather, who cut short a vacation in France when Iraq invaded Kuwait, has been among CBS overseas staffers reporting the story, with Rather working from Jordan. NBC's Tom Brokaw and his ABC counterpart, Peter Jennings, have remained in New York to anchor their evening newscasts, but ABC ``Nightline'' anchorman Ted Koppel flew to Cairo to broadcast from there Aug. 9. Garrick Utley, co-anchorman of NBC's ``Sunday Today,'' went to Cairo to co-anchor the program from there Aug. 12.
DOC.HEAD: Iraq Jamming Voice of America, BBC Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: Voice of America and the BBC increased their Arabic-language broadcasts after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and Iraq began jamming both services. The broadcasts have been heavy on news about the invasion and international efforts to punish President Saddam Hussein. The U.S. service was trying to bypass the interruption by beaming its programs to Iraq through satellite television broadcasts. VOA Deputy Director Robert Coonrod said Iraqis can tune in if they have a satellite dish or access to one through a local TV station. Satellite transmissions, too, can be jammed. But experts say Iraq would need to jam the entire Indian Ocean satellite in order to block VOA. The English-language programs of the VOA and BBC have not been blocked, Coonrod said Aug. 7. VOA increased the number of hours it broadcasts in Arabic to the Middle East from 7{ daily to nearly 10, and replaced music programs with more news. The BBC expanded its Arabic-language broadcasts from nine to 10{ hours. ``Jamming the BBC is always the last resort of those who wish to suppress the truth _ and in a way it is a tribute to the role of the World Service at times of crisis,'' said David Witherow, deputy managing director of the BBC World Service. ``Jamming is never entirely effective and I am sure that listeners throughout the region are relying on the BBC for news,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Army Refuses Comment on Deployment at Fort
DOC.TEXT: The military clampdown on information about the deployment of troops to the Middle East is the tightest in years, say reporters staking out this sprawling army post. Fort Bragg officials answer press requests and questions in generic terms, scheduling briefings on the history, climate and culture of Saudi Arabia and bringing in army chemical weapons experts. But they refuse to comment on any activity regarding deployment of 82nd Airborne troops to the Middle East, leaving the news media to sift through rumors. Michael Rouse, executive editor of The Fayetteville Observer-Times, said he respected the military silence. He attributed the tense security position to ``irresponsible acts of the media.'' ``Some of these people (from outside this area) do something really stupid like film troops when they're getting ready to move out when nothing has been announced,'' he said. ``That doesn't add a damn thing to any of us getting anything.'' But Tom Lawrence, a reporter for Raleigh television station WRAL, said the military differentiates between the general public and reporters. ``Civilians with a home camcorder could drive through the base and shoot anything,'' Lawrence said. ``On the other hand, the news media can't. ``Unless a declaration of war does exist I think the public does have a right to know what's going on.''
DOC.HEAD: Western Reporters Detained and Beaten
DOC.TEXT: Three Western news agency reporters were detained and beaten by government soldiers who threatened to shoot them as spies after they crossed through rebel lines Aug. 12. Among the reporters was Michael Goldsmith, 68, of The Associated Press. The incident happened as government soldiers attacked rebels trying to take an airport. Reports said at least 18 civilians were killed in the fighting. The reporters were detained by government troops after they had crossed on foot through rebel lines into government-controlled territory in the center of Monrovia. Besides Goldsmith, those detained were Michael Roddy of Reuters and Mark Huband, a free-lance writer for United Press International and The Guardian of London. Soldiers seized watches, wallets and other valuables from the journalists. Some of the items were later returned by senior officers, but others vanished. Soldiers ripped the shirts off the reporters and forced them to walk shoeless to the presidential mansion. On the way, they were slapped, punched and threatened with rifle butts. Senior officers of President Samuel Doe's army later apologized for the troops' behavior. ``You have to understand they're very nervous,'' said Lt. Col. Moses Thomas. The journalists later made their way back across rebel lines without incident.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Organization for Journalism Programs at Black Colleges
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-nine historically black colleges and universities agreed Aug. 10 to form an association of journalism and mass communication programs. Orlando J. Taylor, dean of the School of Communications at Howard University in Washington, said the group will be called the Association of Black College Journalism and Mass Communication Programs. The new organization ``represents a historic effort to ensure that the voices of black colleges and universities will be heard in journalism and mass communication education and in the media professions,'' he said. The association is designed to help journalism programs gain accreditation, and increase the hiring of black journalists and other media professionals. ``This association wants to destroy the myth that there are no qualified black media professionals,'' Taylor said. Taylor, chairman of the new group's planning committee, said large U.S. corporations and major foundations will be asked for donations. Taylor said the organization plans ``an intensive study of the nature, scope and status of all journalism and mass communication programs at the nation's 117 historically black colleges, to be accomplished in the coming year, in order to provide the data base for enhancing these programs.'' The new organization was formed during the convention of the Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication. Other members of the group's planning committee are Elayne Hayes-Anthony of Jackson State University, Harry Amana of Clark-Atlanta University, Dianne Cherry of Hampton University and Clarice Lowe of Texas Southern University.
DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules Against Houston Chronicle in Transcript Case
DOC.TEXT: The Houston Chronicle says it will appeal a state appeals court ruling blocking it from seeing the college transcripts of local school administrators. A three-judge panel of the 1st Court of Appeals held unanimously Aug. 9 that an amendment to the state Open Records statute exempts the transcripts from public scrutiny. The amendment was enacted at the request of the Houston Independent School District. That request came after the Chronicle asked to see the records and after the state attorney general and a district court had agreed they were public record. ``The aspect of this litigation that continues to be distressing is the extent and the public expense to which the district goes in order to operate in secret,'' said Chronicle Managing Editor Tony Pederson. HISD Superintendent Joan Raymond declined comment. The Chronicle request stemmed from an investigation that showed that at least 25 high-ranking school officials had obtained worthless college degrees by mail.
DOC.HEAD: Court Justice Bars Access to TV Videotape
DOC.TEXT: A state Supreme Court justice on Aug. 9 stalled an attempt by prosecutors to force a television station to hand over portions of an interview tape with a crime suspect that were not broadcast. Kevin E. Gendron was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading no contest to a charge he improperly dumped more than 200 containers of paints and thinners. Gendron called WJAR-TV and gave an interview before surrendering to authorities. Superior Court Judge Anthony A. Giannini ruled earlier that the Rhode Island reporters' shield law did not apply to broadcast portions of the videotaped interview that were not broadcast. The judge said WJAR could not claim confidentiality because Gendron had invited the interview. Of more concern to news executives, however, was Giannini's broader ruling that even if there had been confidentiality concerns, parts of the shield law that kept such materials from grand juries were unconstitutional. Prosecutors have said the videotape is needed for a grand jury investigation. Justice Donald Shea delayed enforcement of Giannini's order until the supreme court decides whether to hear the station's appeal. Shea's order provided no comment on the merits of the case. Larry Price, the station's news director, said he was encouraged by Shea's order ``because it would seem to indicate some interest in the Supreme Court in hearing the appeal. So we're optimistic we'll have some opportunity to salvage the shield law.''
DOC.HEAD: Councilors Criticize Newspaper for Vendor Flyers
DOC.TEXT: Two city councilors blasted The New Mexican newspaper for handing out flyers urging motorists buying papers from street vendors to support a fight to keep the vendors. The city's Public Safety Committee on Aug. 6 adopted a recommendation by the city attorney to bar vendors from Santa Fe streets because of liability concerns. The New Mexican, the only Santa Fe newspaper that uses vendors, contends street sales are not a traffic hazard and that a ban would serve only to put the vendors, many of whom are homeless, out of work. On Aug. 8 vendors distributed flyers headed, ``Help us save our jobs,'' and listing the home and work telephone numbers of Mayor Sam Pick, City Manager Suzanne Huebner and the eight city councilors. But Councilor Peso Chavez told a council meeting that night that it's ``not professional for a reputable newspaper to publish something without giving the public all the facts.'' Chavez said it was never the intent to do away with anyone's job, adding, ``If it's The New Mexican's job to be humanitarian, they should find these people jobs inside.'' And Councilor Ouida MacGregor, who said she had been leaning in favor of the vendors until she saw the flyers, said the newspaper ``knew better (than) to give people the scare that their jobs would disappear.'' A secretary in the mayor's office said about 125 calls were logged by mid-afternoon, most in support of the vendors. The flyers also suggested people who could not reach their councilor attend the council meeting to speak on the issue, but only one man spoke. The council took no action on the issue in the Aug. 8 meeting.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Verdict in Washington Mayor's Trial Prompts Extra Newspaper Coverage
DOC.TEXT: The outcome of Mayor Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial was big enough news in the nation's capital that it prompted one of the city's two daily newspapers to publish its second-ever extra edition. The Aug. 11 Washington Times extra also was the 8-year-old newspaper's first weekend edition. The Times is usually published Monday through Friday, while the more widely distributed Washington Post is printed seven days a week. Barry was convicted Aug. 10 of a single cocaine possession offense after a 10-week trial that featured a videotape showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine during an FBI sting operation. Linda Clark, spokeswoman for the Times, said the extra edition was sold in downtown Washington and in newsstands and racks on the street. She said the paper also was being distributed in some suburban areas. The Times published its first extra edition after Barry's arrest.
DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Examiner Editorial Calls for Legalizing Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco Examiner, in one of the first pro-legalization editorials by a big-city newspaper, said Aug. 12 that the sale and use of drugs should be made legal in the United States. An editorial called the federal war against drugs ``a colossal waste of effort, money and human resources.'' ``All anti-drug laws should be repealed,'' it said. ``The war on drugs should be called off. Just declare victory, play `76 Trombones' and march out. It always gets applause.'' The newspaper noted that the federal government recently finished a much-publicized sweep against marijuana plantations in Humboldt County, about 200 miles north of San Francisco. The operation was termed a success by federal officials, the Examiner noted, although the 1,400 marijuana plants destroyed was ``not enough to put a dent in the supply of marijuana.'' ``Any way you slice it, there is no denying that this politician-declared war has been just about effective as the war on poverty, the war on crime and the war on cancer put together, which is to say, a complete defeat,'' the editorial said. ``The time has come to legalize the sale and use of drugs. Treat them all like alcohol, which is legal though its sale is subject to controls.''
DOC.HEAD: State Ordered To Dissolve Board of Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Aug. 11 directed the state to dissolve a board of inquiry it convened to investigate a contract dispute between the Daily News and 10 labor unions. U.S. District Judge Kenneth Conboy, in granting the newspaper's motion for a preliminary injunction, agreed it would be ``irreparably harmed'' if the state fact-finding panel proceeded with its investigation. An inquiry by the board would destroy ``any atmosphere of frank and open discussions'' and could force the News ``to divulge confidential or proprietary information,'' the judge wrote. The decision also said the newspaper was likely to succeed in its argument that state labor law, which provides for the establishment of such a panel, is pre-empted by the National Labor Relations Act. Daily News spokeswoman Virginia Woo said the newspaper does not comment on ongoing litigation. State Labor Commissioner Thomas Hartnett formed the three-member board in July to look into the labor talks at the News. The panel has the power to issue subpoenas and take sworn testimony, but cannot mandate a settlement. The News and its unions have een negotiating for six months. Their contracts expired March 30.
DOC.HEAD: Two Newspapers Pull Doonesbury Strips
DOC.TEXT: A set of ``Doonesbury'' comics containing suggestive language and showing a woman wearing nothing but rope and a bucket is in poor taste, say two newspaper editors who pulled the strips. ``If we had been running it on the op-ed page, we probably would have thought differently about it,'' said Phil Record, associate executive editor of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram. ``But we just did not think this was suitable on a page we try to draw kids to.'' The newspaper said Aug. 6 it was not publishing ``Doonesbury'' strips that week and notified readers they could pick up copies at newspaper offices. The Republic in Columbus, Ind., also decided to drop the strips. The newspaper planned to run old ``Doonesbury'' comics instead, Editor John Harmon said. ``It just didn't meet our guidelines for taste,'' he said. ``If our photographers came back with something like that, we wouldn't run it.'' The Baton Rouge (La.) State-Times and Morning Advocate decided to run the strip opposite the editorial page rather than on the comics page. ``It contains language and art that I would be very reluctant to invite children to look at,'' said Jim Hughes, executive editor. ``And children read the comics page.'' The strip by Garry Trudeau apparently referred to the controversy over National Endowment of the Arts funding. Some politicians have tried to block government money going to art they consider obscene, and some artists have lost grants. In the Aug. 6 strip, the character J.J. tells her husband she has a new concept for performance art so innovative that the NEA will have to reconsider her grant application. She is covered only by a strategically placed rope and her hand, and she has a bucket over her head. In strips for later in the week, J.J. utters words such as ``ooze,'' ``lubricate'' and ``hot juices,'' although she makes no direct reference to sex acts. Lee Salem, editorial director at the strip's distributor, Universal Press Syndicate, said only about eight to 10 newspapers called with concerns. The Kansas City company distributes the strip to about 1,000 newspapers.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Washington Magazine Folds
DOC.TEXT: Washington magazine has ceased publication and sold its subscriber list to rival monthly Pacific Northwest after an overhaul failed to increase circulation and advertising. Washington owner Robert Best was not responding to inquiries, employees in his office said Aug. 7, four days after the move was announced. Washington publisher Ilene Briggin said the September issue was ready to go to press when the plug was pulled. Pacific Northwest magazine publisher Alan Humason said the purchase would add 40,000 subscribers for a total of more than 100,000.
DOC.HEAD: Radio Station Halts Coverage of Festival
DOC.TEXT: A radio station pulled the plug on coverage of a festival at an Indian reserve after one of its reporters said she was told to soften her reports. CKNW reporter Laura Ballance said a volunteer at the Stein Festival on Aug. 4 told her to do a positive story if she wanted to stay on the site at the Tsawwassen Indian reserve south of Vancouver. ``It's just not acceptable to be told what slant to put on a story,'' Ballance said. News director Warren Barker told listeners on the noon newscast that the station had canceled further coverage of the festival, a joint production of Indian bands and environmentalists to help preserve the Stein Valley north of Vancouver from logging. More than 15,000 people turned out Aug. 5 for the festival. ``We are not trying to influence coverage,'' said festival co-ordinator Don McCandless. ``This festival is all about free speech.'' Ballance also objected to signing a waiver that urged ``a gentle approach'' to media coverage. McCandless said the waiver merely meant reporters should use discretion when conducting interviews. ``If any media has any difficulty with the waiver we're prepared to rip it up,'' he added. Other media outlets said the waiver was no problem. ``They're assisting us rather than hindering us,'' said Margo Harper, a producer for British Columbia Television. The festival, first staged in 1985, mixes native, pop and country performers with speeches and panels on environmental and native issues.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reporter Secretly Taped Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A reporter for the Vancouver Province newspaper, forced to testify in a drug trial, acknowledged he secretly taped a meeting he had with a defense lawyer. ``You did not ask me if I was taping the meeting,'' reporter Greg Middleton testified Aug. 9 when asked by lawyer Ken Young about their May 3 meeting. ``I tape-recorded that conversation at the request of my editors,'' said Middleton. He later turned over a cassette recording of the meeting as an exhibit. Young is one of several lawyers defending seven people charged with conspiracy to import and traffic in cocaine. The defense is trying to get the drug charges thrown out on the basis that the accused's right to a fair trial has been prejudiced by news media coverage.
DOC.HEAD: Concern Over Attacks on Press in Turkey and Namibia
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said Aug. 8 it was ``extremely concerned'' at the arrest of a newspaper editor in Turkey and the firebombing of a newspaper's offices in Namibia. The institute sent a message to Turkish President Turgut Ozal calling for the ``immediate and unconditional release'' of Dogu Perincek, editor of the newspaper Yozol. Perincek was arrested Aug. 6 in Diyarbakir, eastern Turkey, ``apparently because he had spoken out against current government repression in the southeastern region of Turkey,'' the message said. The institute said it was ``distressed'' to learn of a fire bomb attack last week on The Namibian newspaper in Windhoek. ``We understand that white right-wing extremists are thought to be behind the bombing,'' the institute said in a message to Prime Minister Hage Geingob. It hoped those responsible would be brought to justice quickly and the newspaper compensated and given protection. The institute has offices in London and Zurich and is an independent organization of publishers and editors in some 60 countries.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NABET Union To Challenge NBC in Court
DOC.TEXT: A major union at NBC said it probably will go to court to fight the network's ``final'' offer that the company plans to put into effect Aug. 15. The decision by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians was made Aug. 9 after NBC rejected the union's bid to resume negotiations with a federal mediator present, a union spokesman said. ``NBC's position is that we've had a number of meetings over seven months and there has been ample opportunity to discuss key issues,'' said Betty Hudson, an NBC spokeswoman. ``The contract is on the table and we have no intention of modifying it.'' There will be no salary increases when NBC puts the contract into effect because union members haven't ratified it, she said. ``They'll operate under the old wage provisions until we have a ratified contract.'' NBC's previous contract with NABET expired March 31. Union members have twice rejected NBC contract offers. When NBC implements its new four-year contract, ``it appears that we'll be countering with every legal means at our disposal,'' said the union's spokesman, John Krieger. This means a court challenge of NBC's action, said Krieger, whose union says it has 2,373 members at NBC, 1,300 of them engineers. Major issues in the dispute include jurisdiction, daily hires and NBC's proposals to let outside producers rent its facilities to make new programs without union members employed by NBC. No walkout is imminent. The union's members, who struck NBC for 17 weeks in 1987, have not taken a strike vote, Krieger said. NABET members work at NBC and NBC-owned facilities here and in Burbank, Calif., Washington, Cleveland and Chicago.
DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Fund Buys Minority Stake in Radio Company
DOC.TEXT: Merchant banking funds headed by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have agreed to buy a significant minority interest in Infinity Broadcasting Corp., which owns 17 radio stations. The privately owned company announced Aug. 6 that the Merchant Banking Partnerships of Lehman Brothers agreed to buy $26.7 million in newly-issued stock and warrants from Infinity Broadcasting. In addition, the funds agreed to pay an undisclosed sum for additional stock from the founders of Infinity Broadcasting, Michael Weiner and Gerald Carrus. After the deal is completed, the partnership will own just under 50 percent of the company's stock, according to Infinity spokesman Farid Suleman. The biggest individual shareholder will be Mel Karmazin, Infinity's president and chief executive, who holds just under 20 percent. Weiner and Carrus, who will stay on as co-chairmen of the company, each will own under 10 percent of the company, Suleman said. Warrants held by bondholders and employee stock options account for most of the remainder of the company's stock. Suleman said Infinity had $107.8 million in revenue last year. Infinity owns and operates the following radio stations: WXRK-FM and WZRC-AM in New York; KROQ-FM, Los Angeles; WJMK-FM and WJJD-AM, Chicago; WYSP-FM, Philadelphia; KOME-FM, San Jose-San Francisco; WBCN-FM, Boston; WOMC-FM, Detroit, and KVIL-AM and KVIL-FM, Dallas. Also, WJFK-FM, Washington, D.C.; KXYZ-AM, Houston; WLIF-AM and WLIF-FM, Baltimore; and WQYK-AM and WQYK-FM, Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla.
DOC.HEAD: Judge To Decide on Radio Case Verdict
DOC.TEXT: A judge said he would rule the week of Aug. 13 whether to uphold a $694,204 verdict awarded to a former radio news director who sued two disc jockeys for their on-air comments about her. Attorneys for former WBZZ-FM news director Liz Randolph asked Judge John L. Musmanno to uphold the verdict against EZ Communications, which owns WBZZ-FM, and against DJs Jim Quinn and Donald ``Banana Don'' Jefferson. Earlier this year the jury said Ms. Randolph was entitled to compensation and punitive damages for intentional infliction of emotional distress, invasion of privacy and defamation. The case was based on comments and skits, which Ms. Randolph said implied she was sexually promiscuous, had sexually transmitted diseases and was seeing a psychiatrist. Attorneys for the defendants want the judge to overturn the verdict or to grant a new trial outside of southwestern Pennsylvania. The defendants maintain the remarks were jokes. Their lawyers argued Aug. 6 that the announcers can't afford to pay the $292,000 the jury ruled they should give Ms. Randolph, who now works for KDKA radio in Pittsburgh.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Morning News Announces Newsroom Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Dallas Morning News announced 13 newsroom management changes Aug. 10, including the appointment of Bill Evans as executive managing editor. Evans will oversee news operations, said Ralph Langer, the newspaper's vice president and executive editor. The managing editor, photo director and art director also will report to Evans. Bob Mong replaces Evans as managing editor and will be responsible for the daily newspaper. Stuart Wilk has been appointed deputy managing editor with responsibility for the Metropolitan, Business and Texas & Southwest news departments. Seven assistant managing editors were also named: Walt Stallings, news desk, universal desk and page one; Kevin Merida, national and international news; Melissa Houtte, Sunday paper and daily enterprise; Vernon Smith, Discoveries section, newsroom portion of Sunday Reader, recruiting and development of new coverage areas; Lennox Samuels, High Profile, Fashion!Dallas, Dallas Life, House & Garden, Travel and Line One sections; Mark Weinberg, Today, Arts, Guide, Food and Books sections; and Howard Swindle, special projects. Don Smith, assistant to the managing editor, will take on reference and systems department responsibilities. John Davenport becomes a special assistant working with the management group. Gilbert Bailon has been named metro editor.
DOC.HEAD: Malone Named Monroe News-Star Publisher
DOC.TEXT: William T. Malone, a long-time Gannett executive, succeeded George H. Van Wagner as president and publisher of The News-Star newspaper on Aug. 10. Malone, 61, was named president and publisher of the Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock in 1986 and has been its chairman for the past year. He was named vice president-circulation for Gannett in 1980.
DOC.HEAD: Hawkins Publisher in Madisonville
DOC.TEXT: Roger Hawkins, advertising director of The Ledger of Lakeland, Fla., became publisher of the Madisonville Messenger on Aug. 9. Hawkins replaces Doug Miller, who resigned. Both properties belong to the New York Times Regional Newspaper Group.
DOC.HEAD: Waggoner Named Publisher
DOC.TEXT: LaJeune Waggoner, publisher of the Appalachian News-Express in Pikeville, Ky., became publisher of the Stanly News and Press in Albemarle, N.C., on Aug. 6. Waggoner, 58, replaces Gary R. Cunard, who resigned. The 13,000-circulation News and Press, a thrice-weekly, has plans to go daily next year, he said.
DOC.HEAD: Campbell Promoted at Oak Ridger
DOC.TEXT: Jim Campbell, managing editor of The Oak Ridger newspaper, has been promoted to editor. Campbell, 32, succeeds Joan Wallace, who resigned the post. Campbell had been managing editor since May, following two years as city editor. He was sports editor from 1983 to 1987. Wallace, who has been with the paper for about 25 years, said the time required as editor led to her decision to change posts. She will remain on the paper's staff.
DOC.HEAD: Wayne Nelson Named Editor Of Sun
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Nelson, sports editor of The Jamestown Sun, is the newspaper's new managing editor. He succeeds James Smorada, who resigned to pursue a master's degree in journalism and teach at South Dakota State University. Nelson joined the Sun in 1980 as a general assignment writer and served as city editor before becoming sports editor in 1983. He has been named Sports Writer of the Year twice by the North Dakota chapter of the National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association.
DOC.HEAD: Butters to Executive Editor in Vancouver
DOC.TEXT: Brian Butters, chief of corporate and investor public relations for Southam Inc., has been named executive editor of the Vancouver Province. Ian Haysom, the Province's editor-in-chief, said Aug. 7 that Butters will act as the morning tabloid's chief administrator and chief of staff. Neil Graham, formerly city editor, and Mike Graham, formerly news editor, were named deputy managing editors. Bob Stall moves from day assistant managing editor to columnist. Eric O'Higgins, night assistant managing editor, becomes production editor while Steve Carlman moves to associate editor from Sunday editor. In other changes, Kent Gilchrist has resigned as sports editor to write a column. No replacement has been named yet. The Province is published by Pacific Press Ltd., a division of Southam Inc.
DOC.HEAD: Davis to Fill Gannett Chair at Marshall
DOC.TEXT: Wayne M. Davis, news editor for The Associated Press in Washington, D.C., has been named to fill the Gannett chair at Marshall University's School of Journalism. Davis is on a leave of absence. He will teach reporting, writing and editing, said Harold Shaver, the journalism school's director. Davis, 39, was AP news editor in Charleston from 1980 until 1987, when he moved to Washington.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: M. Richard ``Dick'' Bradley, a sports broadcaster in Springfield for more than 30 years, died Aug. 9 of cancer. He was 62. Bradley began broadcasting Southwest Missouri State football and basketball games on radio station KICK in 1951. Survivors include his wife, two sons and two daughters.

John G. Briggs Jr., author and former opera critic for The New York Times and New York Post, died Aug. 10 after a long illness. He was 74. Briggs, who studied at Philadelphia's Curtis Institute of Music, wrote four books on opera. He wrote for the New York Post from 1940 to 1949 and for the New York Times from 1952 to 1960. In 1961, Briggs returned to Philadelphia and worked as a public relations writer before joining The Courier-Post of Cherry Hill as a business writer. Briggs worked there from 1970 until his retirement two years ago. Survivors include a daughter, a son and two sisters.

Fred Burns, former executive sports editor of The Herald-Dispatch in Huntington, died Aug. 7 after a long illness. He was 90. Burns was remembered as a champion of golf in West Virginia. He worked at The Herald-Dispatch for 41 years, retiring in 1967. In addition to writing about golf, he also served as a tournament director and a rules official.

Si Cornell, a writer for 44 years best known for a long-running column in The Cincinnati Post, died Aug. 9. He was 68. Cornell spent half of his career at the Post writing a column five times a week that combined humor and poignancy. He stopped writing his column in 1977 and left the newspaper in 1984. He also worked as a business reporter and general assignment writer. Survivors include his wife, two sons, a sister, a brother and a granddaughter.

Jimmy Glenn, longtime part-owner of radio station KDRO, died Aug. 6. He was 68. The cause of death was not disclosed. Glenn was part owner of the Sedalia station from 1957 until January, when it was sold to Mathewson Broadcasting Co. He was instrumental in forming the Missouri Sports Network, which carries University of Missouri football and basketball. Survivors include his wife and daughter.

Elizabeth S.J. Grant, publisher of The Danville Register & Bee, died Aug. 7 after suffering a heart attack at her home. She was 70. Mrs. Grant inherited The Danville Register, a morning newspaper, and The Bee, an afternoon daily, from her father, Rorer A. James Jr., in 1937 at the age of 17. Her husband, Walter L. Grant, became publisher in 1945. He died in 1972 and the two newspapers merged last year. Survivors include two sons, two daughters, one sister and two grandchildren.

ABC newsman Sam Donaldson says he pulled his punches during verbal sparring with ``PrimeTime Live'' co-anchor Diane Sawyer when the show began last year. ``I could not bring myself to slap Diane across the chops,'' he said in the Aug. 18 issue of TV Guide.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: A career military man from California who the Pentagon said was accidentally hit by a truck in Saudi Arabia has become the first American soldier to die in the U.S. buildup in the Middle East. John Campisi, a 30-year-old Air Force staff sergeant and father of four from Covina, Calif., died Sunday during troop preparations. Campisi, who had been in the military since he was 18, was assigned to Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska. ``It will be very hard on those children,'' Campisi's father, Salvatore Campisi, said. ``Anything he could do with his children he did with them.'' ``The main thing is that he was a wonderful father,'' his mother, Marge Campisi, said in a telephone interview. ``He was involved in everything with those kids _ scout leader, religious classes. He always made time for his family.''

A 40-year-old flight attendant shouldn't be forced to starve herself into her 20-year-old size, says Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, who's asking American Airlines to change its weight policy. The policy is ``outdated and wrong,'' Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said in a letter urging the Texas-based airline to scrap its weight standard. The senator said the standard appears to be biased against women, particularly older women. ``According to American's flight attendants, the standard is applied in practice almost exclusively to the female attendants. Certainly it has no application whatsoever to the pilots, management or executive staff,'' Metzenbaum wrote. American Airlines President Robert Crandall has said weight standards are necessary because ``we've got some people on our airplanes that are way too heavy.''

The 50th Black Hills Motor Classic, which lured 300,000 bikers to this town of 7,000, had everything people here had come to expect from a motorcycle rally: choppers, tattoos, leather _ and violence. Eleven people died, one man was shot and two others were stabbed in a bar brawl between motorcycle gangs, and hundreds were arrested during the weeklong event. ``As I've said before, the potential is there,'' said Sheriff Floyd Cleland. ``These people all drink booze, take drugs and carry knives and guns.'' Law officers shot to death a knife-wielding Australian who charged them, and another person died of carbon monoxide poisoning in a tent. The nine other deaths came in crashes.

The Middle East crisis helped drive up gasoline prices at the pump by more than a dime a gallon over the last three weeks, an oil analyst says. The nationwide Lundberg Survey of about 13,000 stations found the average price for all grades of gasoline, including taxes, was $1.27.94 a gallon on Friday, up 10.2 cents from July 20. Analyst Trilby Lundberg on Sunday said that U.S. oil companies have been forced to pay inflated prices for oil and gasoline on the short-term spot market to meet consumer demand during the summer driving months. ``The refiners are more susceptible to what's happening in the Middle East now than at any other time,'' she said.

One of the Magellan spacecraft's backup computers rejected commands when a memory chip failed, but the glitch won't hurt the $744 million exploration of Venus, engineers say. ``It's like a stuck traffic light. It's not allowing the proper flow of commands,'' said Tommy Thompson, Magellan science manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``The spacecraft is healthy except for this little problem, and we can work around it,'' he added. ``Every indication is this will have no effect on our operations.'' Launched from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, Magellan is on a mission to use radar to penetrate Venus' thick clouds and make the best pictures and maps yet of the planet's rugged landscape. The spacecraft went into orbit around Venus on Friday after a roundabout, 948-million-mile voyage to the second planet from the sun.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, August 20th, the 232nd day of 1990. There are 133 days left in the year.
Fifty years ago, on Aug. 20, 1940, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill paid tribute to the Royal Air Force, saying, ``Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.'' On this date: In 1833, Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, was born in North Bend, Ohio. In 1866, President Andrew Johnson formally declared the Civil War over, even though fighting had stopped months earlier. In 1914, German forces occupied Brussels, Belgium, during World War I. In 1918, Britain opened its offensive on the Western front during World War One. In 1920, America's first commercial radio station, 8MK in Detroit (later WWJ), began daily broadcasting. In 1948, the United States ordered the expulsion of Jacob Lomakin, the Soviet Consul General in New York, accusing him of attempting to force the return of two consular employees to the Soviet Union against their will. In 1953, the Soviet Union publicly acknowledged it had conducted a test detonation of a hydrogen bomb. In 1955, hundreds of people were killed in anti-French rioting in Morocco and Algeria. In 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed a nearly $1 billion anti-poverty measure. In 1968, the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact nations began invading Czechoslovakia to crush the ``Prague Spring'' liberalization drive of Alexander Dubcek's regime. In 1977, the U.S. launched Voyager 2, an unmanned spacecraft carrying a 12-inch copper phonograph record containing greetings in dozens of languages, samples of music and sounds of nature. In 1979, swimmer Diana Nyad succeeded in her third attempt at swimming from the Bahamas to Florida, arriving at Juno Beach 27 hours and 38 minutes after leaving North Bimini. In 1986, mail carrier Patrick Henry Sherrill went on a deadly rampage at a post office in Edmond, Okla., shooting 14 fellow workers to death before killing himself. Ten years ago: The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 _ with the United States abstaining _ to censure Israel for declaring that all of Jerusalem was its capital. Five years ago: The Reverend Jerry Falwell, returning to the U.S. from a five-day tour of South Africa, called Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu a ``phony'' for presuming to speak on behalf of South African blacks. One year ago: British conservationist George Adamson, 83, was shot and killed by bandits near his camp in Kenya. Today's Birthdays: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, is 57. Singer-musician Isaac Hayes is 48. The former prime minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi, is 46. CBS newscaster Connie Chung is 44. Thought for Today: ``If a thing is absolutely true, how can it not also be a lie? An absolute must contain its opposite.'' _ Charlotte Painter, American writer and educator (1926- ).

DOC.NOTE: $Adv23
For Release Thursday, Aug. 23
Eds: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT date to Aug. 23 sted of Aug.21
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, Aug. 23, the 235th day of 1989. There are 130 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Aug. 23, 1927, Italian-born anarchists Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were executed in Boston for the murders of two men during a 1920 payroll robbery in a case that had drawn widespread controversy. (In 1977, Sacco and Vanzetti were vindicated by Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who declared that ``any stigma and disgrace should be forever removed'' from their names.) On this date: In 1754, France's King Louis XVI was born at Versailles. In 1785, U.S. naval hero Oliver Hazard Perry was born in South Kingstown, R.I. In 1838, one of the first colleges for women, Mount Holyoke Female Seminary in South Hadley, Mass., graduated its first students. In 1914, Japan declared war on Germany in World War I. In 1926, silent film star Rudolph Valentino died in New York at age 31. In 1939, Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union signed a non-aggression treaty. In 1944, Romanian prime minister Ion Antonescu was overthrown, paving the way for his country to abandon the Axis in favor of the Allies. In 1947, an audience at the Hollywood Bowl heard President Truman's daughter, Margaret, give her first public concert as a singer. In 1960, Broadway librettist Oscar Hammerstein II died in Doylestown, Penn. In 1972, the Republican national convention, meeting in Miami Beach, Fla., nominated Vice President Spiro T. Agnew for a second term. In 1979, Soviet dancer Alexander Godunov defected while the Bolshoi Ballet was on tour in New York. Ten years ago: In a reversal, the Communist government of Poland agreed to negotiate directly with representatives of striking workers. Five years ago: The Reverend Jerry Falwell said his statement calling South African Bishop Desmond Tutu a ``phony'' was a poor choice of words. But Falwell said he still believed Tutu did not speak for the majority of black South Africans. One year ago: In a case that inflamed racial tensions in New York, Yusuf Hawkins, a 16-year-old black youth, was shot to death after he and his friends were confronted by a gang of white youths in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Today's Birthdays: Actor-dancer Gene Kelly is 78. Orchestra leader Bob Crosby is 77. Actress Vera Miles is 60. Political satirist Mark Russell is 58. Senator Pete Wilson, R-Calif., is 57. Actress Barbara Eden is 56. Ballet dancer Patricia McBride is 48. Actress Shelley Long is 41. Actor-singer Rick Springfield is 41. Queen Noor of Jordan is 39. Thought for Today: ``I never learned hate at home, or shame. I had to go to school for that.'' _ Dick Gregory, American comedian-activist (1932- ).

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP on TV-Women and Men, Adv14, 1st Ld-Writethru,0754

For release Tues PMs, Aug 14, and thereafter
