Star Watch: Mel Gibson Enjoyed Exotic Film Location
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Many film stars return from far-off locations with tales of peril and privation. Now listen to Mel Gibson, who spent three months in the mountainous jungles near the poppy fields of the Golden Triangle of Southeast Asia: ``It's a neat place, you know. It's not so unpleasant. The food is great; it's hard to get a bad feed there. The dogs are a little mangy; you gotta watch out for rabies and stuff_ don't walk around at night. The people are absolutely charming. The culture is old and rich and amazingly simple.'' Gibson went to Thailand for the filming of ``Air America,'' a Tri-Star Pictures action-adventure about CIA operations in Laos during the Vietnam War. It looks like a physically strenuous shoot, but you won't hear any complaint on that score, either. ``It wasn't too bad,'' says Gibson. ``I think the most strenuous thing I did was cut out of the picture. So it isn't worth talking about.'' The star's good feelings may partly be due to his reported salary of $8 million, plus a cut of the profits. Beyond that, Mel maintains a cheerful attitude about the good fortune that has befallen him during his unexpected movie career. That makes him unique amid a new generation of actors who seem to suffer under the pressures of stardom. Air America was the name of the CIA's secret airline that operated in Southeast Asia from the late 1960s to the mid-1970s. The film is partly based on the book by Christopher Robbins, who wrote that the CIA ``maintained a secret mercenary army in Laos.'' The cargo included refugees, ammunition, counterfeit money as well as bushels of opium transported for local war lords, said Robbins. Gibson and Robert Downey Jr. are among the ragtag group of pilots flying the rugged terrain. To ease into the role, Gibson took lessons in helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft ``so I could at least know what to do, what it felt like. I enjoyed it. There's a safer feeling when you can understand it more.'' Until he read the script, Gibson was unaware of the secret operations in Laos. ``The picture tells about it in a primer fashion, and it's informative. But I don't think most Americans did know about it.'' He observed, incidentally, that the head of the CIA at that time was _ George Bush. ``Anyway,'' he added quickly, ``I'm not on a witch hunt.'' After appearing in high-energy films like the ``Mad Max'' cycle and the two ``Lethal Weapons,'' Mel Gibson surprised everyone by taking on the title role in Franco Zefferelli's ``Hamlet.'' Mel Gibson as the gloomy Dane? Is something off-kilter in Denmark? ``I liked the story, it's a great story,'' he explained. ``It's a very tragic story: it's all about bad timing. Why do it? Why not do it, because it was sitting there for the taking and it was offered to me on nothing less than a silver plate? I couldn't see any reason not to.'' He added that he had done Shakespeare as a young actor in Australia, ``but on the stage; he didn't write for the screen, did he? That's why it's a little tricky for celluloid. It's only two hours instead of four and a half.'' Gibson, who costars with Glenn Close, said Zefferelli fixed on a ``standard English sound'' for the actors: ``It required a kind of uniformity, since you couldn't have a Utah cowboy amid the likes of Alan Bates, Paul Scofield and Ian Holm, pretty good actors who know their Shakespeare.'' Mel Gibson's dual nationality, along with his good looks, contribute to the immense popularity he now enjoys after a dozen films. He spent his first 12 years in upstate New York, then moved with his large family _ he was sixth among 11 children _ to Sydney. After his graduation from the National Institute of Dramatic Arts, he was picked by director George Miller to play ``Mad Max.'' His first international films _ ``The Bounty,'' ``The River,'' ``Mrs. Soffel''_ were unsuccessful, but Gibson made his box-office mark with ``Lethal Weapon.'' Now his choice of projects is unlimited. A devout Catholic, Gibson, 34, strives to maintain a balance between career and family; he and his wife now have six children, including 7-year-old twins. He tries to take them all along wherever he works. ``We had to suspend that because of the `Air America' location,'' he said. ``I didn't want to risk going through all that business of inoculations and kids in the jungle and talk about the snakes. ``Geography and time permitting, they go to school wherever we are. There's a sense of semi-permanence about their education, but they're getting one. Cultural shock? They get a cultural smorgasbord, and that can't be bad. ``It's rounded and educational for everyone.'' The Gibsons now have a base here, but their principal home remains an Australian cattle ranch. Mel wants it known that he is no mere gentleman rancher. ``It's all happening there: genetics, embryo transfers, cryogenic tanks with liquid oxygen, embryos shipped from above the 45th parallel, because of the disease problem below the 45th,'' he said. ``Then there's the genetic part at the end: what you end up with walking around on the ground. A cow with a sheep's head. No, not really. It's not genetic engineering. ``They're really nice animals. You can practically map out what you want and be sure of hitting fairly near the mark. You can do in three years what took your grandfather all his life.''

The Artists: Art Sleuths Weeding Out Masterworks From Also Rans
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. (AP) _ It's been a long, strange trip for the oil painting of the nude woman and Cupid now hanging in a Bard College gallery. The painting was found years ago in a hayloft with a modest fig leaf painted on Cupid and the chubby, prone woman's breasts enlarged. A private collector bought the painting, removed the bogus overpainting and cleaned it over three years. The collector, who refuses to reveal his identity, says he's convinced the painting was created in a Venice studio by Titian, one of the greatest painters of the Italian Renaissance. The art world isn't so sure. That puts the purported Titian in the same boat as many of the 80 works of art exhibited at ``A Connoisseur's Quest,'' a new gallery exposition at this Hudson Valley college. Paintings from Europe, carvings from Africa and ancient Egyptian pottery are coming under scrutiny for the first time as art detectives try to weed out bonafide masterpieces from artful forgeries. Art historians and others who breath the rarefied air of the art world have begun debating whether particular works are really Raphael's or Durer's or El Greco's. ``Some of these pieces will be shrouded in mystery for the rest of their existence,'' said Linda Weintraub, curator of the Edith C. Blum gallery. The exhibit, which Weintraub shepherded here, is unique in that the pieces are being shown to the public for the first time after being held in a private collection for decades _ some for up to 50 years. The collector credits Weintraub, a longtime acquaintance, with persuading him to share his private treasure with the public after all these years. His identity though, remains hidden so as not to deflect attention from the art, he said. ``The object of the collection is not the collector. The object is the art,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I'm glad to have it scrutinized.'' The scrutiny in this case means students of art looking for subtle clues that would place a work in time, or a technique that would distinguish a creation as belonging to a particular artist. The question with the picture of the nude woman and Cupid is whether the painting is a first version of Titian's ``Danae,'' which depicts the picture's namesake just after being impregnated by Zeus. Weintraub said such aficionados as former Metropolitan Museum of Art curator Thomas Hoving have applied their critical eye to the work and believe it to have come from the brush of Titian. One dissenting voice comes from artist Martin Canin who says ``the painting lacks the quality of execution'' to be a real Titian. ``I'm sure it's not,'' he said. ``There's just too many bad passages.'' Canin said his painter's eyes can see what many art historians cannot. In ``Danae,'' he sees an un-Titian-like linear approach to the work and an ``amateurish'' painting of the figures' feet and toes. Canin thinks the painting was a product of a contemporary workshop or student. A big problem with sorting out the works of the European masters is that most of them trained their young students to paint just like them _ often exactly like them. Weintraub said many students were instructed to paint over the master's sketches and even copy their work outright. ``Even pieces with signatures can easily have been done by students,'' she said. Also, in the days before photocopiers or even photos, copying the great contemporary works by hand for affluent buyers was a common practice. Unlike people who study stones or stars, art sleuths usually rely on more esoteric means to weed out masterworks from copies. Bonnie Solomon, an art restorer with Solomon & Mattozzi of New York City, shined a black light on ``Danae'' to determine if the work was fudged with overpainting. ``There was some work done on it, but not a lot,'' she said. Solomon said she's pretty sure the Titian is the real thing along with another possible masterpiece by the European master El Greco, but admitted there are some incredible fakes in existence. The presumed El Greco, a palm-sized painting of Christ at Calvary looking imploringly up to heaven, could represent the finest of the painter's work. Then again, just like the Titian, it could be the work of one of his rivals or students, or any exceptionally talented painter familiar with El Greco's work. ``This could be a student's, it could be a copy, it could be from 200 years after his death,'' Weintraub said. ``But look at his eyes. How could it be by anyone else?'' Even established works of art can become suspect. Vincent Van Gogh's ``Self-Portrait With Straw Hat'' is familiar to anyone who has ever flipped through an art book. The painting has been in the Metropolitan for years as one of the pearls in its collection. Now, a leading scholar has raised questions about its authenticity. ``There's little certainty about any work,'' Weintraub offered. Paintings for non-European works are less problematic in terms of determining the creator. Artisans kept a lower public profile in most other cultures and so works by any particular person tend to be less in demand in the art world. But they do pose other problems. ``Some of these works, we just have no idea where they're from,'' Weintraub said. Works shown in the Bard exhibit such as the Chinese Buddha and little icons of Egyptian deities are easy to trace, but others aren't. Experts agree a small, carved ivory spoon shown at Bard is from Africa. But where, when and even the why of the spoon is debatable. ``All the scholars are bewildered,'' Weintraub said. ``Even if there's a consensus, it's never absolutely known.'' Still, the mystery collector says he's relatively unconcerned that someone might soon come up with some devastating evidence his Durer or ancient Greek coins are not what they appear to be. ``I bought all the work for its visual power,'' he said. ``It wouldn't change the effectiveness of the work one bit.''

Music Makers: The Blooming of a Knucklehead Savant
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: John Hiatt is basically a sentimental kind of fellow, though you'd never guess from those Dust Bowl eyes, 5 o'clock shadow and paisley tie. But talk about rock 'n' roll heroes, Elvis Presley or Bob Dylan, and Hiatt gets a little misty-eyed, a little nostalgic. ``Isn't that cool,'' he says, his voice lifting slightly as he thinks about the days when Elvis could top the pop, country and R&B charts with just one song. And Dylan, he still remembers the summer of 1965, sitting in a car as a teen-ager when ``Like a Rolling Stone'' came on the radio, wondering if his mother would realize her son's life had changed by the time of the next commercial. Hiatt is from Indiana, and that means the heartland, with all the corny talk of family and the outdoors. Don't expect him to run for office, but this is one rocker with plenty to say about the wife and kids, and the music that sprang from ``this fair land of ours.'' ``Yeah, you surprise yourself when you find out how really traditional you really are,'' Hiatt said in an interview at the Manhattan offices of A&M Records. ``Especially when you fancy yourself kind of a wild, rebellious, angry-young-man sort of guy. ``A lot of it comes from the idea of coming from the Midwest and not having a strong cultural background, in a traditional, melting pot kind of American way. It's almost like being a blank, fill it in as you learn about it. It's kind of an adventure, booting around like a wild hedgehog.'' The jokes come easy now for Hiatt, no small achievement for a man who knows a few things about drugs and death and life on the road. ``Stolen Moments,'' the followup to his acclaimed ``Slow Turning'' album, is his happiest, most personal record, with brick houses and sleeping babies and a tall tale about a guy leaving town in the back of a pickup truck. ``A little encouragement goes a long way with me,'' he said of the response to ``Slow Turning'' and the cover version of Hiatt's ``Thing Called Love'' by Bonnie Raitt. ``I've never been so at ease with the process of record making. ``I think this record's got a kind of celebratory tone to it. I'm just kind of grooving on the fun of it. I had a wonderful time in the studio and I learned a whole bunch. I hung out for the mixes, which is something I've never done. That's a real step forward.'' On ``Stolen Moments,'' you'll learn a few things about Hiatt's father, Robert Hiatt. He was a storyteller, his son remembers, who'd gather the kids in the living room and imagine them on great adventures _ incredible adventures _ in all kinds of places. That's what ``Seven Little Indians'' is about, but as Hiatt tells it, real life was never that way. His older brother, Michael, committed suicide when Hiatt was nine. Two years later, his father died. ``In that old brick house it always felt like something was moving for the kill,'' Hiatt sings. ``They started dropping like flies.'' ``I found myself out on the road on the `Slow Turning' tour,'' Hiatt explained, ``and all of a sudden it seemed like my father was everywhere. ``I don't know why it was that way. At 35 or 36, all of a sudden these `dad' things should come up. But that happened. A lot of these things came from just riding around in the back of the bus.'' Hiatt, born in 1952, dropped out of high school and drifted. He wrote songs in Nashville, Tenn., earning $25 a week. He toured in 44 states. Made albums in every style you'd care to name. There were two bad marriages, his second wife committing suicide. He was hooked on heroin, kicked it, and got addicted to alcohol instead. ``Back of My Mind,'' a country rocker, tells how he survived, and Hiatt sounds amazed about it still, sitting back and telling his tale like a soldier spinning an old war story. It's all there _ watching his dad at the foot of the stairs, taking to the highway, ``just a lookin' and a hopin' to find some solutions, some answers,'' taking a wife, hitting the bottle and almost losing everything. But he turns it around, right in the middle of the song: ``Well the end of the tunnel, it never came up, 'til I came to the end of the line. And I saw that the light I'd had been hoping to see was just a spark in the back of my mind.'' In 1985, he joined Alcoholics Anonymous, where he met his current wife, Nancy, and cleaned himself up. Two years later, he issued ``Bring the Family,'' receiving some of his best reviews, and topped it in 1988 with ``Slow Turning.'' ``The similarity I see between myself and John Cougar Mellencamp is he seems to do his best work as he gets into his 30s,'' Hiatt said of his fellow Indiana rocker. ``I see myself as a late bloomer, though I kind of consider myself a bit of a knucklehead. My friend calls me a `knucklehead savant,' a step up from idiot savant, but not much.'' And that's how it is for a man who never expected life to turn out so well. It really is a stolen moment, he'll tell you, a time to just take in every second, when it's so much easier to think about the past because you're feeling so good about what's going to happen the following day.

Books and Authors: A Smooth Landing for John Casey
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: John Casey began writing ``Spartina'' in 1979 at the worst time of his life. One of his former students, a talented author, had committed suicide. His father died and his marriage was breaking up. The book came slowly. It started as a short story called ``The Mean Story,'' and was continously revised. The central character, Dick Pierce, was a cranky Rhode Island fisherman, about 40 years old, like the author himself. When he was finished, nearly 10 years later, Pierce was still a pretty difficult fellow, but a little more likable, a middle-aged man with a wife, two kids, a lover and an unfinished boat called ``Spartina'' in his back yard. ``People who are simply good or simply bad are harder to write about,'' Casey explained in an interview to promote ``Spartina'' which has been released in paperback by Avon Books. ``It's not the way most of us are. Most of us are pretty bad hoping to get better. Sometimes if you can just observe the process, the accidents involved in getting better, that's the real purpose of fiction. ``There's an enormous grace in nature, as well as a grace to people.'' He speaks in a voice as rough as saltwater. You can't get much further from the life of a fisherman than the tearoom of a Manhattan hotel, but Casey looks as if he just stepped off the dock, his sleeves rolled up, his hair windblown, his face reddened by the sun. The author's background seems more suitable to the yachting circuit. Casey, born in 1939, is the son of Joseph Edward Casey, a Democratic Congressman from Massachusetts in the 1930s and '40s. He wrote poetry in high school and eventually graduated from Harvard Law School. Research was unnecessary for ``Spartina.'' He started sailing as a kid, racing boats at summer camp. He and his wife then purchased a four-acre island in Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island, where Casey lived _ and fished _ for four years. ``I thought I knew something when I got to Rhode Island,'' said Casey, who has also written the novel ``An American Romance,'' and a collection of stories, ``Testimony and Demeanor.'' ``Boy, did I learn there was a lot more to it. After four years there, I learned an awful lot of stuff,'' he said. ``It was the time of my life I was most integrated into the place I lived. I had to work part time to make ends meet. I had very little money, but it didn't matter. I caught fish every day. I had a couple of lobster pots, and there were a lot of things to eat almost all year round.'' Casey writes love scenes like adventures at sea and adventures at sea like love scenes. Dick's determination to build his own fishing boat has strained relations with his wife, May, and he eventually turns to Elsie Buttrick, a free-spirited rich-kid, for support and affection. ``She took both his hands, and he floated to his feet,'' Casey writes of the moment when Dick and Elsie begin their affair. ``He bumped the corner of the table. When she touched his cheek, they were clear of the table, in the center of the room. ``She said several things but he didn't take them in. He felt weightless, but when their bones touched he felt their weight against each other, as though they were small boats at sea rising on the same swell, jostling, fendered by their flesh. ``He had one complete sting of conscience when they drifted apart for an instant. Elsie shoved aside the red curtain and they floated through.'' When Dick finally finishes his boat, he stubbornly launches Spartina despite an oncoming hurricane. He is no longer floating. With the ship being thrown in the air like a parent tossing his child, Casey describes a man staggering on deck, his only fortiication a can of Coke and a thermos of coffee: ``As he stood back up, Spartina suddenly slid forward as though she were greased. She stuck her nose into a wave. He felt her head held down, caught, then lifted up by the bow and spun sideways. He leaned against the spokes of the wheel. No effect. She fell back on her beam. He clung to the wheel post with one hand to keep from falling over. For a long moment he had no idea where she was or which way was up.'' Casey landed quite smoothly. ``Spartina'' won the National Book Award in 1989, the same year his brother-in-law, Dr. Harold E. Varmus, shared the Nobel Prize in medicine. A professor of English literature at the University of Virginia, he now lives in Charlottesville, Va., with his second wife, Pinchot Pittman, an artist and calligrapher. And ``Spartina'' is just the first novel of a trilogy, Casey promises, with other characters telling their stories and the author giving them the chance as well to show their natural grace through the worst of times. ``I knew I wanted Dick to become a better person through his troubles,'' Casey said. ``There was a flowering of him. And Elsie, too. She knows she needs to become better in some way. It's an optimistic story in a way. Both of them become better even though they've been bad.''

Nashville Sound: Carter Returns to Country
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the first phase of her career, Carlene Carter was caught in a deadening trap _ too rock 'n' roll for country radio stations, and too country for rock listeners. This daughter of one of country music's most famous families leaves no doubt where she stands now in her first album in seven years. She brought in Heartbreaker Howie Epstein, retro-rocker Dave Edmunds and former Band member Levon Helm to help her record _ an album as country as her Tennessee home. ``I just did what came naturally and felt right to me and it came out more country,'' said the 34-year-old Carter. ``I guess I've just evolved as a writer and a performer a lot more and have gotten a little older and wiser.'' For anyone familiar with Carter's rocking side, the new ``I Fell in Love'' comes as a bit of a shock. Fiddles and steel guitars abound, and Carter doesn't hide her Tennessee accent on lines such as, ``You burned me up like a chicken in a barbecue.'' Carter was more of a stranger to the country crowd during the late 1970s and early '80s. The daughter of June Carter Cash and stepdaughter of Johnny Cash moved to London for eight years, married English rock star Nick Lowe and ``was pretty wild and crazy,'' she said. Her wedding to Lowe was immortalized in the video to Lowe's hit, ``Cruel to Be Kind'' and can still occasionally be seen on late-night MTV. No video chronicled the divorce, however. Carter recorded five albums but none made her a star. ``Musical Shapes,'' with Carter backed by her husband's former band, Rockpile, was a favorite to the few who heard it and presaged country music's more extensive flirtations with rock 'n' roll. But with the 1983 release of ``C'est Ce Bon,'' a synthesizer-tinged album that even Carter disparages now, her recording career went on hiatus. She turned briefly to musical theater, performing in the London production of ``Pump Boys and Dinettes.'' ``I took a little time off and said I can't just make another album without really knowing what I wanted to do,'' she said. ``You can only get away with that for so long.'' It was a phone call from her mother that changed her career. June Carter Cash and two of Carlene's aunts were performing in London as the Carter family. One night, Carlene recalled, her Aunt Anita took sick and the Carters needed an emergency fill-in. At first, Carlene protested she didn't know the songs, but then did her family duty. She loved it. The songs she thought she didn't know were burned into her memory from family singalongs. Carlene, who learned how to play guitar and poker from her grandmother, Maybelle, soon found herself touring as a backup singer in the Carter family band. ``It's something I never thought I would want to do after having been a rebel for so long,'' she said. ``I didn't think I would want to go back and be in a group with my mom. But it was fun singing with them and fun remembering what it was like laughing and being a kid.'' She helped the Carter Family record an album, then turned to her own career. She has nothing but praise for Epstein, who took a holiday from Tom Petty's backup group to produce Carter. ``It was really his first album as a producer and I felt it was my first album as a serious participant,'' she said. On past albums, she said, ``I had my mind on so many other things I didn't really take a lot of time. My thought processes were often scattered, and it came across on record sometimes. This time I'm real focused and I think that comes across, too.'' Carter plunders her own background for songs. Cuts on the new album include the Carter Family's ``Dixie Darling,'' ``You Are the One,'' a hit for her father, Carl Smith, and ``Easy From Now On,'' one of the first songs Carter ever wrote that was once featured on an Emmylou Harris record. Carter has no regrets about her rock 'n' roll days and doesn't feel they discredited her family tradition. ``I was doing something that I believed was right at the time,'' she said. ``There's nothing written in stone that if you do one kind of music one day that you can't do another kind of music another day. I was experimenting. I was doing what they had taught me growing up to do _ to be yourself and to be comfortable with yourself.'' Her marriage to Lowe over, Carter has moved into the house in which she grew up in Madison, Tenn. The woman who once couldn't turn down a party invitation crawls into her pajamas at 11 p.m. and gets ``real excited when I see they have Spectravision in my hotel room.'' She's rehearsing with a new band for a touring show that will draw heavily from ``Musical Shapes'' and ``I Fell in Love.'' ``I'm country through and through but some people might think it's more rock 'n' roll,'' she said. ``I really don't care what they think.''

Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Colon Theater, the world-renowned opera house, is back in business after a renovation and then labor disputes kept its stage almost bare for two seasons. When the curtain belatedly went up on ``Faust'' in mid-July, moviemaker and Colon director Sergio Renan said with relief, ``It was a kind of compensation for a lot of headaches.'' The modernization of the lighting system, repair of the machine that rotates the sets, and other renovations were stretched out by Argentina's recession and inflation that nearly reached 5,000 percent in 1989. A short-lived production of ``Aida'' was performed last year in between repairs. The fall season normally begins in April. However, 1990 subscriptions initially were refunded and ``Faust'' was pushed back. As the July 19 opening date drew near, opera and dance lovers wondered if the 82-year-old theater would be ready in time. With special effects such as lightning and billowing smoke, the opera also gave the Colon a chance to show off its improvements, including a computer-controlled system to move sets up, down and sideways; quickly and quietly.

After overcoming a year of financial stress, The Philadelphia Theater Company is back and ready for the 1990-91 theater season. The Company will return to its resident home, Plays and Players Theater, to celebrate its 15th anniversary. With renewed life and continued dedication to the American playwright, the Company will offer a three-play season, showcasing the range and diversity of the American experience. The Philadelphia premiere of ``Speed-the-Plow'' by Pulitzer Prize-winner David Mamet will open the Company's 1990-91 season Oct. 12-Nov. 4. Running Nov. 16-Dec. 9, is the Philadelphia premiere of A.R. Gurney's ``The Cocktail Hour.'' The professional premiere of ``Pill Hill,'' a new play by Yale University playwright Sam Kelley is set for the last slot of the season, Jan. 25-Feb. 10.

The Pennsylvania Ballet will open its 1990-91 season with a program of American ballets. George Balanchine's ``Donizetti Variations'' and ``Western Symphony,' and the world premiere of Christopher d'Amboise's ``Franklin Court'' will make up the program opening at The Academy of Music on Sept. 12. ``Our opening program represents a move toward the future, bringing more contemporary works into our repertory, while maintaining the ballet's great tradition of classical works, particularly those of George Balanchine,'' said d'Ambroise, artistic director. The program will also include a company premiere of Jacques d'Amboise's ``Irish Fantasy,'' John Cranko's ``The Taming of the Shrew,'' Balanchine's ``The Nutcracker'' and ``Swan Lake'' by Martinez-Petipa.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market tumbled and oil prices climbed as belligerent rhetoric by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein unnerved investors and heightened fears of an oil shortage. The stock market closed the week with its worst performance since Monday as virtually all sectors except gold and oil were battered by tensions in the Middle East. Hussein's call for a ``holy war'' against Western forces and the planned dispatch of Arab troops to Saudi Arabia created fears of further disruptions of oil supplies from the Middle East, a critical source of world fuel.

The Teamsters union agreed to postpone a strike and resume negotiations with United Parcel Service of America Inc. if union members reject a proposed contract. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service asked that the company and the union go back to the bargaining table if the Teamsters rejected the new pact. The votes were being counted Friday, and Caminiti said no word was expected on the results until Monday.

Eastern Airlines announced it was raising fares by 5.3 percent because of increased jet fuel prices, while two other carriers scaled back previously announced increases to more closely match their competitors. Eastern said Friday its increased fares for domestic flights would take effect Aug. 15. Midway Airlines and Northwest Airlines reduced their previously announced increases from 10 percent to 5.3 percent, also effective Aug. 15.

Wholesale prices declined 0.1 percent in July, the government said. The report showed inflation was in check before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week sent oil costs spiraling. The seasonally adjusted decline capped a six-month stretch of virtually no change in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods. The index had risen a modest 0.2 percent in June, the department said Friday. For the first seven months of the year, wholesale prices advanced at an annual rate of 3 percent, down sharply from the 4.8 percent increase for all of last year.

Federal judges in Cleveland and Texas consolidated thousands of asbestos liability lawsuits in a first step toward resolving claims against manufacturers for worker deaths and illnesses. The joint class-action ruling was issued Friday by federal district judges Robert M. Parker of Beaumont, Texas, and Thomas D. Lambros of Cleveland following a meeting of judges to consider ways of clearing a burgeoning asbestos case backlog. More than 100,000 lawsuits are filed in state and federal courts nationwide against companies that produced asbestos, a hazardous mineral used widely for insulation.

General Motors Corp. said a strike by parts plant workers would halt several assembly lines from Michigan to Louisiana, idling nearly 15,000 workers. GM's Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Division said Friday its Buick City auto plant in Flint and its Orion Township plant in Oakland County would close at midnight Friday for lack of fuel tanks. A total of 9,500 workers would be idled, spokeswoman Julie Hamp said.

Consumers will pay an average 2.3 percent more for General Motors Corp. cars and trucks in the 1991 model year, as GM joined the other two Big Three automakers in announcing price increases. Chrysler Corp. said last week that its 1991 cars, Jeeps and minivans would cost 0.9 percent more than this year's models, while Ford Motor Co. said a week earlier that its 1991 cars would cost an average 3.2 percent more than this year's. Ford's trucks will cost 3.6 percent more. GM announced its prices Friday.

The United Auto Workers union has rejected proposals that would give workers a stake in the financially struggling Chrysler Corp. and would establish a new way to figure profit sharing. UAW Vice President Stan Marshall said Friday that a third company proposal, which would establish a multi-employer health-care trust, is still under consideration.

Chrysler Corp. was fined $7.6 million in federal court for selling about 30 previously wrecked vehicles as new cars and for odometer violations. The criminal fine handed down by U.S. District Judge John Nangle on Friday is on top of an earlier settlement of more than $16 million in a civil lawsuit. Chrysler had entered a plea of no contest to the criminal charges in December 1987.

The stock market tumbled sharply lower Friday as concerns flared up over the volatile Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 42.33 points at 2,716.58, putting its loss for the week at 93.07 points. Gold prices climbed in heavy trading after Iraq's call for an Arab holy war against Western forces in the Persian Gulf region. The dollar finished lower against most major currencies. Bond prices slumped because of oversupply concerns. In the commodities markets, petroleum futures soared; soybeans rallied strongly while wheat futures plunged; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dive, Dollar Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices nose-dived following the cancellation today of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's planned trip to the Middle East because of the Persian Gulf crisis. The dollar firmed against the Japanese yen. The dollar, normally considered a safe haven in time of international crisis, closed at 150.65 yen, up 0.90 yen from Friday. The dollar has gained 4.00 yen since Iraq's invaions of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues plummeted 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent, to 26,176.43. The index had shed 286.18 points Friday. The Nikkei, already weaker due to higher interest rates, has percent since Aug. 1, when it closed at 30,837.99. Oil prices rose to above late Friday levels in New York. North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $25.20 a barrel as of 4 p.m. local time, up from Friday's close of $23.70. Earlier in the day, the government said Kaifu postponed his trip because he was needed in Tokyo to coordinate Middle East policy. His 12-day visit, scheduled before the current crisis erupted, was to take him beginning Wednesday to Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan and Egypt. Following the announcement, the Nikkei index collapsed, traders said. The closing rate was the lowest since April 1, 1988, when the index finished at 26,104.22. ``Uncertainty prevaied, while activity was slow with only 250 million shares traded,'' said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities. Trading was light because this week is a traditional Japanese holiday.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Cancels Public Calendar of Senior Officials' Schedules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bureaucratic ooze has engulfed a popular daily calendar that for many years has informed the public where senior officials at the Agriculture Department spend their time and with whom. The daily schedules of Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and his top aides were last published on July 19. Efforts by news organizations that regularly cover USDA to have them reinstated have been denied. ``There's no requirement for us to produce a calendar such as that,'' said Kelly Shipp, director of the department's Office of Public Affairs. ``If you want to know who is meeting with whom, you're more than welcome'' to file under the Freedom of Information Act. Long before the FOIA, the creaky old department was something of a model of openness. Glasnost, which made its mark in the Kremlin, was old hat in USDA. Of course there were and are secrets. You are in peril of life and limb if an attempt is made to crack the ``lockup room'' where crop reports are prepared. And television monitors keep track of visitors hanging around the secretary's office. Speaking of which, the USDA secretary's glass-walled outer office once was shrouded from the inside by heavy drapes so passersby couldn't identify visitors by sight. The drapes came down during the Nixon years so reporters and anyone else could see inside. Sometimes you could even go into the ``bird cage'' outer office and read a magazine or two while keeping an eye out for agricultural celebrities. But gradually there was a tightening of the rules. The old USDA, referred to as ``peculiarly the people's department'' by creator Abraham Lincoln, became perceptibly stuffier and harder to penetrate because of the security. Tourists once were freely able to traipse in from the rounds of the nearby museums and art galleries and get free USDA brochures and booklets on virtually every subject. Fees are charged now, and the booklets have to be ordered from some place out West. So the elimination of the daily postings of schedules is only a small part of the changes that have occurred. The public versions of the daily schedules of USDA officials underwent editing to delete certain sensitive appointments from the calendars, a practice that went back through at least several administrations. Shipp, who was Yeutter's press secretary before taking over the top public affairs post recently, is still his chief spokeswoman. In an interview with The Associated Press and United Press International, Shipp said the canceling of the daily appointments calendar was an internal matter and ``you're just making too much out of it.'' She said Yeutter did not make the decision to cancel. ``It was a decision made at a lower level,'' she said. ``I'm not even sure he's aware of the decision. It was not a press (office) decision. It was not Kelly Shipp.'' The daily calendar was canceled for three basic reasons, Shipp said. It was not accurate, she said, and there are difficulties switching to a new computer system. Another reason is security. Daily schedules were floated all over Washington, allowing lobbyists, market speculators, foreign interests and intelligence gatherers of all sorts to note the comings and goings at USDA.

The nation's total 1991 meat output is expected to increase about 3 percent from this year's level, according to Agriculture Department projections. Red meat, mostly beef and pork, is forecast to increase in 1991 after two years of decline, the department's Economic Research Service said in last week's monthly supply-and-demand report. Beef production may increase slightly next year, most likely from fed cattle going to market. Non-fed beef output may drop a bit in 1991. ``Prices in 1991 probably will average the same to a little above the 1990 level,'' the report said. ``Beef imports are forecast to increase slightly in 1991, and exports will likely show another gain.'' Looking at pork, higher hog prices are expected to trigger a 3 percent increase in 1991 production. ``Prices will weaken under the increased output and for all of 1991 average a few dollars below this year's expected level,'' the report said. ``Pork imports in 1991 are expected to increase modestly, and exports likely will remain near the anticipated 1990 level.'' Broiler producers may boost 1991 production by about 5 percent, despite lower prices, the report said. ``The 1991 average price is expected to be near to slightly below 1990's level,'' it said. ``Broiler meat exports in 1990 have been boosted by sales to the Soviet Union and, if these sales continue in 1991, exports likely will remain at this year's level.''

Domestic cookies are costing more in Taiwan these days, so the Asian nation is looking toward imports. An Agriculture Department report in the August issue of Foreign Agriculture magazine says cookie and cracker importers are hopeful they can profit from the situation. In the past, the report said, imports of cookies and crackers were minimal because of high tariffs and ineffective marketing strategy. ``With the tariff now reduced to 35 percent and recent increased (domestic) production costs, imports of cookies and crackers are on the rise,'' the report said. But if U.S. manufacturers want to get into the growing market, they'll have plenty of competition from South Korea, Japan and Hong Kong, the report indicated.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Crisis Pushes Gas Prices Up 10 Cents a Gallon Nationwide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Middle East crisis helped drive up gasoline prices at the pump by more than a dime a gallon over the last three weeks, an oil analyst says. The nationwide Lundberg Survey of about 13,000 stations found the average price for all grades of gasoline, including taxes, was $1.27.94 a gallon on Friday, up 10.2 cents from July 20. Analyst Trilby Lundberg on Sunday said that U.S. oil companies have been forced to pay inflated prices for oil and gasoline on the short-term spot market to meet consumer demand during the summer driving months. ``The refiners are more susceptible to what's happening in the Middle East now than at any other time,'' she said. Refiners also raised their wholesale prices quickly to prevent panic buying that would leave them unable to fill customer orders, she said. There was a bright spot for consumers: Dealers failed to pass on the full cost of wholesale price increases to their customers. Between July 20 and Aug. 10 their profit margins shrank by 0.8 cents a gallon, Ms. Lundberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Economy Said in Weak Position to Withstand Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Despite Iraqi claims to the contrary, the Iraq economy is weak and ill-prepared to withstand an economic blockade, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today. ``Iraq's financial position was precarious before the invasion and the ending of new hard currency flows will impose severe strains on the Iraqi economy very rapidly,'' said the respected weekly newsletter based in Nicosia. The newsletter disclosed that payments for Iraqi crude delivered even before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait are being frozen. Payment is normally made by 30-day letters of credit. Iraq's economy depends almost entirely on oil. And the three outlets for Iraqi oil exports, pipelines across Turkey and Saudi Arabia, and shipment by sea direct from an Iraqi terminal at the head of the Gulf, have been blocked. The blocking of oil exports is part of a total trade embargo decreed by a U.N. Security Council resolution after Iraq invaded and then annexed Kuwait. ``Drawing together the available economic indicators, the clear indication is that the Iraqi economy has been deteriorating during the last year,'' the newsletter said. Iraq was becoming more dependent on outside funding after an expensive eight-year war with Iran. In the second half of 1989, a large increase was reported in short-term debt to Western industrialized countries. Also, last year cash aid to Iraq from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, estimated at $2 billion a year during the war _ which ended in a cease-fire in 1988 _ stopped. In 1989, Iraq had trouble borrowing from commercial banks, according to newsletter. Of a total of $1.6 billion in loans, $1.5 billion was in unauthorized loans from the Atlanta, Ga. branch of the Italian Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. The Middle East Economic survey said it is unlikely that Iraq, even before the embargo, could have found significant untapped sources of new money. ``It is clear that at the present time the Iraqi economy is very vulnerable and that it has little leeway to withstand an economic blockade,'' it said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has claimed that Iraq can hold out against the embargo if it conserves supplies. ``Iraq's national wealth is abundant. ... Our supplies of essential needs and food stuffs is great,'' Saddam said in a message broadcast Sunday on Baghdad television. ``Victory is on our side and defeat is certain for the aggessors who have pinned all their hopes to their economic sanctions and to their forces and their useless fleets.'' However, in the same speech he indicated a concern about shortages. He asked Iraqi women not to hoard foodstuffs and to cut back on consumption.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Carrying Iraqi Oil Docks In New Jersey; Payment Frozen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX2 of Aug. 12
DOC.TEXT: A tanker carrying nearly 1 million barrels of Iraqi oil that docked here does not fall under the trade embargo ordered by President Bush, the Coast Guard said. Mobil Oil Corp. accepted the oil at its Paulsboro Refinery on Sunday, but payment for the oil was blocked by sanctions Bush imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, said refinery spokeswoman Ida Walker. The embargo does not apply to the oil because the Bahamian-registered tanker left Turkey before the Middle East invasion, Ms. Walker said. Mobil contacted the Treasury Department for instructions and was told to accept the oil and deposit the payment due Iraq into a frozen account. She said she did not know how much the shipment cost. The tanker Nausicaa was docked in this port located across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. It carried the first Iraqi oil shipment into the area since the embargo was imposed, said Coast Guard Lt.j.g. Jonathan Burton. ``It was all bought before the thing started,'' he said. Until the embargo is lifted, Mobil will try to obtain extra oil from the North Sea, Mexico or other Middle East nations, Ms. Walker said. Before invading Kuwait, Iraq had been exporting 2.7 million barrels of oil a day through two pipelines across Turkey and Saudi Arabia and by ship through the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment At Highest Rate In 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: Israel's unemployment rate climbed to 10.1 percent in the second quarter of 1990, the highest figure in at least 15 years, the Central Bureau of Statistics reported Monday. According to the bureau, about 165,000 Israelis older than 15, or 10.1 percent of the country's work force, were jobless between April and June. Among men, the unemployment rate was 8.7 percent, compared with 11.9 percent among women, the bureau said. According to Finance Ministry projections cited in the Jerusalem Post Monday, unemployment rates will hover around 9 percent to 10 percent during the next five years. Goverment data show a steady increase in unemployment since 1975, when the jobless rate measured 3.1 percent. The mass immigration of Soviet Jews is expected to pose a major problem for the job market. About 70,000 Soviet Jews have already arrived, and the number is exected to climb to 150,000 by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: New Loans Approved, Despite Reports Of Dropping Credit Rating
DOC.TEXT: India can repay all the foreign loans it receives, the nation's top finance official said in an effort to refute charges that commercial banks are having misgivings about lending to the nation. ``There has been no scrambling for loans,'' Finance Secretary Bimal Jalan said in an interview this weekend, adding that India is not facing a credit crunch. ``As far as India is concerned, there is still a lot of enthusiasm'' on the part of international financial institutions to lend it money, he said. But experts say India's credit is in danger with commercial banks and predict that borrowing will become more difficult as its oil bills multiply. India spends $4 billion a year on oil, and rising prices will strain India's finances even more. India was approved last week for $320 million in new commercial loans, according to a Finance Ministry document. One loan, to the state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Commission by a Japanese syndicate, was previously reported to have fallen through. Jalan said India is paying off $1 billion in loans this year, ``and we are absolutely on schedule.'' He admitted, however, that repayment terms were not as good as they once were. ``Two or three years ago we were underborrowing, and we got the finest terms. We are still getting terms as good as Indonesia and better than China,'' he said. V.J. Ravishankar, a senior economist at the World Bank in New Delhi, said so far India has not been rejected for a loan, but its credit rating has fallen as it dipped deeply into its foreign currency reserves to finance a balance of payments deficit. ``India has never had any problems. But the situation is changing,'' Ravishankar said. Bankers are worried about its low foreign currency reserves and the increase in short-term loans, he said. A diplomatic source who closely monitors India's finances agreed the drop in reserves to about $2 billion _ enough to cover one month's imports _ worried the banks. Jalan said India's external debt grew to $44 billion as the government borrowed to bankroll major projects. World Bank figures said the external debt was actually about $65 billion as of last March. The larger figure included $9 billion in foreign currency deposits by Indians living abroad and loans from the International Monetary Fund. On the positive side, Jalan said exports are growing at about 18 percent aa year and ``keeping pace with imports. India's foreign debt is 17.8 percent of the gross domestic product, which he said is manageable. The debt service ratio, or the percentage of exports needed to repay loans, declined to 21.6 percent, one of the lowest ratios in the developing world, and is still falling, he said.

DOC.HEAD: GM Strike Continues, Could Idle 40,000 This Week
DOC.TEXT: A six-day strike at a General Motors Corp. parts plant has idled three assembly plant and could force the layoff of 40,000 autoworkers by midweek, the company says. Bargainers for United Auto Workers union Local 659 and the AC Rochester Flint West plant began meeting Sunday afternoon and continued talks into the night. The plant makes 65 percent of the fuel tanks for GM cars and trucks as well as other parts including engine valves, van doors and grilles for vans and pickup trucks. ``The workers attitudes are excellent and they are positive,'' union spokesman Larry Sills said Sunday. Among the plants that could close as early as today are GM's luxury car plant in Oakland Orion Township and the Pontiac East plant in Pontiac, GM said. GM officials were forced to close truck assembly plants in Pontiac, Moraine, Ohio, and Shreveport, La., last week due to parts shortages, idling 7,400 workers in all. Parts shortages brought on by the strike by 2,700 workers, which began Wednesday over health and safety issues and line speedups, also threaten production at the Buick City complex and the Truck & Bus Group assembly plant in Flint. Also threatened with layoffs are GM plants in Baltimore, Md.; Fort Wayne, Ind.; Wentzville, Mo.; and Oshawa, Ontario. The strike also could force shutdowns inside GM's vast network of component plants. For example, workers at the AC Rochester East plant in Flint, where pumps used in GM fuel tanks are made, were sent home Friday. In all, the strike could idle more than 40,000 GM workers by midweek unless the dispute is settled. One UAW insider, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said bargainers have made little progress in the past few days. ``We're just not getting anywhere,'' he said. UAW Vice President Stan Marshall has called the strike a signal to GM that union officials are frustrated with the drain on jobs due to outsourcing _ contracting for parts from sources outside GM. The UAW's national contracts expires Sept. 14.

Stock prices fell sharply in early trading today as the market remained jittery over the tension in the Middle East and the resulting jump in oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 24.25 to 2,692.33 in the first half hour of trading. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by more than 4 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 195 up, 859 down and 387 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 20.99 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts expected the market to continue its downward path from Friday, when the Dow plunged 42.33 points. Concern about the Mideast prompted investors to dump stocks in favor of safer investments, such as U.S. Treasury securities and precious metals, analysts said. Analysts expect the rise in oil prices to put pressure on corporate profits. Before the Mideast shock, experts were looking for profits to improve in the second half of the year. The domestic market didn't get any help from abroad. The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei, posted its fourth-largest percentage drop ever today, while share prices also were down in Europe. Among actively traded blue-chip issues today, Boeing fell 1 to 52, Philip Morris lost { to 45], IBM was down } to 101\ and General Motors fell | to 38~. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common shares was down 1.27 at 182.88. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 338.91, down 0.41. On Friday, volume on the floor of the NYSE came to 145.34 million shares, down from 155.81 the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 2.09 to 184.15. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 339.32, down 2.17.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Review Trump Deal
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump may have to reveal some details of his financial bailout if the Casino Control Commission rules the public has the right to the documents. Trump has requested that some of the 1,000 pages of documents remain secret because they hold sensitive financial information and business plans. The commission, in hearings scheduled to begin this afternoon, will decide which documents will be released. The material outlines a $65 million bank loan made to Trump in June. The loan was designed to avoid a default on bonds issued to support the Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay, one of three Atlantic City casinos owned by the Manhattan developer. The commission ruled last week that all the documents could be released, appellate judge delayed the order. The appellate division ruled Trump should present the commission with specific requests for what should not be released. Trump's attorneys say release of the more sensitive details could jeopardize future negotiations on restructuring the $1 billion in debt used to finance his three casinos. The commission is scheduled to hold a hearing Thursday on the merits of the restructuring plan. In other developments, news reports said Trump will hire First Boston Corp. to handle the restructuring, replacing Merrill Lynch & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Jumps by 26
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose for the first time in three weeks, jumping by 26 this week to 992, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. In the two previous weeks, the count had dropped by a combined 56 rigs. A year ago this week, the count was 858. Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes who keeps track of the count, said the increase ``may well be'' the start of a resurgence sparked by the Iraqi oil embargo. ``If this isn't the increase, I would certainly expect it shortly,'' Kerridge said. But he noted most of the fluctuation came from Texas, which last week dropped 16 rigs and this week gained 14. Kerridge said many of those rigs may have been moving to other locations in South Texas, the predominant site of a surge in horizontal drilling in the past year. Kerridge said he expected the count to continue increasing throughout the remainder of the year from seasonal fluctuations alone. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Texas gained 14 rigs for the week, after losing 16 last week. Other states with gains for the week included California, which added six, and Louisiana and Pennsylvania, which each added three. States reporting rig declines for the week include North Dakota, down three; Ohio and Michigan, each of which dropped by two; and Wyoming, which lost one rig. Other states including Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico and Oklahoma reported their rig counts were unchanged for the week.

Stock prices slipped this morning as the market remained jittery over the tension in the Middle East and the resulting jump in oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 15.34 points to 2,701.24 in the first hour and a half of trading. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by nearly 5 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 377 up, 890 down and 459 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 45.31 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts expected the market to continue its downward path from Friday, when the Dow plunged 42.33 points. Concern about the Mideast prompted investors to dump stocks in favor of safer investments, such as U.S. Treasury securities and precious metals, analysts said. Economists expect the rise in oil prices to depress the economy and put pressure on corporate profits. Before the Mideast shock, experts were looking for profits to improve in the second half of the year. The domestic market didn't get any help from abroad this morning. The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei, posted its fourth-largest percentage drop ever, while share prices also were down in Europe. Among actively traded blue-chip issues today, Boeing fell ~ to 52[, Philip Morris lost ] to 45{, IBM was up \ to 102\ and General Electric fell { to 66[. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common shares was down 0.66 at 183.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 338.43, down 0.89.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Should Have Oil Reserves Ready to Go, Petroleum Group Says
DOC.TEXT: The United States should be prepared to tap its strategic crude oil reserve in case the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil creates an insurmountable shortage, the head of an industry group said today. President Bush ``should give very serious consideration to releasing that oil,'' said Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute. ``There is no immediate pressure to do that, but that could change and we should be prepared to do that.'' The White House said late last week that it had no plans to open the nation's strategic petroleum reserve, a vast quantity of crude stockpiled in response to the Arab embargo oil shocks of the 1970s. The reserve is stored in underground salt caverns in Louisiana and is said to contain several hundred days' worth of emergency supplies. Oil prices climbed again this morning because of the uncertainty in the Middle East. The price of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, rose 47 cents a barrel to $26.70 by late morning on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil fetched $21 a barrel just before Iraq seized Kuwait Aug. 2. It might take a few weeks for the government to gear up to auction the oil held in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, so preparations for opening the reserve should be made now to avoid any delays, DiBona said. The turmoil in the world oil markets caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``is clearly the kind of circumstance for which the oil reserve was designed,'' DiBona said. He told a news conference that the immediate fate of the oil supply will hinge on the willingness of foreign producers to make up nearly 4 million barrels per day that had been exported by Iraq and Kuwait. ``Saudi Arabia, a key gulf producer, has indicated a willingness to help,'' DiBona said. ``So has Venezuela. And to the extent they do, they will largely make up the 4 million barrel per day shortfall. However, no one can know at this point what the net effect on world oil supplies will be.'' DiBona said there are other steps the United States can take to lessen the effects of the higher prices. He called on the government to open the Point Arguello oilfield off the coast of California, which he said is sitting idle because California officials have not given oil companies permission to deliver their oil. The field could immediately produce 90,000 barrels per day, DiBona said. Consumers could ease the crisis by conserving the oil they use and by resisting the temptation to top off their tanks or hoard supplies, although conservation will not be enough to solve the problem, DiBona said. Asked about complaints from consumers that oil companies have been unfairly raising prices, DiBona reiterated the industry's view that the companies have shown restraint. Retail prices of gasoline have not risen nearly as high as spot market prices or wholesale prices, he said. ``The petroleum industry has not taken advantage of this international crisis in a self-serving way,'' DiBona said. DiBona declined to predict what will happen to prices in the future. Increased domestic production could also alleviate the oil crisis, DiBona said, but oil companies base their plans for more exploration on their projections of prices over a long term. The prices have been changing too rapidly in recent days to permit any such long-term planning, DiBona said.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Chief Reportedly Given Ultimatum; Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck & Co. Chairman Edward Brennan was given an ultimatum by the board of directors last week to either shape up the company's sagging retail operations or ship out, Crain's Chicago Business reported today. Sears categorically denied the report. Crain's, attributing the report to unidentified board members, said Brennan was told at a directors' meeting last Wednesday that he has six months to achieve marked improvement in retail profits. The company did announce after that meeting that Brennan demoted the head of the Merchandise Group and took on those responsibilities himself. At the time, Sears said Michael Bozic was removed as president of the Merchandise Group because he wasn't moving fast enough to implement changes already under way. But Crain's said there was more to Bozic's removal than met the eye. ``You say you can turn this around _ then do it yourself,'' a director told Brennan, according to the Crain's account. Sears spokesman Gerald F. Buldack denied there was any truth to the Crain's report. ``It's absolutely false and misleading,'' Buldack said. He declined to answer specific questions about the report.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Retreat In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were modestly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly reflecting profit-taking after last week's gains in corn, soybeans and oats. Analysts also linked early losses in the corn and soybean markets to forecasts for more good growing weather in the Midwest. A National Weather Service six-to-10-day outlook issued Friday predicts mild temperatures and above-normal rainfall for the Midwest for the five-day period beginning Thursday. Traders will get an update on the condition of the corn and soybean crops when the Agriculture Department releases its weekly crop progress report after today's close. Wheat futures were pressured in early trading by perceptions the United States is becoming less competitive on the world wheat market because of an increased global supply of the grain. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.79 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 2 cents lower with September at $2.48\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents lower with September at $1.18\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 4 cents lower with August at $6.06{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .15 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 79.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .38 cent to .50 cent higher with August at 89.90 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .58 cent higher with August at 58.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to .63 cent higher with August at 48.25 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly lower on Friday; pork futures were mixed.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 405.88 down 2.15 from the previous day's close.

Stock prices slipped today as the market remained jittery over the tension in the Middle East and the resulting jump in oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 16.58 points to 2,700.00 as of noon on Wall Street. DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished lower on London's Stock Exchange Monday, but recovered after early losses. Investors said the trading day opened amid fears that the buildup of U.S. military forces in Saudi Arabia over the weekend and Tokyo's near-record fall earlier Monday could send London shares tumbling. ``There hasn't actually been that much selling,'' said the head of trading at a major London brokerage. ``London was never that nasty.'' Some traders said the market may be about to bottom out from its mid-summer fall. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 14.3 points or 0.6 percent, to close at 2,219.5, only a point lower than the day's high of 2,220.5 at the market's open. The low was 2,193.3. DOC.HEAD: Not Quite Like 1973 and 1979
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT release date and cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: Much of the immediate reactions in securities markets after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was based on fears of an oil shortage and a runup in the price of fuel, as in 1973 and 1979. But much has changed since then, a good deal of it, though not all, for the better. Some of the conservation program has been junked, for example, but it has left a legacy of better insulated houses, more efficient combustion engines, and less reliance on oil. And parts of the program can be resurrected. The political situation has changed. Back then, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Nations was united in efforts to raise prices. And the world powers were still antagonistic toward each other's plans, whatever they were. Today, much of the Arab world opposes Iraq's actions, and the world's powers seem more accommodating to each other's hopes for the future. OPEC seems willing to allow production to rise. Stability is another widely shared goal. Oil reserves of the Western world and Japan today are massively higher than before. The United States has close to a billion barrels in strategic and commercial oil stocks. Relative to usage, Japan may have more. Meanwhile, the lesson of the 1970s was not entirely wasted. Philadelphia Electric now relies heavily on nuclear power, generating less than 5 percent of its electricty from oil. New England electric has cut its reliance in half. The economic situation has changed. In the 1970s the U.S. economy was effectively out of control, with prices and interest rates high or rising. As a result, the Federal Reserve tightened its monetary policy, hoping to slow the economy. In 1990, the economy has many weak spots _ debt, for instance _ that pose more critical dangers than a temporary increase in the price of oil. The economy as a whole is under a tight-fisted monetary policy. Moreover, when the Fed pushed up short-term interest rates in the earlier crises it precipitated recessions, the second one considered to be among the worst of the century. It isn't likely to commit that error again. While a prolonged shortage of oil or extreme prices could be debilitating to the American economy, that prospect is not nearly so high today as it was in the 1970s, when major oil producing countries were united in their stand. A short-term cut in the flow of oil from abroad still would affect prices, but perhaps to a smaller degree than many people fear. In the absence of panic, says economist Roger Brinner, a $2-a-barrel rise seems likely in 1991. By his calculations for DRI-McGraw-Hill, an important provider of economic data to the private sector, this would imply a 5 percent gain in the average wholesale price of all fuel and power. While that $2-a-barrel increase would be close to 10 percent, he reasons that the significant roles of nuclear, hydro and coal generation would dilute the effect on delivered prices. The consumer impact would be even less, he says. Because household spending on energy is 5.5 percent of all consumer purchases, ``the direct inflation impact is about a quarter of a percentage point (5 percent of 5.5 percent).'' The spillover from other product and labor markets could add to this impact. Brinner believes it might mean a total price bulge of 0.5 percent, ``but not to any material, sustained increase in the rate of inflation.'' A more optimistic scenario than many would paint, of course. And it never should be forgotten that economic projections have a tendency to be revised when confronted with reality.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Power Outage Socks Lower Manhattan, Halts Some Financial Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with several markets closing for the day, quotes. No pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An electrical blackout disrupted New York's financial district today, halting the operations of many investment companies and the trading of some stocks and commodities. The American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and other New York commodities futures exchanges suspended trading for the rest of the day following the early afternoon power failure. Many financial brokers and dealers had to curtail or suspend operations and others simply told workers in the affected area to leave for the day after power failed at about 1:15 p.m. ``Except for a skeleton crew, everybody's heading home,'' said Steven Faigen, spokesman for Shearson Lehman Brothers, one of the biggest Wall Street investment firms. Shearson and other major brokerages still kept traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, which was unaffected by the power outage. But the volume of trading slowed. A substation fire caused the outage, which affected much of southern Manhattan's Wall Street area, the World Trade Center and World Financial Center, headquarters of many of the nation's biggest financial businesses. Con Edison, New York's electrical utility, said it wouldn't restore power for hours. The outage also briefly disrupted operations at Dow Jones, which publishes the Wall Street Journal and operates a financial news wire service. Spokesman James Ambrosio said the news wire stopped for about 30 minutes and the company was operating on emergency backup power. The fire at Con Ed's Seaport substation began shortly after noon, said utility spokesman Dan Walden. ``It knocked out some high voltage cables serving the area,'' Walden said, initially affecting 500 customers. Two other feeder cables became overloaded and were also knocked out, causing the blackout to spread. ``I can't say for sure how many now. But it's going to be substantially more than 500,'' Walden said. Concern that continued electrical usage by other customers would overload feeder cables and knock out additional networks, prompted Con Ed to issue an emergency plea for immediate cutbacks. ``It's imperative that other customers cooperate,'' Walden said. The cause of the fire, which was not under control more than an hour after it began, was not immediately known. The fire also affected some subway service in the area, the Transit Authority said.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Announces Reduced Fare Program
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines announced reduced fares Monday, and gave travelers about two weeks to buy tickets before a fuel-related fare increase takes effect. The one-way fares, ranging from $69 to $139, cover all of Eastern's 62 U.S. destinations from Sept. 5 to Dec. 16, but the tickets must be purchased by Aug. 29, the Miami-based company said. Eastern, along with several other airlines, plans to hike fares by 5.3 percent this week because of higher fuel costs following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But Eastern said it decided to offer the reduced fares to increase business during the slower fall season. A Saturday night overnight stay is required to qualify for the lower fares, which are available all days but Nov. 21 and Nov. 25-26, said senior vice president for marketing George Brennan. Some of the fares include: Miami-New York, $79; New York-Los Angeles, $139; and Atlanta-Boston, $79.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-UPS-Teamsters Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the three-year contract by drivers and package handlers at United Parcel Service of America Inc.
DOC.HEAD: WAGES
DOC.TEXT: All current regular seniority employees' wages will increase by 50 cents per hour on Aug. 1 of 1990, 1991, and 1992, for a total $1.50 over the life of the contract.
DOC.HEAD: COST-OF-LIVING ALLOWANCE
DOC.TEXT: Base wages would be raised by up to an additional 20 cents an hour each year based on a cost-of-living adjustment linked to inflation. The adjustment will be calculated on Aug. 1 of 1991 and 1992. If the cost-of-living increase were to increase 5 percent each year, for example, eligible employees would receive 10 cents an hour more in both 1991 and 1992.
DOC.HEAD: BENEFITS
DOC.TEXT: Contributions made to Health and Welfare and Pension Plans will be increased each year by 35 cents, for a total increase of $1.05 per hour over three years.
DOC.HEAD: BONUS
DOC.TEXT: Full-time seniority employees as of Aug. 1, 1990, will receive a $1,000 bonus within one month of ratification; part-timers will receive $500.
DOC.HEAD: PART-TIME PENSIONS
DOC.TEXT: The maximum retirement benefit for people in the Part-Time Pension Plan will increase by $100 to $1,100 a month.
DOC.HEAD: WORKING CONDITIONS
DOC.TEXT: Improvements include heated mirrors for tractors, easier-to-handle dollies and better seats in package cars. Also, joint labor-management committees will be formed to offer recommendations on all safety, health and equipment issues affecting UPS employees. A special committee will deal specifically with safety in handling toxic and hazardous materials.
DOC.HEAD: JOB OPPORTUNITIES
DOC.TEXT: Three of each four permanent full-time job opportunities will go to part-time employees.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Retreat on Weather Forecasts, Technical Factors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS prices in last graf
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures retreated Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to improved growing conditions for the southern soybean crop. Rain fell Monday in the Mississippi Delta region, where drier-than-normal conditions had raised concerns about the soybean crop. Weather forecasters predicted a continuation of beneficial crop weather in the Midwest, where the bulk of U.S. corn and soybeans are grown. The broad-based decline also reflected disappointment in the market's generally weak response last week to a government crop report that projected lower 1990 U.S. corn and soybean production than traders had expected. ``There were some discouraged sellers today,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Wheat futures settled 3 cents to 7{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.75\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 5 cents lower with September at $2.45\ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $1.16 a bushel; soybeans were 5{ cents to 14 cents lower with August at $6.03\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: New OPEC Meeting Planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf At the... to UPDATE with later oil price, detail on trading halt. Picks up 6th graf, Charles DiBona... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Oil-producing countries are planning a new meeting to discuss how they should handle oil shortages that have resulted since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Saudi ambassador said Monday. ``There will be an OPEC meeting soon,'' Prince Bandar Bin Sultan said at a briefing for reporters. He said members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are holding ``consultations'' in preparation for the meeting. Bandar provided scant details, refusing to say when and where the OPEC meeting would be held. Earlier he said the Saudis would like ``to have a stable and predictable market for oil.'' The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 _ and subsequent sanctions against those countries _ have cut by 4 million barrels a day the amount of oil available on the world markets. At the same time, oil prices have climbed because of the uncertainty in the Middle East. The price of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, rose 54 cents a barrel to $26.77 Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, in trading that halted early due to a power outage. Oil traded at about $21 a barrel just before Iraq seized Kuwait. Charles DiBona, chairman of the American Petroleum Institute, said Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have both indicated a willingness to help ease shortages. At the most recent OPEC meeting, which concluded in Geneva, Switzerland, July 27, the 13 OPEC ministers raised the target price $3 to $21 a barrel. They also agreed not to puncture the production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day until the end of the year. Just before the meeting, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had threatened military action against countries that were over-producing chronically, namely Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.
