DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Rise at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level in two weeks. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.41 percent, up from 7.23 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.31 percent, up from 7.19 percent last week. The rates were the highest since July 30 when three-month bills sold for 7.50 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.37 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.66 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,812.70 and 7.70 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,630.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.70 percent last week, up from 7.67 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Denies Report That Chairman's Job In Jeopardy
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck & Co. said Monday there's no truth to a published report that Chairman Edward Brennan was given six months to revive the company's retail operation or risk losing his job. The report in this week's edition of Crain's Chicago Business quoted unidentified directors as saying the board is fed up with Sears' decline as the nation's biggest general retailer. ``Brennan is on real thin ice, and he has a very short time period,'' Crain's reported, quoting a source close to the company. ``He has taken over the helm of a ship that has a rotten bottom, and he has been running around trying to patch up the holes with tar, but he has too many gushers.'' Brennan reportedly was given the ultimatum during a directors' meeting last Wednesday. After the meeting the company announced the demotion of Michael Bozic from head of the retail operation and said Brennan was taking on those added responsibilities. But director Albert V. Casey, former chairman of AMR Corp., said he attended Wednesday's meeting and there was no attack on Brennan. ``His job isn't in jeopardy at all,'' Casey said in a telephone interview Monday. ``If we didn't have him, he's just the kind of executive we'd be looking for.'' Sears also denied that Brennan had been given an ultimatum. ``It's absolutely false and misleading,'' spokesman Gerald Buldack said of the Crain's report. He declined to answer specific questions about the story. Sears stock dropped 25 cents to $30.50 in Monday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Before taking over the leadership of Sears, Brennan had been in charge of its Merchandise Group and led it to its top earnings in 1984. But the company has struggled in recent years with rising costs, stiff competition and a sluggish overall retail environment. Sears' retailing costs are the highest in the industry. Expenses last year consumed 30 cents of every retail sales dollar, compared with 23 cents at K mart Corp. and 16 cents at Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Net income produced by the Merchandise Group declined 32 percent during the second quarter of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Maker To Sell Rail Works
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, The rail ... to CORRECT to revenue sted earnings.
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp. said Monday it plans to sell its railroad freight car division as part of an effort to divest assets unrelated to its basic steel making operations. The division, which is located in Cambria County and employs 1,000 people, produces rail cars including coal gondolas and haulers for truck trailers. The rail car division posted revenue of $120 million in 1989. Bethlehem, the nation's second-largest steel maker, said the division's earnings increased in the first six months of 1989 because more rail cars were shipped. USW Local 2635 President William Kramer in Johnstown said the announcement was a surprise. He had no further comment. The sale offer was announced to employees Monday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Up, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices climbed to five-month highs Monday on concerns that Iraq's occupation of Kuwait could explode into war involving Western forces, choke off the oil flow and batter the economy. The U.S. dollar, meanwhile, slumped against major foreign currencies, which are expected to strengthen as interest rates rise overseas while rates fall here as monetary authorities try to keep the economy out of a recession. Gold for current delivery was up $8.30 a troy ounce at $405.20 as trading was unexpectedly halted in the early afternoon on New York's Commodity Exchange due to a power outage. The gain followed a rise of $11.10 an ounce. The spot price for gold hasn't closed that high since early March, traders said. In after-hours trading at Republic National Bank in New York, gold was quoted at a $403.25 an ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $7 from Friday's late bid. Dealers in New York said most of the gains in gold prices occurred overnight in foreign markets and included reported purchases by Mideast buyers. They said gold prices surged in the first hour in New York to match the gains overseas but trading was subdued and featureless for the rest of the day. ``The price rise reflected the continued crisis in the Mideast,'' said Steven Pepper, bullion dealer for Republic National Bank. He said investors buy gold in times of international political turmoil, and the metal also affords protection against inflation that is expected to result from the oil price surge that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. Gold rose $13.35 to $404.60 an ounce in London, and jumped to $404 an ounce in Zurich from $390.50 late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.92 an ounce to close at $397.67. Silver for current delivery rose to $5.145 per troy ounce on the Comex, up 17.6 cents from Friday's close. Silver rose to $5.15 a troy ounce in London from $4.95 late Friday. In the currency markets, the dollar lost more ground against major currencies on anticipation that U.S. interest rates will move lower while rates overseas rise in coming days. The dollar has been under pressure in recent weeks because of weakness in the U.S. economy, and many traders expect the Federal Reserve will eventually move to lower interest rates in an effort to stimulate the economy to keep it from a recession. But at the same time, traders expect rates will rise in Germany and Japan as central banks there try to head off inflation due to rising oil prices. The net effect would be to make the dollar less attractive for foreign investors. ``The only thing supporting the dollar is the flight to quality'' that is traditionally involved when international events are in turmoil, said Karen Gibbs, a seniuor financial analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ``The dollar is no longer perceived as quality _ it's the Swiss franc, the D-mark and the Australian dollar,'' she said. In New York, the dollar fell to 150.25 Japanese yen from 150.40 yen late Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 150.65 yen from 149.75 yen at Friday's close. In London, it fell to 150.35 yen. The dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8825 from $1.8735 late Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.8842 from $1.8730 late Friday. DOC.HEAD: Chase Manhattan Offers Severance to Longtime Employees
DOC.TEXT: Longtime U.S. employees of Chase Manhattan Corp. are being offered severance payments to leave their jobs early as the nation's second-biggest banking company begins efforts to trim costs by $300 million. The company made the offer last week to employees with at least 10 years service, a company spokesman who asked not to be identified said Monday. He was unable to say how many of the company's 30,000 domestic employees are eligible for the program, but estimated it is a few thousand. Like other major banking companies, Chase has been under pressure to cut costs because the commercial real estate market has left lenders with increasing levels of problem loans. Chase expects to charge about $30 million against its third-quarter earnings as a result of the voluntary program, depending on how many employees take advantage of it. It expects to save $10 million in the fourth quarter as a result of the program, again depending on participation. The new separation program is only part of the company's plan to trim costs, the Chase spokesman said. He said the program ``is a way of giving added flexibility to the employees who have been with us a long time.'' Under the offer, employees who retire with at least 10 years service would get two week's pay for every year of service and those with at least 20 years would get three weeks' pay for every year of service. The offer is open until Sept. 10. Chase told employees in June that it intends to trim $300 million in costs. That announcement came in the wake of a management reorganization in which it named President Thomas G. Labrecque to replace Willard C. Butcher as chairman and chief executive officer effective Oct. 31. For the first six months of this year, Chase's profits have fallen 64 percent to $96 million, or 44 cents a share. For the third quarter of 1989, Chase lost $1.11 billion, or $12.45 a share, including $1.26 billion of special provisions, such as adding to the bank's reserves for possible losses on loans to countries refinancing their debts.

Concern about the Mideast and the effect of rising oil prices on the economy prompted investors to dump stocks in favor of safer investments, analysts said. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market grew $20.877 billion, or 0.65 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.48 to 185.63. Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index rose 3.32 to 338.84. S&P's industrial index was unavailable due to the power outage. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.27 to 408.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index as of 1 p.m. EDT _ before the market was forced to close by the power outage _ stood at 338.14, down 1.18.

DOC.HEAD: Plants Prepare for Strike After Offer Rejected
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. closed coke ovens and blast furnaces Monday as the ailing steel maker braced for a strike Thursday by 5,500 union workers in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. The Wheeling, W.Va.-based company said it cut production after the United Steelworkers rejected a contract that included a $3,000 signing bonus and a raise of $2 an hour in each of the next four years. Workers at 13 USW locals last month authorized a strike beginning just after midnight Wednesday. USW spokesman Dick Fontana said Monday the union had no comment on the rejection of the offer. Resumption of talks wasn't scheduled this week, but Wheeling-Pitt was trying to meet with the union before the strike deadline, said company spokesman Ray Johnson. ``We'd certainly be willing to sit down with them to negotiate further,'' he said. Wheeling-Pitt, the nation's 10th largest steel maker, operates steel mills in Allenport, Washington County, Pa.; Beech Bottom, Follansbee and Wheeling, W.Va.; and Steubenville, Mingo Junction, Canfield, Martins Ferry and Yorkville, Ohio. The company sought protection from its creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in 1985, and its reorganization has been one of the nation's longest. Wheeling-Pitt said in a news release Monday that mills were preparing to stop making and shipping steel ``to effect an orderly shutdown in event of the walkout.'' ``You don't just shut these operations down by pressing a button,'' Johnson said. ``You have to gradually get them to a point where you can shut them down.'' Union officials have said they are angry about fees paid to accountants and lawyers in Wheeling-Pitt's reorganization and payment to union members of 13 cents on the dollar for stock, compared to 74 cents on the dollar for creditors' claims. Wheeling-Pitt said its negotiators are concerned the USW kept details of the rejected proposal from rank-and-file members. The company said it would keep its doors open to employees who wanted to work during a walkout. The company alleged a strike would violate federal labor laws and accused the USW of repressive bargaining. Wheeling-Pitt Chairman William Scharffenberger told the company's board of directors in July that a long strike would force him to consider liquidating the company's assets and turning over proceeds to creditors. The USW called Scharffenberger's announcement a bluff.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Relieved by Robert Campeau's Removal
DOC.TEXT: Creditors overseeing the Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization of the Federated and Allied retailing companies were relieved by the ouster of chairman Robert Campeau of Campeau Corp., a creditors' lawyer said Monday. Toronto-based Campeau Corp., which owns Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., announced Friday that the 66-year-old Canadian businessman who founded the company more than 40 years ago had been forced out as chairman and chief executive. He remains as a company director, but his future role has not been announced. ``We obviously hope that it would have some positive _ although I doubt any immediate _ direct impact. His involvement has not had any apparent effect on the administration of these cases,'' said Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer representing Federated's unsecured creditors. ``I think what's important is his removal reflects realization by his board of directors and shareholders of the financial destruction wrought by the administration of Federated and Allied,'' Rosenbloom said. Campeau engineered the 1986 purchase of Allied and the 1988 buyout of Federated. The leveraged deals saddled Federated and Allied with debt that prompted them to seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors on Jan. 15 in Cincinnati. Federated and Allied, which listed $7.7 billion in debts, still have not announced when they plan to file their formal plans for emerging from reorganization. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. of Cincinnati is overseeing their operations. Rosenbloom said the ouster reassured creditors because it suggests Campeau will not attempt to involve himself in the reorganization by claiming equity in the reorganized Federated and Allied. Federated and Allied, both based in Cincinnati, operate 256 stores in 28 states and employ about 100,000 people. ``Our view was that any role he would play would be in the ultimate reorganization of those companies, and that he would potentially present an impediment to the reorganization process,'' Rosenbloom said. Rosenbloom said the creditors he represents want Federated and Allied to survive _ not be liquidated _ because the two companies have demonstrated historically that they are profitable. ``Our constituency believes that the return of the companies to the marketplace as operating companies outside of Chapter 11 is very, very important to the health of the companies,'' he said. Conrad Morgenstern, the U.S. trustee helping Aug administer the Federated and Allied cases, said Robert Campeau's ouster should not affect the reorganizations. Carol Sanger, a Campeau Corp. spokeswoman in Cincinnati, said Federated and Allied have been remote from Robert Campeau since January's Chapter 11 filings. ``Ultimately, I think it may prove to be a good thing in that many of the creditors were urging that this be done all along,'' Ms. Sanger said. ``It will have no direct impact as far as we're concerned.''

DOC.HEAD: Gold Soars With Oil Price, Inflation Fears
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices soared in an abbreviated trading session Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting rising inflation fears as oil prices continue to climb. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures fell sharply and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Trading on the New York commodity exchanges ended abruptly with an electrical blackout early in the afternoon that affected much of New York's Wall Street district. On the Commodity Exchange, trading halted with gold futures up $7.20 to $11, with the contract for delivery in August at $405.20 a troy ounce, the strongest finish for a spot gold contract since March 1. Silver futures ended 17.1 cents to 20.9 cents higher with August at $5.145 a troy ounce. Precious metals rose sharply for the third straight day as surging oil prices kept inflation fears alive. Gold is considered a good hedge against inflation. When trading ended on the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures were 43 cents to $1 higher with September at $26.66 a barrel; heating oil was 1.48 cents to 3 cents higher with September at 75.05 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .65 cent to 3.45 cents higher with September at 82.90 cents a gallon. Strength in the oil markets was again linked to tensions in the Persian Gulf, where a barricade of U.S. warships stood ready to block all trade with Iraq. Iraq's conquest of Kuwait has been a powerful stimulant for gold, which traded as low as $352 an ounce in early June. Some analysts believe the market would fall just as sharply if the Middle East situation suddenly cooled. But Stephen Gotwald, vice president of GoldCorp Australia, a marketer of Australian precious metal coins, said Monday's rally above $405 demonstrated ``some real confidence'' in gold that had nothing to do with the Middle East. And as long as the United States remains a key player in the Persian Gulf war, gold will find additional support there, he said. ``The deeper we go, the less likely that a reasonable solution is going to be found any time soon,'' Gotwald said of the Middle East situation. Grain and soybean futures tumbled on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to improved growing conditions for the southern soybean crop. Rain fell Monday in the Mississippi Delta region, where drier-than-normal conditions had raised concerns about the soybean crop. Weather forecasts predicted a continuation of beneficial crop weather in the Midwest, where the bulk of U.S. corn and soybeans are grown. In a six-to-10-day forecast released after the close, the National Weather Service predicted normal- to above-normal temperatures and normal precipitation in the Midwest for the first half of next week. A 30-day forecast projected warmer and drier-than-normal conditions for the region through mid-September. Corn and soybean development continues to lag well behind the normal pace, according to the Agriculture Department's weekly crop progress report, which was also released after the close. Wheat futures settled 3 cents to 7{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.75\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 5 cents lower with September at $2.45\ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $1.16 a bushel; soybeans were 5{ cents to 14 cents lower with August at $6.03\ a bushel. Strong cash markets helped lift near-term livestock and meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle settled .15 cent lower to .23 cent higher with August at 79.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent to .55 cent higher with August at 90.07 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .53 cent higher with August at 58.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent lower to 1.28 cents higher with August at 48.90 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Freak Outage Disrupts Trading on New York Financial Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd with two grafs to add description; picks up 4th graf pvs, Amid the...
DOC.TEXT: A Wall Street blackout displaced Iraq's Saddam Hussein as the bogeyman of the U.S. financial markets Monday, disrupting trading in stocks, bonds, currencies, and commodites. The fire at a Con Edison power substation forced the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and other futures markets in southern Manhattan to close by early afternoon. The New York Stock Exchange was unaffected by the outage but trading volume slowed at the nation's biggest stock market as electricity-starved offices elsewhere in the financial district emptied. Thousands of workers from secretaries to investment bankers flooded into traffic-snarled streets and headed home early. Yellow-tinged smoke from the substation fire billowed through the skyscraper canyons of southern Manhattan. Amid the confusion, oil prices rose, gold surged, stocks and bonds were mixed and the dollar fell. Amex spokesman Robert Shabazian said power was restored by late afternoon and it planned to reopen Tuesday morning as normal. He also said ``we're making provisions for auxiliary power in the event there's another outage.'' The disruptions in trading caused by the fire added to the pressure bearing down on the markets since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. Among the markets that were forced to close early was the volatile oil futures market at the New York Merc. ``It greatly affected us,'' said Peter Stern, a dealer at Refco Inc., a leading New York commodities futures concern. ``Our phones went down, our screens went down, a lot of people went home.'' The fire forced an evacuation of several buildings including parts of the World Trade Center and World Financial Center complexes that frame southern Manhattan's skyline, leaving some of the nation's biggest brokerage operations functioning with skeletal crews. It briefly stalled the Dow Jones News Service and caused a more serious and prolonged disruption to the Telerate Inc. news service, two of the principal information pipelines feeding the markets. In addition, the fire hampered trading far beyond New York's borders, since many key dealers based in the affected area were forced to curtail business. This meant they could not move price information to the network of computer screens and telephones that form part of a global trading system. ``To sum it up real simple, the bond market more or less shut down,'' said Mark McCluskey, who works on the bond trading desk at the Manhattan office of Bank Julius Baer & Co., a leading Swiss bank. Many dealers shifted their trades to offices abroad such as London and Tokyo, but others with speculative positions in the market were left dangerously exposed. ``A number of our sources had no screens to work with, or didn't want to say anything. The picture of the market suddenly disappeared and a number of dealers were affected,'' said Bruce Chalfant, assistant vice president for information services at Telerate. ``I'm sure there are people who are not going to be sleeping well. There was no close, things just stopped.'' On the New York Merc, one of three key world oil markets besides London and Singapore, the price of benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude was up 54 cents to $26.77 a barrel when trading shut down. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale home-heating oil rose 2.44 cents to 75.05 cents a gallon, and wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 3.35 cents to 82.80 cents a gallon. The exchange said the day's trading would be reflected in the tally of transactions for Tuesday, when trading was expected to return to normal. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.20 points to 2,746.78, but the broader market for stocks was mixed and trading was light because of the power outage. The Amex market value index was down 1.18 to 338.14 before the outage. Prices in the bond market, an important barometer of interest rates, were mixed in light volume as well. Gold was up $8.30 a troy ounce at $405.20 on the New York Commodity Exchange when traded halted, the highest price since early March and a signal of growing inflation anxiety caused by the rise in oil. The dollar lost value, reflecting expectations that higher interest rates abroad will make foreign currencies such as the German mark and Japanese yen worth more.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern, TWA Announce Discount Fare Promotions
DOC.TEXT: Two major airlines announced Monday they would cut some domestic air fares for a limited time, offering the promotion at a time major airlines have raised most ticket prices to account for sharply higher fuel prices. Eastern Airlines announced new discount one-way fares that will range from $69 to $139 and cover all Eastern's 62 U.S. destinations from Sept. 5 through Dec. 16. The tickets must be purchased by Aug. 29, Eastern said. The cheaper fares, which will apply only to round-trip tickets with a Saturday overnight stay, were announced two days before Eastern's scheduled 5.3 percent hike in its other fares. Like other major airlines, Eastern is raising most of its fares because of the jump in jet fuel prices following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and subsequent speculation of a disruption in oil supplies. The discount fares aren't available for travel on Nov. 21 and Nov. 25-26, but the tickets will be refundable, Eastern said. Separately, Trans World Airlines announced it would cut non-refundable domestic fares in most markets 20 percent or more, reducing the rate to $158 one-day from New York to St. Louis, for example. Trans World spokesman Jim Faulkner said the company still plans to raise international fares by $20 and might consider raising its domestic fares in the future if fuel prices do not retreat. Trans World's cheaper tickets must be purchased between Tuesday and Aug. 29 for travel between Sept. 5 and Dec. 16. Airlines that have announced fuel-related fare hikes include Delta, United, USAir, Northwest, America West, Midway, Pan Am, Southwest and Trump Shuttle.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Officials File Charges Against Western Union Over Lockout
DOC.TEXT: Union lawyers filed an unfair labor practices complaint with the National Labor Relations Board Monday over Western Union Corp.'s lockout of about 2,000 workers. At the same time, employees represented by the Communications Workers of America have set up informational picket lines at Western Union telephone and computer centers, but said they had no plans to call a strike. In its brief to the Washington-based labor board, the CWA accused Western Union of acting illegally by imposing a selective lockout on Saturday. About 500 service and business representatives, administrative clerks and technicians have been asked to continue work, said George Kohl, the union's director of research. Lawyers also are protesting that some temporary workers earn more than union employees and that the company violated the workers' rights to bargain and strike by locking them out. Kohl said he expects the labor relations board to set a calendar date Tuesday. Union employees have been hoisting signs and distributing information since the lockout was declared Saturday, but the union's chief negotiator, Dan J. Beckstead, said the CWA has no plans to call a strike. ``It is not a strike,'' Beckstead said, taking pains to distinguish between the informational picket lines and strike lines. ``No one has even suggested that we are going to strike.'' Union employees authorized a walkout two weeks ago, but set no date for a strike, said Beckstead, president of the Communications Workers of America-United Telegraph Workers Bargaining Council. Monday, both sides expressed a desire to continue the contract negotiations that began July 23, two weeks before a two-year contract was due to expire. Talks continued after the agreement expired Aug. 6, but ran aground on the company's desire to pare down medical benefits and to contract union work to outside firms, Beckstead said. Western Union served notice Saturday that it would replace most of its union employees unless labor officials reconsidered the company's Aug. 8 offer to extend the expired contract by 90 days. Some temporary workers were on the job by 1 a.m. Saturday, with 2,200 replacements reporting to work Monday morning, said Western Union spokesman Warren Bechtel. About 300 of the workers are Western Union managers and the rest are locally hired and trained replacements, he said. Union workers total nearly 75 percent of the company's nationwide staff of 3,400, Bechtel said. Operations at the giant telegram company have been slowed, but not disrupted, Bechtel said. ``Services are being provided, and the level of service is good and getting better,'' he said. ``You don't replace trained, experienced people and overnight come up to same level of service, but we're working on it.'' Monday, pickets were concentrated at Western Union centers in Bridgeton, Mo., and Reno, Nev., where major central phone bureaus and a computer center are located, Beckstead said.

DOC.HEAD: AAA Says Gas Prices Dropped Slightly After Huge Leap
DOC.TEXT: Average gasoline prices dropped more than 3 cents nationwide this weekend after soaring nearly 18 cents as the Persian Gulf crisis unfolded, the American Automobile Association said Monday. AAA's national Fuel Gauge Report shows self-serve regular unleaded averages $1.216 per gallon, down 3.4 cents since Friday. In Detroit on Monday, the average price fell .6 cents to $1.184 per gallon. In St. Louis, it fell .6 cents to $1.063 per gallon, and in Kansas City, it dropped 1.7 cents to $1.121. In Washington, motorists were paying $1.157 per gallon, up .7 cents since Friday. The average costs in the capital had dropped 2 cents between Wednesday and Friday. In southern Indiana, the average price, which dropped 5 cents overnight Friday, increased 1 cent Monday to $1.22 per gallon. Monday's survey was based on a spot check of stations nationwide by Computer Petroleum Corp. of St. Paul, Minn. The company also publishes the National Petroleum Price Index, which monitors more than 50,000 daily wholesale prices in the United States and Canada. The Orlando-based AAA is a not-for-profit federation of motor clubs with nearly 32 million members in the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Union Says USAir Will Lay Off 211 Pilots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with USAir confirming layoffs; PICKUP 7th graf pvs, ``I think ...
DOC.TEXT: USAir Group Inc. said Monday it would lay off about 200 pilots in a cutback that could also affect flight attendants and other employees, a spokeswoman for the airline said. ``We will not fly as much new service as originally planned, in view of the state of the economy,'' spokeswoman Susan Young said in explaining the layoffs. She said she could not elaborate on the number of workers involved or when they might be let go. Earlier Monday, the Air Line Pilots Association announced to members that the Arlington, Va.-based carrier had decided to lay off 211 pilots around the end of the year. The union told its members in a tape-recorded telephone message that it learned of the plans last week in Los Angeles during a meeting with USAir President Seth Schofield and other airline executives. USAir Group lost $113.1 million in the first half of this year, and has not posted a profit since the second quarter of 1989. ``I think it's safe to say that the airline's traffic and the industry's traffic is flat,'' she said. She also said the airline may have too many pilots for its fleet. The excess could have resulted from ``older aircraft and rescheduling of aircraft deliveries,'' she said. Twelve new jets had been scheduled for arrival this year, but USAir delayed taking delivery in an unusual cost-cutting move. It also has tried to save money by paying less overtime to maintenance crews. The union message said Schofield told the pilots' Master Executive Council that USAir foresees a further decline in traffic and higher fuel prices. The vice chairman of ALPA's Master Executive Council, Chris Beebe, urged the pilots to adhere exactly to the wording in their contract and not to fly overtime.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Stays Order Releasing Key Parts Of Trump Documents
DOC.TEXT: An angry state Casino Control Commission on Monday ordered Donald Trump to release information on a restructuring that puts the developer's three Atlantic City casinos up as collateral. However, the commission delayed its order for 24 hours to allow Trump's attorneys to appeal the decision. The panel ordered all the documents unsealed after Trump's attorneys asked for a blanket order sealing the more than 1,000 pages of documents detailing a $65 million emergency loan for Trump. The loan was arranged in June after Trump missed a date to make a payment on bonds sold to finance Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. Trump made the payment within a 10-day grace period after receiving a bridge loan while paperwork on the $65 million deal was finished. Under the agreement, Trump for the first time is using his casinos as collateral for financial assistance. The agreement with the banks will restructure about $1 billion of his $1.3 billion casino debt and $1.9 billion in other debts. The commission is scheduled to review the bailout on Thursday and members say they want the plan's underpinnings available to the public. Attorneys Nicholas Ribis and Joseph Fusco said the sensitivity of the documents could jeopardize the negotiations. Acting commission chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said in a scathing opinion that Trump's attorneys again failed to prove why the public should not know the details of Trump's restructuring. ``This proposal would, if approved by the commission, collateralize Mr. Trump's ownership of three of the largest casino hotels in Atlantic City,'' Ms. Armstrong said. ``It is indisputable that the economic structure and stability of Trump's casino holdings in this state is a matter of public concern.'' She rejected the argument that details of Trump's problems would hamper his deal-making efforts. ``It is certainly no secret to the marketplace that Mr. Trump is experiencing serious financial difficulties,'' Ms. Armstrong said. Since its April 2 opening, the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort has hovered around the $1.3 million a day in gross gaming revenues that analysts said it needed to show a profit. However, those figures were achieved in months skewed by the attention given the opening and by higher numbers traditionally recorded by the casinos during the summer. Trump's other casinos _ Trump Castle and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino _ have posted faltering numbers since the Taj Mahal's opening. By a 4-1 vote, the commission rejected attorneys' requests to seal the documents that included a debt repayment schedule for Trump, which Ms. Armstrong termed, ``the key inquiry of the upcoming hearing.'' In another development related to Trump's restructuring, Ribis said First Boston Corp. would handle the restructuring, replacing Merrill Lynch Corp., which left last week.

DOC.HEAD: Group Seeks Control of Southmark
DOC.TEXT: Boston area investor Andre Danesh announced plans Monday to seek a major stake in the stock of Southmark Corp. which recently emerged from bankruptcy reorganization. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Danesh disclosed he and entities he controls have 9.9 percent of Southmark's common stock. Most recently, Danesh sold 176,800 Southmark shares between July 16 and Aug. 6 at prices ranging from 9 cents and 22 cents per share. But Danesh, a Brookline, Mass. investor who specializes in buying the stock of troubled companies, said he intends to buy up to 100 percent of new preferred stock, 100 percent of new notes and up to 49 percent of new common stock expected to be issued by Southmark, a Dallas-based real estate investment company, this week as part of its reorganization.
